description:
If you love peaches, MK has two decidedly decadent offerings for you. 

Hakutou Jelly is a creamy textured custard-like sin. Smells and tastes so peachy! I'm not sure how these are created, but just don't look back. Just try one. There's a mochi ice cream version too!

For a real peach, Tosenka, is a whole white peach encapsulated with the jelly. Best eaten cold, it's so refreshing!

I buy one for a friend and one for me!
author: David N.

description:
My friend and I stopped by Minamoto Kitchoan while exploring SF because Japanese sweets are amazing. When you walk into the shop you are welcomes by super sweet ladies who will help answer any of your questions. 

But there is one downside, the prices. Japanese desserts are a delicacy and look like pieces of art. Tasty art. 

My friend ended up buying a box of 6 Peach Mochi for about $12-13. Were they good? Yes! Would I go back to buy some? Maaaaybe. 

The mochi was super fresh. Very pillow-y and soft. The inside was a peach flavored cream. Quite sweet but a good white peach flavor. Check it out if you're in the area :)
author: Jessica N.

description:
I come here whenever I am in the city and my favorite is the cherry blossom mochi. 

everything tastes fresh and exquisite. Though I would say I don't like everything there.... just like cherry blossom mochi. But I see people ordering various items. 

My friend bought the famous white peach dessert to try and thought it was just ok. 

they are all on the pricey side, I think my mochi is more than $3. But this place is definitely worth checking out at least once!
author: Danika Z.

description:
Quick Summary
- Seasonal treats, so it's fun to check every month
- Conversation can be done in English and Japanese
- Treats can be purchased from individual to a gift set
- One will receive a discount after joining a membership 

What I tried and liked
- Sakuragoromo 
- Rabbit cake
- Gold fish jelly
- Sakura yokan
- Kashiwa mochi
- wine jelly
- Aya Ichigo

It's a cozy Japanese confectionary store on Market Street. It is slightly intimidating to enter, but once entering it is welcoming. They will take orders by when the customers entered the store, so one might need to be patient if there are a lot of customers inside. 

I recommend the Japanese confectionary (wagashi) over the non-Japanese (ex: Baumkuchen) and jellies. I have tried the jellies, and although I haven't tried the Baumkuchen here, I would say the reason I return to the store is for the Japanese confectionaries. 

I loved the ones with anko (red bean or white bean) paste because the sweetness is very delicate and unlike the confectionaries in general Japanese stores. There is no lasting bite attack of the overwhelming sweetness, so throughout start to finish, the treat is very pleasant and goes very well with green tea. 

The fun part about visiting the store is that most of the confectionaries are seasonal, so every month there is something changed.
author: Mito I.

description:
Pricey, but definitely a once in awhile treat.

I purchased a matcha waffle cookie sandwich and it was $3.50. Never would I buy one cookie for that price, but I really wanted it. It was packed with matcha flavor. The cookie was crunchy and the matcha cream filling was the best matcha cream filling I've ever had. Would I come back? Yes. 

Highly recommend for a treat or pick me up. Overheard that they have peach mochi but they aren't sold individually, so one day!
author: Tammy P.

description:
I've got a huge problem. This place is only two blocks away from my office. Everything they have here is delicious and authentic. The store itself makes me feel like we are in Japan. 

Yes they are expensive but it's worth it. If you buy often enough there is a loyalty program that gives a discount. I usually get the same thing (dorayaki) but I might even go for the super fancy white peach jelly desert some day. YOLO, right? 

Right on Market St and always busy. Enjoy the experience!
author: Tamami T.

description: Pretty much the same as you were to get them from japan... just 100% more surcharges lol, but oh well you didnt need to pay for the flights...
author: Jason C.

description:
I've never visited a nicer, cleaner, more beautifully displayed Japanese candy store in my life.  But, since this is the only one, I can't  even imagine one any better.

The array of handmade candies is breathtaking, and the prices also tend to make one gasp.  The candy is worth it, but still, it's not something I would regularly buy.  That said, the candy is quite delicious, and yes, some was brought home for later consumption.  Staff member Kazumi was most helpful and patient during our visit.

This is a serious candy store, almost a contraction in terms.  It is a feast for the eyes.  And sublime satisfaction for the sweet tooth.
author: Bert G.

description:
Gringo disclaimer: I have no idea what this place is, or what expensive little Japanese desserts mean to the people who shop here regularly. I don't consume mochi with any regularity, beyond the occasional box of ice cream mochi from Trader Joe's. That said, sugar is good, and I think that's pretty universally understood. 

I stopped here at the suggestion of an old colleague I hadn't seen in months - I think he was picturing a little cafe, so we were both kind of surprised when we found what was basically a See's Candies full of beautifully wrapped little desserts and hilariously friendly ladies peddling them (literally, like picking one up and telling me how tasty it is). We bought a couple, and then ate them on a bench in the Wells Fargo bank nearby. It was a unique experience for me. Seating in the place would not go unappreciated.  

I did a thorough, studious sweep of the store to understand the gist of it - pretty pricey boxes of beautiful candies/mochi-things, and individual ones that you can buy for a few bucks each. I poo-poo'd all of the ones that had chestnut (which was a good number of them), and grabbed a one-off of a Matcha-thing...it was like matcha goo wrapped in premium Nilla Wafer skin. It was great! Not looking to make it a habit of it, though. 

I also picked up a $16 box of Strawberry Mochi - 8 in the box, and they were definitely the softness, nicest mochi I've ever had in my life. They actually tasted like real, grown strawberries, not "strawberry flavor." Pretty solid, and they doubled as a sweet gift for my +1. 

All in all, I would eat more of these little things. They were really, really good, but definitely out of any price range I've ever considered for mochi. The Wells Fargo has beautiful architecture, if you're looking to make a day of it. Cheers.
author: Laura B.

description:
Running through the city I hopped into this place on Market since it had been in my bookmarks for some time. The first thing I noticed was several tourists inside ordering a bunch of stuff.

The staff here is really friendly and since this isn't a typical sweets store and kind of a niche offering they are very well versed in explaining the various options. 

I settled on two of their more "popular items" 
Kuridaifuku (Rice Cake) $3.60- Green Round mochi 
Sauramochi (Rice Cake) $3.60 -  White with a pink flower looking thing on top and bean paste in the middle 

I like the green round "plain looking" mochi one much more than the more elaborate looking Sauramochi (flower) which goes to show you that you can't judge a book by it's cover. 

All in all in a good experience but at the price point I think there are better dessert options nearby hence the 3 star rating.
author: Rod M.

description:
Amazing food, lots of selection and top notch quality ingredients. 

1. Vibe
Quaint shop located on the corner Market and Post. In typical Japanese fashion, everything is gorgeously packaged and you know exactly what you're buying. There are small cards that explain what each wagashi is which is helpful.

2. Service
The staff here had some trouble explaining what some of the items were which was frustrating, but were very polite and offered several suggestions when I was indecisive about what to get.

3. Presentation
Cute packaging gets me every time and this place does it really well. ie: peach jellies packaged inside a peach shaped paper mould, wrapped in a peach color furoshiki. Take my money.

4. Taste
Sublime taste and quality! We've tried several items from the mango mochi, peach jelly and various seibei all of which were amazing!

5. Value
All of their products are imported from specialty Japanese wagashi shops in Japan which explains the steep price tag. But for saving you the cost of airfare to Japan, what you're getting is well worth it.
author: Chris V.

description: The service here is impeccable. I was a bit intimidated because I don't know much about Japanese sweets but both the women working when I came in were lovely and explained everything to me without me even having to ask. They also gift wrapped my selections more beautifully than anywhere I've ever been, and made sure to get my approval before sealing it up. I would totally pay more for that service but they only ask $3. All the dessert prices are fair relative to their quality.
author: Annie F.

description: When coming to this place, it's a high end mochi place. I have to say it's alright because I've had better mochi from small Ma & Pa shops. Just a disappointment which both the cost and the mochi itself...
author: Kiana S.

description:
Minamoto Kitchoan is a lovely place to pick some delicious treats for yourself and others!

The shop itself is very cute and aesthetically pleasing! There are beautiful displays of different Japanese sweets and confectionaries.

On today's visit I stopped by to get a gift for a friend, and couldn't resist picking something up for myself.

For myself, I picked up a Sakura Mochi and Red bean mochi (not pictured because I ate it too quickly). The Red bean mochi was amazing! The outside was sweet and chewy and the red bean inside a little more mellow, which paired nicely with the mochi skin. The Sakura mochi was also very delicious and I loved the sweet and floral flavors it had.

For my friend, I picked up a red gift bag filled with different cookies and sweets. While I didn't get to try them myself, my friend told me they were "AMAZING"! 

The prices here are a little higher then simply going to an Asian grocery store, but the quality of the products are beyond comparison! One can truly tell the quality products, time and care are put into the creation of these confections, and I highly recommend stopping by here!!
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Japanese love fancy sweets made of agar jelly, mochi, red beans, white beans for tea time. They're called "Wagashi" in japan. 

Minamoto is one of thew few shops in the states that brings that culture to the US. The prices here are very high for desserts but it's the same in Japan for high quality sweets. You're paying a slight premium for the import, but the quality is not lost. If you've never had japanese desserts, why not stop by and buy a piece or two? 

The thing with Japanese desserts is that they're all very small so it's perfect for portion control and given how expensive everything is, you won't be able to buy large quantities anyways :P
author: Annie Z.

description:
The hakutou mochi is my absolute favorite, with soft chewiness and great flavor. I've also tried their hakutou jelly, which is pretty sweet and strong. Their rainbow senbei are just alright but taste strong and I liked their matcha best. Don't forget these will expire, but I think it's best to eat within a few days as it will not retain the same texture after being exposed to air.

The price, of course, is very expensive. (For reference, 12 tiny mochi is $22.) I believe it is worthwhile as a special treat or gift. The staff here are friendly and helpful upon asking questions.
author: Ashley P.

description:
What a beautiful little shop. Too many sweets to process in one visit. All imported from Japan and each a little work of art, nearly too pretty to eat. I stopped in looking for souvenirs for my friends back home, and was treated to full tour of all the shop's offerings, including how well any of them would travel and how long they would keep. 

I picked a sampler gift set, a custom three-piece set of chocolate pancake cookies, and some chocolate, green tea and vanilla flavored waffle cookies to put in cat-shaped gift boxes. The boxes are purchased flat, and I was shown how to fold them into the adorable Maneki Neko shape. Such friendly, attentive and personal service, like shopping with your own confections concierge!

The prices are a bit spendy, yes, but these edible artworks came a long way to be enjoyed by us stateside. Minamoto Kitchoan also has a rewards card you can sign up for that gives you $10 after you spend $100, which I found to be incredibly easy to do in this wonderland of sweets.
author: Diana J.

description:
Me walking home: "I just paid $3.60 for one piece of Kuridaifuku mochi instead of getting a legit meal..."

I am low-key regretful, but also happy to have savored a delicious, soft, and chewy Japanese sweet.  The Kuridaifuku had a whole chestnut inside!

The store is full of beautifully presented Japanese sweets with descriptions highlighting what they're made of.  I honestly stepped in because the store looked really nice and I love mochi.  There were mostly gift box sets of their Japanese sweets and a few individually-wrapped mochi that you can purchase.

The items are quite expensive, but the presentation and taste make it a wonderful gift for you and your loved ones.  I appreciate that there is a loyal card program that allows you to earn 1pt per $1.00 spent, and the points added are exactly the amount you paid (Ex: $3.60 means 3.60 points).  Once you get to 100 pts, a $10 reward will be added to your card!  It shouldn't be too difficult to reach that reward after buying a few gifts.

I would come back to try other items or buy gifts for people, but quite frankly, it's a hefty price tag so this won't be a frequent visit and I must love you lots!
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
The mochi and senbei are amazing!  We enjoyed the white peach and strawberry mochi - these were as good as it gets.  Also enjoyed the mochi filled with white bean and red bean paste - these were just as good.  A must visit to get a little taste of high quality Japanese desserts if you are in the area.  The only reason for 4 stars is the price.  It's quite expensive for the portions, but the taste is incredible.  Service is top-notch as well, so friendly and helpful explaining the different items.  

However, just a few miles away is Japantown where you can get similar quality and flavor for a cheaper price, but not as fancy, elegant, or rich.
author: Mike F.

description:
I cannot wait until summer! When the deliciously cute goldfish jellies make their anticipated return - flying straight from japan to the Minamoto stores. 

The thing I really love about this place is the verity, all of those sweet and natural flavours and - most importantly - no animal gelatin! 

Growing up, we were bombarded with sweet jellies. They were always so artificial. That's not the case with these jellies. Because they're natural, they can also expire quickly, so be sure to keep an eye on expiration dates. 

Minamoto don't just have great stock, they also have great service. 

Every time I stop by, I leave with a big smile for the whole experience (and a huge stash of sweets.) 

My tip: always ask for a gift box with wrapping, so you can feel good about spoiling yourself! They can make fantastic gifts too....
author: Andrea F.

description: One word, Expensive! I'm not sure how I feel about this place because athought it's good and they have a huge variety of sweets, it's hard to justify the price to what you get. It's a very Japanese thing for them to exert effort in the packaging and in the marketing, to even their toothpick being fancy - A+++ for that. Please see the pics I have attached to see both the options and the staggering price of their deserts. The employees here are extremely helpful and are a delight to talk to.
author: Jan R.

description:
"Okay" says my fiancé, "it's really expensive in here so let's try not to go overboard" as we walk out 20 minutes later having bought about $60 of Japanese desserts from Minamoto Kitchoan.  It's not like we have a sweet tooth or anything.  I saw the dollar signs adding on as I picked up more and more jelly-filled pastries, but at a certain point I threw all caution to the wind - an easy thing to do when there are freshly made desserts delivered directly from Japan.  In this case, less was not more.  More was more.  I needed more sweets, and oh - I got them!

My fiancé and I pounced out of Minamoto Kitchoan after being so graciously helped 15 minutes before closing the store; when arriving back at our hotel with the big bag of goodies they were immediately dumped onto the bed and torn into.  As I bought half the goods that were in the storefront, I won't even try to list each and every single one of them, but it is absolutely imperative that you know this: each one was as good as the next.  Some of the desserts tasted somewhat similar as many of the Japanese desserts are made with green tea, red bean paste and that fluffy pancake-like dough (if you can call it that).  Though there were similarities among the desserts, they each had their own distinct flavor as well.  The desserts were great, but make sure you have some water at hand as the desserts can dry you out pretty quickly do the paste-y texture of some.

The desserts were superbly fresh, but like I said - this is because they are flown in from Japan to be stocked on these very shelves.  Because the treats are flown in from Japan, these luxurious items are also somewhat expensive, hence how we walked out of Minamoto Kitchoan with $60 worth of sweets.  We'd have spent more had we caved to our own desires and gotten some of the box sets of sweets.  However, some of our self control was still withstanding and we decided to only proceed with buying individual sweets.  Most treats are available for individual purchase, but there are a few select ones that can only be bought in box sets/multiples.  My advice: get the individually wrapped/sold ones so you have more selection.  Like I said, more is more.

I also loved this little place because of how pleasant the ladies behind the counter were.  We had arrived to the store about 15 minutes before closing and they were so kind and patient with us.  Besides this, the lady helping us was so cheerful - it only made me more excited to break out the sweets when I got back to the hotel room.  Great service, beautiful and sparkling establishment, wonderful sweets (and a break from the typical dessert), and truly something one of a kind.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Do know that this place is pricey and have that expectation when you go. Their goods are high quality and imported from Japan. The service here is also excellent. The ladies who work at the shop are all so nice and welcoming. If you plan on coming here often (like I have found myself), sign up to become a member and collect points ($10 off for every $100 spent). 

I personally adore Japanese sweets. I find them to be quite artistic and so pleasing to look at. You can see the thought and patience and dedication that was put into each piece. Even the wrapping is neatly crafted and finely prepared. And that brings me to another point. The sweets here make lovely gifts. 

I've bought two gift sets so far from Minamoto each around $20. I got one that was Easter-themed and the other was a set of peach mochi. They gift wrap for you using quality paper with beautiful prints. The peach mochi were even individually wrapped inside the box. It brings to mind Roland Barthes' meditations on packages in Empire of Signs. 

"It is as if, then, the box was the object of the gift, not what it contains...as if the package's function were not to protect in space but to postpone in time; it is in the envelope that the labor of the confection (of the making) seems to be invested..." Although the individual packaging is charming, I do wonder if there can be a move to a more sustainable option. 

I came here recently for a tea ceremony demonstration. It was an intimate experience with a maximum of 3 participants for each session which was about 15 minutes. The demo took place right at the front of the store. We were each offered a sample of a selection of sweets to try. I chose the lime and lemon-flavored summer style bean jelly. 

The bean jelly was exquisite and enchanting with jelly forms of a fish and maple leaves and whole red beans all captured within a block of jelly. It was rather sweet but turned out to be the perfect pairing with the bitterness of the deliciously smooth and rich matcha green tea that was individually prepared for us right before our eyes. 

After the demo, I bought a sakura mochi and took the time to eat and enjoy it in the store. There was a small bench available for sitting. One of the ladies was sweet enough to offer me a piece of folded paper to place the mochi on (it comes in a plastic container) when she saw that I was struggling a little to take a photo of the treat.  

The mochi was a delicious savory and sweet combination. The briny leaf and sweet and smooth red bean paste filling made a surprising but wonderful pairing. The leaf was so delicate and pretty you can see its veins and the dots lining its serrated edges. The pickled sakura flower had strong floral notes. As for texture, the gelatinous rice of the mochi was so soft and pleasant to chew.
author: Lauren H.

description:
This shop is located directly across the Palace Hotel so each time I stepped foot outside our hotel, Minamoto Kitchoan beckoned me to come inside.  I finally made my way on our last day in San Francisco, and only wish I had stopped in sooner!  A week later, I'm still trying to ration my consumption... but the treats are so good I'm nearly through the $50 stash I purchased.

The wagashi are decadent and delicious... and have just the right amount of sweetness.  The textures of the filling are unlike anything I've tasted.  Everything I purchased was great, but my favorites were the matcha cookies and the matcha-filled pastries (for lack of a better word).  Yes, the treats are expensive but 100% worth it.  If/when I visit San Francisco again, I'll be sure to make a stop here!
author: Michelle S.

description:
I used to going to tea ceremonies often in Japan with my mom, when I was little, since my mom's friend was the tea ceremony master. at each tea ceremonies, They serve a beautiful and very tasty wagashi( japanese sweets) with a cup of green tea.
Those experiences made me a Wagashi lover. but I haven't eaten many wagashis since I've been in u.s. because I can't find any good. 
One day my friend gifted me Kitchoan's Sakuramochi&Kashiwamochi.
They were great! Cherry blossom leaf's scent was delightful, been paste was well pasted,got gentle sweetness and not too much. It could be a little more less sweetness for me but I bet majority of people would love this way. My daughter fought over for the last one with my husband. 
I can't wait to try other kind from them.
author: Keiko W.

description:
So many Japanese dressers here and today I go they recommend about Moon cake but I don't like it. I'm get a pain cake it nice. So they have a lot a promotional let's go inside and ask them. 
No seat here just only take home.
author: Somphop S.

description: Minamoto kitchoan is one of the most beautiful and peaceful stores I've ever been in. Keep in mind that also means "extremely intimidating" and like a hyper sensitive library when it comes to the ringing silence once you walk through the door. For a clumsy person like me, that's effing terrifying. But... Everything is laid out so beautifully that it feels like you've walked into a palace hallway of desserts, each one designed for royalty. With every luxurious bite, you're transported to Kyoto during cherry blossom season with gentle pink petals falling all around you. This is a mandatory visit for me every time I'm in San Francisco and one of my favorite places in the country.
author: Oanh M.

description: Super cute and peaceful place with the best quality Japanese treats! One of the things I liked most about this place is that the ladies behind the counter are helpful, sweet, and don't hover or try to push sales on you. There is so much to choose from and it's really difficult not to go overboard here. Definitely pricey ($3-5/dessert) and it adds up, but the tastes and looks are way too good to pass up. Will be back
author: Alaina P.

description: Best Japanese sweets store around. The matcha mochi balls are the best, as well as their kumquat mochi. Undoubtedly will be coming back often!
author: Sabrina L.

description:
I love mochi and I love sweet things in general.

Minamoto Kitchoan is the place to be for all Japanese goodies and cute packaging. 

Two friendly ladies will help you out and give you great suggestions for your sweet taste. I didn't need it, I wanted EVERYTHING!!! Buahaha

Sakura mochi = one of my favorite. Sweet and savory. MUST GET IT!!!

Kuri Daifuku mochi - red bean paste and a whole chestnut inside. 

Maccha Senbei - green tea flavored cookies with rich green tea cream.

Usagi = Yuzu flavored bean cake that comes in a cute shape of a WABBIT!

I adore this cute sweet shop and the two friendly ladies that work in this store. She gave me a tray /card-box to put the food so I can sit down and stuff my face. Hehe

I hope you give this place a try. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description: The bean cakes here are the same as the ones in NYC and just as fresh and delicious.  The shop is well maintained and the employees are helpful and friendly.  Minamoto Kitchoan offers unique gourmet Japanese desserts!  Try the peach Jelly and the Green Tea Sponge cake.
author: Melanie B.

description: This is my Mochi go to place after work I enjoy going in for some sweet desserts to bring home. They have amazing seasonal quality items and superb customer service. If you are ever in downtown SF and get a sweet tooth visit Minamoto Kitchoan!
author: Karlos G.

description:
I've seen the New York location and had always been curious of the store, so I decided to visit the SF location when I learned that it was close by.  I am a huge fan of mochi and wagashi (traditional Japanese sweets) and I certainly wasn't disappointed- in fact I came back the next day to introduce my friend to the store and buy different types of sweets!

No sitting area- just pick up and take to-go.    

The salespeople were very proactive in answering any questions about the desserts without being too pushy- they gave some good suggestions to me and my friend in picking out wagashi for ourselves and friends (assuming our friends had somewhat of an Asian / open-minded palette).

Individual sweets were $3-5... a bit pricey but was worth it:
Sakura-mochi (mochi with red bean paste and a pickled sakura leaf) - this has been my favorite from what I have tried so far; the sour leaf was a great palette cleanser to the mochi (which sometimes can be a little too sweet / one note).  Definitely a must-try!

Ayashirabe (white bean paste surrounded by cake) - the filling was different than what I've tasted before but was delicious; the cake layer was a bit thick for my personal taste.  

Kuri Daifuku (mochi with red bean paste and chestnut) - love how the chestnut added texture and more earthy flavors into the typical daifuku

Kinako Ohagi (mochi with red bean paste covered with roasted soybean powder) - I'm a huge fan of kinako (the powder) though some people might not like how it can feel like eating sawdust due to its dry texture.  However I like this texture and bean flavor on the otherwise smooth and sweet mochi.

Tsuyaguri (bean jelly with chestnut) - it was a little hard to get out of the package because it was a bit sticky, but the jelly was not too sweet and complemented the chestnut very well.  You might need to use a utensil with it because it tends to break apart easily if you try to use your fingers. 

I'll definitely be stopping by more to pick up some of my favorites and try some more of their desserts (including baumkuken and their usagi san)!
author: Audrey H.

description:
I've spent hundreds here on snacks and gifts for friends and family. You can't go wrong if you're looking for something really special and different. This is the only store in SF where you can buy high quality Japanese desserts. Here are their problems:

1. No ability to leave feedback anywhere online which is why I have to leave it here in hopes that management sees this.

2. The checkout process is way too slow. If there's a line of three or more people and all three people require some form of gift wrap, good luck getting out of there within 20mins. I know this sounds way too critical but they need to increase their staff especially over the holidays.

3. Their frequent buyer program should be accessible via phone number and not email. Again, this is to speed up the checkout process.

4. They check people out not by the order at the register but by when they walked into the store. If someone is in the store before you and they are shopping with a small basket, they get priority even though you walked in to get something behind the glass. How is this fair? Imagine if you're at a grocery store and they pulled someone ahead of you at the counter because they entered the store before you and all you wanted to do was buy a box of bubble water stacked against the front wall.

Great store but I hope they address these operations issues one day.
author: Kevin W.

description:
This place is incredible. Everything is beautifully packaged and delicately made. It was so tempting to just buy everything in the store! 

Five stars for the woman who rung me up today. She was so sweet!! I could tell she genuinely loves what she does. There was a line forming and she was patient and took her time (in a good way) with every single customer. 

I will definitely come back :)
author: Alexa P.

description:
Location: very close to Montgomery BART/MUNI stations, and to a lot of bus stops as well. Inside is clean and quiet and filled with yummy Japanese goodies. 

Service: The ladies are super quiet and friendly! They won't hover, but will help you if you ask. 

I've tried the matcha senbei, matcha langue de chat, and sakura mochi. Loved the matcha cookies - both had a very strong matcha taste. I just wish they weren't SOO expensive. Over $3 for ONE cookie?! I get maybe for the senbei, but the langue de chat is super small and still expensive. Sakura mochi is sweet, salty, and good but I'm not sure if I like it. I'm sure it's an acquired taste.
author: Shelley K.

description:
Oook I haven't actually stepped foot in the place but my friend mailed some snacks to me all the way in Phoenix. I grew up in the bay area but had no idea this existed.

HOLY MOCHI. WTF. EVERYTHING I ATE WAS AMAZING.

I had a chocolate sponge cake (amazing, super spongy, felt buttery but not oily, plus a chocolate paste between both chocolate sponge layers), sakura mochi (didn't expect to like this as much as I did but it was soooo good), sakura red bean pancake (super good and spongy), and a sweet bean cake (surprisingly my favorite one).

What in the actual eff. I'm so lucky I'm flying to San Francisco next weekend so I can hunt for more. Definitely going to see if I can stop by this place and try more flavors! I wasn't a HUGE mochi fan but now I just realized I haven't had gourmet, high-quality mochi such as these.

For reference, I ate all of the above pastries in one sitting lol. Self-control is not one of my qualities.
author: Nicola Y.

description:
If you're itching to remember what Japan tastes like, or if you like anything tasty? You must come here. You may have to pay a bit of a premium, but they've got a great selection of tasty goodies - from mochi, to cookies, to cakes. 

Sister just came back from Japan and brought a multi-layer cake. I thought I'd have to wait to go back to Japan to taste the sweet goodness - but shockingly, Minamoto has a great layer cake (baumkuchen). Super delicate, not overly sweet, and the right amount of vanilla. $27, but well worth not having to fly span. 

Most of the goodies are imported from Japan to my knowledge. Positive + negative since I was kind of hoping to find some piping hot fresh out of the oven goodies. Nonetheless, GREAT selection, will come back. 

Pro tip: sign up for their loyalty program (get a $10 credit for every $100)
author: Kristie C.

description: Expensive but fun experience to enjoy authentic Japanese mochi. Workers are very nice. We tried the kinkandaifuku rice cake and sakuramochi. Kin... was very very delicious so fresh and smooth. When u reach the middle there is a fruity goodness that enhance the experience. The sakura would of been better without the salty grape leaf. It was neat to be able to eat the cherry blossom on top. To end the experience... A nice cold bottle of Jasmine tea. YUM!!
author: lisa M.

description:
They're pricy but I've found they're the best mochi in the city so far.

When I visited they had mango, matcha green tea and white peach. They made great gifts!
author: Mandi W.

description: Can't say enough on how pretty and delicious these Japanese imported sweets are. Must try the mochi with red bean paste and cherry blossom leaf. I can eat a whole box.
author: Michael W.

description:
There are places in the U.S. that seem like they were transplanted from Japan.

Kinokuniya book store is one. This is another such example.  

I would describe this store as the Tiffany for Japanese confections.  

Goods are imported so the price is up there.
The company is based in Japan.

Everything tasted great and looked great. If anything once you visit here you will be prompted to visit Japan to see more of this. Japan travel bureau should be paying these ladies.

High-end confections with exquisite presentation.  Typical flawless customer service you get in Japan.  Stamp book for discounts on repeat purchases.

Your lady friend will likely love this place. 

Come see.
author: Jaqen H.

description: Their sweets are excellent and very high-quality! It's great for when you want sweets with a natural flavor or prefer more subtle sweetness. The mochis are delicious and very chewy, great little snacks. There are expiration dates on these so best to eat them quickly! Price may be a turn-off for most but it's worth the occasional splurge or as a gift.
author: Jade J.

description:
If you've ever been to Mitsuwa in San Jose, this shop sells the same pastries as the one in Mitsuwa Supermarket. If you want authentic Japanese desserts/pastries, this is the place to go. Price is a little steep, but the look and taste of the pastries makes it worth it. 

SWEETS: 
I tried some of their mochis before in the Mitsuwa Supermarket and their flavors are so rich, never too sweet or heavy. This time I stopped by the shop and decided to try their matcha cream cookie. For $3.50, yea it's a tad pricey, but it was the one of the most - if not the most - matcha rich cookies I've ever tasted. No hint of artificial matcha flavor in the cookie or the cream in between. And that's saying a lot considering I'm a matcha obsessed freak. I love everything matcha and bake everything matcha. 

Besides a variety of Japanese desserts, they also have cakes, mochis & these unique jello cake things. 

SERVICE: 
Workers are very friendly and professional. I almost though she was Japanese by the way she dressed and the way she applied her makeup. Makes me wonder if it's a requirement for working there. 

AMBIANCE:
Super cute! Makes me feel like I'm in a Japanese tea shop, but desserts instead. They have a cute wooden bench in the shop too if you want to sit inside to enjoy your sweets :)
author: Samantha F.

description:
As most of the other reviews state, this place is a bit pricey. However, you really get something great for what you pay. 

I went in with my brother on a random afternoon and was taken aback by the variety within the store. There were so many options to choose from including, of course, different types of mochi. I opted for the mame daifuku because I was already on a sugar high from boba. It was great! The red bean had just the right amount of sweetness and the textures were all so soft and chewy. 

If you buy larger items, you can get them wrapped in really pretty specialized wrapping paper. All of the items in store are super aesthetically pleasing, but I particularly loved the rabbit cakes which were extremely adorable. You can become a member here and accrue points over time so get on that if this is spot that you're likely to frequent.  Definitely a place you should go to if you want some quality Japanese sweets.
author: Lakshmi M.

description:
I have purchased mochi from the Honolulu location and now the SF location and while the prices are expensive this is worth it for a once in a while treat. The selection is varied and very pretty to look at. I would buy everything in this store if I could afford it! The product is consistent from store to store probably because it is imported from Japan. I have tried the maccha (matcha) mochi and the hakutou (peach) mochi. The matcha ones are soft chewy mochi pillows dusted in matcha powder with a sweet red bean filling. These are delicious and worth the price. If you get their box of 12 (individually wrapped) you are paying $1.60 per mochi. 

I will definitely stop by whenever I'm in the area because its worth it.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Best Japanese sweet store, a bit over price for some items like the citrus rabbits, but if you're reading this you must try the peach jelly.

\(^ . ^)/
author: Wolf B.

description:
I was completely sold when I saw photos of the desserts. Everything in this little shop with Japanese-style decoration is super cute and definitely does not disappoint in that aspect. The staff consisted of two really friendly Japanese women, giving the shop an even more authentic feeling. They only have a few store locations around the world and sell a wide range of mochi, peach jellies, some cakes, and other pastries and have really nice gift boxes.

The mochi are freshly made and are only good for a few days. Each of them is labeled with a good-by date. Everything looked super cute and I wanted to buy all of it! But.. I settled on 5 things to try this time: the pureed peach jelly and 4 different mochis. The pureed peach jelly, one of their popular items, was smooth and peachy and refreshing. They now also have another new kind of peach jelly! I didn't try the new one though. 

I chose 4 of the more interesting mochis - one had a chestnut in the center! The mochi itself was really soft and chewy and had a great texture, definitely high quality (none of that stuff that you buy in the refrigerated section of the supermarket). The fillings were tasty and not overwhelmingly sweet, so you could taste it in combination with the mochi and other flavors. One was covered with green tea crumbs on the outside (very different from the other plain mochi outer layers) = MUST GET!!!

Oh, and they have adorable displays in the cases! Note that the displays aren't real, but they certainly look it and are very accurate representations.

Definitely something to try! A bit pricey, but I may come back here to get small gifts or surprises for friends since it's so cute.
author: Tiffany P.

description: Very good service, nice presentation and tasty treats! It's an experience that you should partake in!
author: Edward C.

description: The cookies are very cute, but expensive! They look exactly like the cookies and cakes sold in Japan.
author: Yinjia Z.

description:
This.may.seem.strange.but.if.I.want.to.feel.as.if.I'm.in.Japan.I.visit.Minamoto's.
I've.spent.time.in.Japan.and.this.is.the,most.authentic.Japanese.food.store.in.The.City.
Expensive?Yes.But.worth.every.cent.for.the.confections.as.well.as.the.kind.service.
author: Daishin S.

description:
This is a great place to buy a gift for your boyfriend or girlfriend's parents or those who are hard to shop for...everyone loves desserts! The sweets are fresh and while pricey, the quality and service are excellent.

Not only is the packaging beautiful and sophisticated, the ladies who work here have the extra sense of Japanese forethought and sensibility. They knew that it might start raining and so they offered to cover my gift in a plastic covering. And it did start raining so good call!
author: Joan S.

description: Walking in here it was overwhelming. Sweets everywhere. I didn't know what to get. I was tempted to get one of there gift boxes set. Comes with various goodies in a pretty box. Ended up getting individual sweets. I found the green tea kasutera to be too sweet. It was however very moist which I liked. The tsuya was just as moist and sweet. This was my favorite. I got individual pieces of mochi as well. Mochi was pretty good too just pricey. They make sure to tell you about the expiration date so you eat before then. Overall great place to get some yummy sweets for you or as a gift.
author: Cathy M.

description:
One thing that amazed me of upscale department stores in Japan is how impeccably dressed the female employees were.  I can't forget a white gloved lady at the end of the escalator, just wiping down the hand rail for the next person.

No escalators here at Minamoto Kitchoan, but you do have the impeccably dressed employees, selling impeccably priced mochi with equally impeccable quality.  My favorite was the Sakura leaf wrapped mochi, which surprised me with a sweet and salty taste combination.

Take it to go; there are no tables for you to consume your purchase.
author: Ron L.

description:
Yes, it is pricey. But it's so worth it. I tried matcha mochi with chestnut and red bean--OMG it's so good and tasty, its a bit on the sweet side the chestnut is also sweetened but you can taste the roasted chestnut flavor. YUM.
I also tried the mochi with the salted cherry leaves on the outside...the flavors are so harmonious. You can't just shove this in your mouth, you have to savor every bite. 

The mochi overall is very delicate and delishousness overload.

I bit the bullet and paid $24 for a whole peach covered in jelly. I haven't eaten it yet... it better be damn good for that price...I'll update when I have eaten it. 

Great service in the store.
author: Eldar B.

description:
I've tried mochis before BUT, the ones I ate here win to all others (I'll never be the same again). Besides, these sweet treats make a really good gift; the boxes are pretty and everything is true Japanese desserts (kinda exotic right?)  
EAT MOCHI!
author: Ana I.

description:
MK might sell super mochi. I could not tell you, because I was unable to eat the mochis when I was there, due to dietary restrictions. This is not MK's fault. I know I've had some super frozen mochis from an amazing iced-mochi food truck back home in Austin. So my review might be a little unfair.

However, I did try their Hakutou jelly, which frankly (especially if you examine the ingredients) was like eating Jello with some fruit pieces floating in it. A ball of jelly the size of your palm for $4.50.

No. Whatever you do, do not waste your money on this particular product, unless you have been living under a rock and never had Jello before, and need to find out what that is like before you perish once you leave MK.

The service at MK, though, was very pleasant, and everyone seemed to be well informed on their products. However, I feel that the product I had was extremely overpriced, not to mention bleh. Erg.
author: Edison C.

description:
It seems to me anyone that has been to Japan has had an excellent time. Most people want to take a piece of Japan home. Well, the Kitchoan chain brings a piece of Japan to its various locations across the globe. 
In 2009, this Minamoto Kitchoan opened its doors on Market Street. I did not have high hopes for their longevity, because it was such a tough time for most brick-and-mortar shops, and for the economy in general. What chance did premium-priced Asian confections stand when it seemed like the rest of the world was bottoming out? Well, I was wrong about that, like I am about most things. This Kitchoan has been on Market Street for a few years, but I finally entered their doors when I was looking for holiday gifts.
I spent a great deal of time peering through their impeccably organized and display of gift boxes and gift sets. The space was very bright and immaculate. The ladies behind the counter were incredibly sweet, polite, and patient.

Kasutera/Castella - sponge cake:
super moist. I got a couple of the honey (plain) and maccha flavored ones for gifts. 

Baumkuchen - German tree cake - uniform rings of cake - like the rings of a tree:
very moist, light, and soft, too
 
Ayashirabe - creamy white bean paste wrapped in very thin layer of cake:
tastes like the white version of a moon cake

Mochi - Chocolate & Maccha:
We got a couple of individually wrapped mochi ones to try. They both had a doughy exterior. The mochi center was smooth and almost creamy as opposed to chewy and stringy compared to the frozen ones you find in grocery stores. 

I bought a couple of other boxes of mochi as gifts. They also had the same smooth consistency, which led me to think that I must not been eating very good mochi in the past.

They also offer complimentary gift-wrapping. Japanese are known for taking their packaging very seriously. I feel a slight twinge of sadness knowing it will all end up in the trash. It's hard not to appreciate the individually wrapped pieces in origami paper, wrapped in cellophane, wrapped in another gift bag, and tied with a ribbon. 

The prices reflect the upscale look of the place. Most boxed items are about $25-$50 and the individually wrapped sweets are about $3-$5. But I have to be understanding of the cost to import these delicate confections, along with the labor of love to produce consistent quality and packaging for each bite.
You can order online from their website too, but their site has room for improvement.
There is also a frequent buyer card. They stamp your card for every $5 you spend. After 20 stamps, or after you spend $100, you can redeem a $5 reward. If you buy a few gift boxes here, it's very easy to reach that reward. 
Now I'm not an expert on Japanese sweets. So if I'm not purchasing a gift, I would probably stick to purchasing the inexpensive version of these products at local Asian grocers instead.
author: Joy W.

description:
If p---y were a dessert, this mochi here would be it:  It's so addicting and soft and delicate, and even though it's really expensive to get ($3.60 for one), you still want it again and have no problem paying up the wazoo for it.  A friend once paid for me to get a 3 minute private lap dance with a stripper.  It was great.

Anyway, this place is pretty pricey for a small pillowy ball, but every now and then I stop by if I feel like I deserve a nice treat, or if I'm having a crappy day, or if I'm having a great day, or for no reason at all.  Its location on Market St. and by the BART station is very convenient, so it's not hard to find an excuse to pass by.  I don't have a particular favorite, but I always go for one of the mochis.  Unfortunately they are not like Benkyodo with the fresh strawberry or blueberry mochis.  That would be nice, since Benkyodo is such a hassle to get to, and they always seem to be on vacation when I finally make my way out to Japantown.

Whenever I come in, the ladies are so nice and welcoming.  I get a cute little tray to hold while looking around, as if I'm going to buy more than one or two mochis.  They leave me alone and aren't pushy, and always are friendly when I ask questions.

Great snack for FiDi workers who decide to play hooky and walk to the mall!  Yay for 2-hour lunches!
author: Annie A.

description: I've only been here twice for sweets and I can say confidently that the only things I think are worth buying are their jellies. When it comes to mochi, manju, baumkuchen and other cakes/cookies you can really get these at any Japanese bakery/mom and pop store in japantown (for a lot cheaper and a lot fresher) but when it comes to the jellies and other specialty wagashi, I would say go with Minamoto Kitchoan. Their pureed peach jelly and loquat jelly are delicious, simple and thankfully not to sweet and, like much of Japanese cuisine, respect the natural of flavor of the fruit/nut/whatever seasonal ingredient they put into their jellies. I can't wait to come back in the fall for their apple jelly and their persimmon sweets!
author: Emaline L.

description: Minamoto Kitchoan is a upscale Japanese sweets store. They have a lot of imports of typical Japanese sweets such as ohagi or fruit jellies as singles or gift boxes. The quality of the snacks are good but it will cost you. Best to take bart or muni here.
author: Dan C.

description: The classic mochi's texture is very very nice! Would definitely recommend especially if you are a fan of Japanese sweets!
author: Yeseul S.

description: The shop is pretty, the ladies were very nice. It's a fancy asian bakery in the middle of SF. They do have a variety of items, but way overpriced to justify buying when you can get them cheaper elsewhere. They didn't have too much Mochi either.
author: Mollie C.

description: I loved the Japanese sweets and bought a ton as gifts for people back at home. All of the mochi was soft/fresh and the other options for desserts were varied (and also awesome). I love all of the green tea flavored desserts - the green tea is definitely strong/present in the desserts, so it gives it a good balance between sweet and somewhat bitter? It is a little pricey, but definitely worth checking out.
author: Cat S.

description:
I was looking for a shop that sells delicious mochi for my boyfriend's birthday... and honestly I NEVER tried any of Minamoto's wagashi, so I was willing to put a big 50/50 chance on this shop. Based on the review I bought the white peach mochi for him.
After my boyfriend tried it, he texted me that he LOVED it and wanted more. I took him to Minamoto Kitchoan after his bday for more. 
It is pricey, but it's a lovely gift for someone's birthday.
author: Jackie T.

description:
This place is pretty great. I got cherries in jelly which were really good.

The place feels more like a jewelry store than a candy shop - everything is neatly arranged (mostly under glass) and the employees behave as if you're buying something much more significant than sugar. 

The prices are pretty high but it's not like there are tons of places to get this sort of thing.
author: Jason F.

description:
I'd been eyeing this place for a while since I love Japanese treats. Walking in, everything is super cute and the ladies working here are really sweet.

September 2013
My purchase: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/minamoto-kitchoan-san-francisco?select=DG4wOppWB0kazRqb6Pcy0g#y9pL91GBeXWQQnlM_0-s5g
*Grace dew (fruit jelly) $11 per bag http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/minamoto-kitchoan-san-francisco?select=DG4wOppWB0kazRqb6Pcy0g#DG4wOppWB0kazRqb6Pcy0g
*Hakuto shigure ($3.50) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/minamoto-kitchoan-san-francisco?select=DG4wOppWB0kazRqb6Pcy0g#pJOcuqvvwHGh5Y3pk7g6Vg
*Shimizu hakuto jelly ($13) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/minamoto-kitchoan-san-francisco?select=DG4wOppWB0kazRqb6Pcy0g#MdJKwtnPtB4aMCHBsiunDQ
*Kuri daifuku ($3) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/minamoto-kitchoan-san-francisco?select=DG4wOppWB0kazRqb6Pcy0g#5qyS5VAhXhH7K7OjhuYjRw
*Matcha bouchee ($3.50) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/minamoto-kitchoan-san-francisco?select=DG4wOppWB0kazRqb6Pcy0g#RyjffEfgDm8zRdbKrnbToA

My favorite item was the Kuri daifuku. It had a nice texture and flavor. Next time, I'd skip the fruit jelly. They just tasted like the standard fruit chews and stuck to my teeth while I ate them. Plus, I thought it was a little pricey at $11. The worst item was the Shimizu hakuto jelly. So sweet. And I didn't care for the wet jelly texture. I ended up throwing this one away.

I hate to say this since the shop is so cute, but I didn't think the treats were worth it. Maybe I picked the wrong things, but I won't be in a rush to go back.
author: Elena N.

description:
Very cute Japanese Dessert boutique on Market street, a big red bow tied around their window created a very child-like feel to this very sophisticated Sweets shop!

A must when you're in the area! Get their Mochi it is the best I've tasted!  They have a variety of sizes for all their sweets ranging from $10 - $32.

Next time I come here I'm ordering others! :P
author: Marina S.

description:
Every time I walk past Minamoto Kitchoan, I try not to go but I always end up walking out with a whole bunch of desserts!

I tried many of the mochis here but my favorite is the fresh Sakura Mochi (made and imported from Japan). These mochis have a short shelf-life, which I do not mind since I know I will devour them all during the bart ride home. The sakura mochi is HEAVENLY! You get both the sweetness from the rice and red bean filling and the saltiness from the sakura leaf and flower all in one bite. 

If you have trouble buying gifts for your friends or families, this place would be perfect! There are pre-assembled gift baskets that you can purchase from or you can choose individual items from the display case and the staff can gift wrap it for you. With the amount of detail and attention that goes into each dessert, the items can be a tad pricey but are worth every bite!

Minamoto Kitchoan is a must for delicious and unique Japanese sweets. This place will NOT disappoint.
author: Linda T.

description:
Awesome and I didn't have to drive all the way to Japantown to grab these awesome treats. Closer to Union Square this beautiful shop has high quality snacks. After having one of the Ayashirabe shaped as bunnies.. It felt horrible not wanting to share them with anyone else. 
If you go in store, they do offer shipping out of state just in case you want to mail your order and you don't want to risk them getting destroyed during travel. 

They also carry variety combos at different price levels. You can try different snacks in one box. Love this place.
author: Ellejah B.

description:
This place looks so legit and I live so nearby and just got a membership rewards card, I'm afraid I may end up reviewing every dessert in the shop before the year is out.  We'll just have to wait and see, won't we?

They sell castella cakes (from Kyushu), white peach jellies and all kinds of other sugary delights.

Worth noting:  They put some of their mochi up for sale at 50% off when it's a day old (i.e. you have to eat the sale mochi the day you buy it).


---- MOCHI ----

The mochis cost between $3.00 - $3.60 each for a pretty large piece.  You can buy cheaper versions in the fridge section of Nijiya, but these at Minamoto are obviously freshly made and more expensive.

Mame Daifuku:  4.5 stars
The most traditional daifuku mochi, filled with red bean paste and firm whole beans that add bitable texture.  Not too sweet, tastes fresh and soft, slightly savoury with the earthy bean flavour.  Reminds me of the famous Mizuho mamedaifuku in Tokyo.

Kusa Mochi:  3.5 stars
The flattened crepe-like mochi is made with mugwort leaf and has a slight herbal, grassy flavour (hence the name "Grass Mochi").  The beans are in paste form so it's more "smooth" to the "chunky" texture of the Mamedaifuku.  This one will have to be more of an acquired taste for Westerners.

Kinkan Daifuku:  4.5 stars
This is a daifuku mochi filled with white bean paste instead of the usual red.  Absolutely delicious, and there's a whole candied kumquat in the centre too for a tangy kick.


---- CAKES ----

Usagi-san:  5 stars
"Yuzu flavored white bean paste wrapped in Japanese style steamed cake rabbit shape."  Tiny, delicate and tender cake casing, healthy-tasting and not too sweet, and the yuzu filling is absolutely delicious.  Bonus points for the adorable bunny shape.
author: Letitia L.

description: My husband and I saw this place while we were roaming around San Francisco. We've never heard about this place nor did we even take the time to look at the reviews. We both absolutely love Japanese food/desserts and seeing this fancy looking dessert shop definitely caught our attention. The prices are a little high, but TOTALLLLLY worth it. We actually stopped by here on both Saturday AND Sunday, and spent ~$50 in total. So, even if you plan on not spending much... think again. LOL. The people working in here have really great customer service  I'm a huge mochi lover, so little ol' me decided to get one of every flavor! The mochi they have here are really soft and loved the fact that their sweets aren't *too sweet*. I love sweets but hate the sugar rushes, if you know what I mean. Hahaha! I've tried multiple cherry blossom mochi before and this place by far has the best cherry blossom mochi I have ever had! It's a mix between sweet and salty, and the small bit of saltiness coming from the leaf makes it taste SO GOOD. You must also definitely try their ayashirabe!! As my husband describes it, it tastes like a "better fig newton." It's so soft, smooth and rich in flavor (and it's one of the cheaper, "bang for your buck," must-try desserts)!! We also tried their peach jelly, $16. It's really smooth and also worth a try. You can request to get a cold one too if you decided to eat it right then and there. ;)
author: Kaye T.

description:
Take me back to Tokyo and sell me truly authentic Japanese sweets! I wandered into this little unassuming shop yesterday and I felt like was back in the Ginza (where I spent a lot of time when I lived in Tokyo years ago). Their products, by American standards seem a bit pricy, but I assure you dear reader they are worth every penny!

The sales lady was super sweet and very friendly. I left with a box of chocolate mini cakes that I will be happily consuming with some green tea later on today! Oishii desu yo!!!!
author: Julie T.

description:
Employees are very nice and sweet. They know their merchandise very well and can answer any question you throw at them

Some items are sold individually
author: Eric R.

description:
I am a mochi lover! Its so difficult to find a place that makes it fresh. When my boyfriend and I were visiting SF, this place was a must. Especially since I love dessert and mochi. 

The place is decorated nicely with Japanese designs everywhere. The mochi was placed in glass cabinets and organized in a way where you would be able to find things easily. There was also a food model of what the mochi looks like inside for each mochi item. I picked out 3 mochi flavors - green tea, red beans, and white chocolate. My favorite was hands down the green tea! Definitely 5 stars! The green tea was authentic. There was a special green tea crunch on top of the mochi too. The red beans mochi was good as well. However, there were bits of red beans that were slightly hard. The strawberry mochi with white chocolate filling was my least favorite. I guess I am not used to having white chocolate as a filling for mochi. 

The mochi wasn't too sweet. It was full of flavors. And most importantly, it was fresh. The balance of the mochi dough to the filling was perfect! Not too much dough and enough filling in each bite. Green tea mochi, I will come back for you! Haha. 

The service was good even though there were only two employees. I will be back! :)
author: Jenifer L.

description:
So I'm sitting here enjoying this delicious peach mochi as I'm writing this.

What a fancy place with beautiful decor. I've walked by here too many times and passed on the opportunity to try something new. Today I took a plunge and I'm glad I did. 

I purchased a 8 piece box of White Peach Mochi for $15. Soft, tender in flavor, and extremely delicate. I've only had mochi a few times in my life and I'm not a huge asian sweets fan. I would highly recommend this box if your in the same boat as myself.
author: Carrie Y.

description:
This is like my candy store of Japanese sweets and cakes I fell in love with all of the options and cakes here. Bought some mochi and fell in love. I will be back

The thing about of Japanese sweets is that it's not overly sweet and is really light. It touches a lot of taste buds too.

I will stop by here again for gifts for my family. I loved how helpful the staff was too!
author: Kim L.

description:
I had just returned from Japan and had fallen in love with a ruffled crispy cookie with vanilla cream. This cookie is called Fukuwatashi Senbei and I did all I could to find a place nearby or online to purchase more. I found minamoto kitchoan and was ecstatic. I arrived and at twice the cost of a cookie (they were sold for $3-3.50 per cookie whereas they are $1.50 each in japan :/) I decided to sample one prior to indulging in a large box. They were also called senju-senbei instead. I asked if the staff knew if they were similar to the originals in Japan and they said they thought they would be... They weren't :( their cookies were much harder and thicker with less sweetness. I barely salivated and began missing Japan more than ever. I wasn't satisfied and decided not to purchase anything else. I wish I hadn't wasted the $6 (I also bought the green tea version). 

The store was pretty but my supreme disappointment has led me to this unimpressed review. Of course, nothing probably compares to the authenticity of purchasing something directly in Japan (although don't they order their supplies from there?) but the $3 per cookie was such a rip. Had it been the same as the original or a cheaper option this rating would be higher.
author: Kristy F.

description:
I absolutely love this place. Any time there's a birthday or anniversary of some kind, I head straight to this place for treats. Everything is so incredibly delicious. 
The only downside is that once you open a big pack of mochi/etc, you have to consume them pretty quickly. The ladies who work here are incredibly knowledgeable about their products, where the items came from (i.e. these peaches came from xyz area in Japan, xyz certain farm, etc). 
Great place.
author: Mima G.

description:
My daughter brought me samples for tasting Peach Jello, Mango Jello, and candied Yuzu.
We all loved Yuzu.  Mango had a great taste but my daughter said "Trader Joe's frozen mango  give her more pleasure to eat and they are cheaper."  Peach also cannot beat the fresh peach taste yet.  The texture is soft jello made from pureed fruits and different from the ordinary jello. I went to San Francisco and tried mochi with peach filling and mango filling.  They are very addictive. 
The best of all were the two type of seasonal jello in August.  One with biwa which is similar to apricot, and the other with blueberry and pomegranate. They change the fruits in seasons.  I loved them more than the other jello.  
I will definitely ask my daughter to buy the seasonal one for every season!
author: K I.

description:
I've passed by so many times and finally walked in. I ended up purchasing their white peach mochi. It's like eating a cloud of deliciousness. Must try! 

I think I'll go back to try their mango mochi next!
author: Aneeta S.

description:
Its like being teleported to the Ginza in Tokyo.

Everything is expensive and arranged to perfection just as you would expect in the Ginza.

All of their products are imported directly from Japan. Even the staff have the appearance of being recently imported.

Thier jellies are the most expensive jellies you are likely to buy in San Francisco, but if you want a little taste of the Japanese obsession with perfection of cookies and jellies this is the real deal.
author: David T.

description:
A jewelry store of Japanese sweets!  You can easily spend 100 bucks on 3-4 boxes of dessert but hey, if you must have a guilty pleasure, wagashi is the way to go!

I can never leave the store without buying a box of usagi (bunny bean cakes). Oh man  they are yummy!

Also love the white peach mochi. Such delicate flavor just melts in your mouth.
author: Jewel L.

description:
I was surprised to learn that they import all their mochi, which is amazing given how fresh it is. That freshness only lasts a day or two, so make sure to consume your goodies quickly!

I came by on a recommendation from Jasmin, who had suggested it after reading my review on Benkyodo. I'd still prefer Benkyodo's mochi because it's freshly made every day (the mochi is softer and puttier hehe) and is more affordable, but I can definitely see the appeal of Minamoto.

Because the mochi are somewhat steep, I only bought two. The first was the KINKAN DAIFUKU, a mochi with a sweet white bean paste and a whole sweet kumquat, $3.00 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/minamoto-kitchoan-san-francisco?select=oUbbQs08bHl6thTkVpTalNg#oUbbQs08bHl6thTkVpTlNg). This was my favorite of the two because, for once, I found myself enjoying the creamy sweetness of the white bean paste over the more subtle, chunky red bean paste. Also, the sweet, dried kumquat in the middle is a pleasant kicker!

The second was the KURI DAIFUKU, a mochi filled with sweet red bean paste and a whole sweetened chestnut, $3.00 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/minamoto-kitchoan-san-francisco?select=oUbbQs08bHl6thTkVpTlNg#6gKm1BtcNYie1mqeUI25_w). The chunkier red bean paste is definitely subtler and more mellow in its sweetness than the white bean paste, with the soft chestnut in the center contributing even more to the low-key sugary tones of this mochi. I think the kuri showcases texture and subtlety, whereas the kinkan demonstrates a balanced sweetness and creaminess.

I also snapped a few pictures of some of their selection (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/minamoto-kitchoan-san-francisco?select=oUbbQs08bHl6thTkVpTlNg#dleCKS1jZjUc3EyqAqbXRQ), though I only got a blurry picture of their Kusa Mochi (sweet red bean paste wrapped in a fresh mugwort (herb) mochi), $2.50.

Their KINKAN DAIFUKU was a treat, though I would choose Benkyodo's strawberry mochi over it any day :B
author: Adele F.

description:
The short: Great place to get some delicious Japanese sweets!

As soon as I walked in, I fell for the decorating and the simplicity of this place. I wish I could afford to buy everything in the store and had to refrain to ogling with my eyes. I came in very hungry (not a good thing to do) and left with a kuri daifuku. Was it worth every penny? Yes! The mochi treat was chewy and had that mild Japanese sweetness, just melting in my mouth, holding me off briefly just before heading to lunch.

There was only one person in the store (the worker) and she was very helpful and gracious answering the questions I had.

Definitely coming back!
author: Catherine W.

description:
Sophisticate, glamorous, elegant, beautiful, terms that I generally don't use for desserts, but Japanese sweets deserve those terms.  Each piece of treat is beautifully wrapped and the attention to detail is down to a grain of sticky rice or a speck of confection sugar.  The staff are so pleasant and helpful; they will answer any questions that you might have. However, descriptions on the items are pretty much self explanatory.

Each time I come to Minamoto Kitchoan, I spend at least the first 20-30 minutes browsing each beautifully crafted piece of mochi and walking out being at least $50 poorer but my taste buds are surely happy and I probably put on a couple pounds around my waist but nothing a good workout can't fix (at least that's what I tell myself.)

I'm going to cut this review short, I can't type review and eat this delicious treat and savor every bite all at the same time. This dessert deserves my full attention.
author: LY L.

description: I came upon this place during a chocolate tasting tour. This store has such beautiful things, it's worth a visit just to see their wares up close.  I tried their leaf cookies, which where these delicate wafer type cookies with lots of layers inside. Delicious. I was overwhelmed with all the edible beauty in here. I want to try their rum cake next time I'm in the city.
author: Mel L.

description: Great tasting chocolates and assorted traditional Japanese sweets. Tasted very good.
author: Eric M.

description:
Delicious, expensive, and tasteful (as in the packaging).  I love Minamoto, it's the most perfect Japanese sweet shop.  There are abundant flavors of mochi, cakes, wafers, and everything under the sun.  The price tag is steep, you're guaranteed to spend at least over $10.  The mochi are about $3-$4 a piece, the cakes can be 10 or more, the yuzu strips are a whopping twenty dollars, and specialty items are through the roof expensive. 

I've had many mochis here, but I can't recall them all.  Most of them are good, some aren't to my liking because of an ingredient or a flavor.  HOWEVER, each mochi is well made-- the rice is well kneaded and it isn't too sweet.

My favorite thing here is the yuzu strips:  yuzu is a Japanese citrus and the rinds of the yuzu are boiled and coated in sugar.  A delicious, somewhat healthier snack than processed stuff.  However it's  20 dollars (5 more dollars than last year).  Still worth it, just not as often.

Service:  Nice ladies, helpful in explaining the items.

Definitely come here for some unique and delicious Japanese desserts.
author: Niku L.

description:
We were traveling to SF then onto Seattle to visit Japanese friends, so I thought I would bring a big box of the white peach mochi for our friends in Seattle as a second gift.  I love white peach.  It is my favorite fruit.  I bought a box of white peach mochi and also a box of mango mochi to bring home.  When I had the mango and white peach mochi I cannot taste the fruit flavor.  The texture of the mochi is very delicate and moist and nice.  I finally tried the mochi in the morning after some light green tea before I had anything else to eat,  I can taste the fruit flavor but it is still very faint.  Consider a 12 piece box cost $20 I was really expecting to taste a pop of the fruit flavor when I eat the mochi.
The store is beautiful.  Clean and bright.  The sweets are displayed as jewels in the glass cases.  The only way to know what each sweet tasted like is to buy a package and eat some.  This makes it difficult to bridge expectation to the actual taste of the products before making the purchase.  If they would have the sweets that can be purchased in single pieces, then i think it would make it easier for customers to make product selection before making final purchase.
The ladies in the store were very nice and friendly.  When I asked for the white peach mochi the lady gave me the boxes that only has the best consumed date about 3 weeks to go.  I asked if there were boxes with a later date it went unanswered.  I was not sure if she understood me.  I then asked for a box of mango mochi, it has the same date.  Think these sweets all have short shelf life.
author: Elim M.

description:
Damn. These were good. 

I had gotten 3 different ones because I wanted to try various items to get a good idea of what I like...and what I don't.  I didn't get to try the jelly and cookies that some friends have mentioned.  So *hint hint* friends get me some! 

I did end up trying 3 different mochis.  
Red bean paste with chestnut in the middle - this was delicious. I love a good red bean mochi and the chestnut was a pleasant surprise! 
Chocolate with chocolate on the outside - the was definitely my FAVORITE. I do love a great chocolate dessert and this didn't disappoint.  Yum!
Chocolate with matcha on the outside - Not that it wasn't good, I just wanted more matcha flavor.  Still good though. 

Chocolate on chocolate on chocolate. So good! 

Protip: chocolate one guys!
author: Nina Y.

description:
They finally had individual chocolate mochi for sale. I have been dying to try this East meets West concoction but was hesitant to fork over the moola for a whole box full if the dessert wasn't to my taste. It would just have gone to waste, uneaten and moldering in my pantry until I worked up the courage to throw away $$$ in the garbage. 

Well that isn't going to be a problem because I declare their chocolate mochi to be delicious. Hmmm good. Can my annual gift giving dilemma be so easily solved this year? I'm going back soon to buy a whole bunch to bestow on my friends and family.

chocora mikasa $4.50
langue dark $3.30
maccya busse $3.50
hakuto sigure $4.00
kuri sigure $4.30
chokora mochi $4.20
sakura goromo $5.00
benihana ringo $4.50
author: Cece E.

description:
Although I dreamt to become Peter Pan instead of Snow White as a child, I enjoyed being treated like a princess at Minamoto. The polite staff patiently explained various types of Wagashi (Japanese-style sweets) to me, my brother and my friend. Without doubt, Minamoto is the perfect place to impress your friends and dates who love authentic Japanese food. 

While Snow White was elegant as she ate her apple, I reverted back to a desperate hipster as I enjoyed the Wagashi that is made out of fresh seasonal fruits at Minamoto. I highly recommend the Hakutou jelly (peach jelly), which is made with Hakutou peaches from Okayama, Japan and mineral rich spring water. The gentle floral and peach aroma made me felt like as if I was picking peaches in a field with the seven dwarfs. 

My brother, the self-proclaimed Prince Charming, enjoyed eating the crunchy seaweed cracker and told me that he would love to propose to his girlfriend with this cracker one day. After I told him that he would definitely get attacked by angry dwarfs for doing such cheap proposal, he decided to get honey katsutera (sponge cake) and bring it back to Miami. He recommended Yelpers to indulge the cake as soon as possible, otherwise it would dry up. 

My friend, who views Doraemon rather than Prince Charming as his role model, greatly enjoyed the chocolate tsuya (pancake with fillings). Normally, tsuya is filled with red bean paste. However, I agree with him that red bean is an acquired taste. 

If Hipster, Prince Charming, and Doraemon all enjoyed the Japanese-style sweets at Minamoto, I am confident that you would love it too!
author: May Y.

description:
This is one of those cute little shops with such charisma and character that you end up staying for a long time to admire all the unique, artistic products.  

Pricey?  Yes.  But if you're going to pay $3 for the average latte and/or $2.25 for a generic pastry at Starbucks, the hand-crafted specialty mochi here suddenly don't seem so overpriced.  

Everything about this store is charming and true to Japanese tradition.  Each item has an informative description and an expiration date.  With some of the expiration dates being within a week, I'm sure they strive to maintain freshness and high quality.  

The staff have courteous Japanese mannerisms and are very helpful.  As I was paying, they even explained to me instructions on how to serve the different types of mochi!

Leaving the store into the bustling Market St. of the City is like going back to reality, until you can enjoy the yummy dessert when you go home :)
author: Edna C.

description:
Seeking a small snack before class, I grabbed something than my usual sweets...I grabbed a bag of beika ebi: baked glutinous shrimp rice crackers. 

Ever since I first stepped foot into this shop, I'd look at the savory rice snacks that they had to offer but never really bought a bag for myself until now. Probably because they were priced to be around $5. Today, they seemed more interesting for some reason and it was that particular bag of shrimp chips that caught my eye. I think it's because it was a nice pink color.

I opened my bag right away and ate a few pieces before going to class. Unlike most shrimp rice crackers (or rice crackers in general) from most Asian markets and stores, these rice crackers did not assault my palate with MSG extreme saltiness or powder flavor. The flavor is found within the cracker.

That being said...although I appreciate that there weren't really any artificial flavorings in these crackers, I can't help but think that they lacked flavor. The texture was different too. High quality, yes, but not a texture I like to chew on. It's hard to explain if you haven't had such glutinous rice crackers before.

Anyway, I probably won't buy any more savory snacks. They were okay, but they really didn't win me over.
author: Sofia R.

description:
I'm generally an advocate against desserts (especially American desserts). But Japanese desserts are a whole different ball game!!! Step into Minamoto Kitch(oa)n and you will find yourself in Wagashi heaven. 

Everything is handmade in Japan and flown in frozen. The desserts on the floor are defrosted daily. Purchases should be consumed same day for maximum freshness, but you can get away with next-day consumption :) 

I'm always picking up little Daifuku mochi's at the Asian market. Don't forget the Dorayaki pancakes! Minamoto has all of these in an astonishing variety. The two days I was in SF, I made 3 trips here. Out of guilt, I ran down the hill from the apartment to go dessert shopping. The challenge came when attempting to run uphill to go home with a bag full of sweets. #fatkidstatus

The Sakura Mochi which is one of their top sellers--and I can see why--was the most delicious of my purchases. Sticky, sans potato starch, sweet red bean paste, salted Sakura leaf, and an adorable preserved Sakura flower. Sampled the Kinako Ohagi (sweet red bean paste, soybean powder) which came in at a solid 2nd. Followed closely by the Kurogoma Ohagi (sweet red bean, black sesame) which was my 3rd favorite.

Honestly, you can't go wrong in here. They have delicious bites which start at $1.50 and average in the $2.80-$4.00 range. They even have gift collections available if you have someone REALLLLLLLY $pecial in your life. I would suggest the little citrus bean filled bunnies. Even if they aren't delicious (they are, don't worry), they're too adorable to pass up.

Don't forget to pick up a stamp card! They don't have an expiration date so they're perfect for people who frequent the city but don't actually live there (T_T).
author: Yuhi K.

description: I saw their booth at the J-Pop Summit's Sake and Matcha Summit at Union Square. For this weekend only at the booth, they're offering a combo package with one white peach mochi and one matcha mochi for $4, which is not available in store. I decided to purchase one and tried it the next day. For mochi imported from Japan, the mochi was still very fresh and soft. I loved it. I look forward to visiting their store next to Montgomery Street station.
author: Diana B.

description:
I bought $70 worth of Japanese treats here and by my checking account's calculations I had no right to do so, but it had to be done.

This is the treat shop you stop at when you want to impress someone, even if that someone is yourself.  It's pricey because it's flown all the way from Japan, it's beautifully packaged, and it's all high quality ingredients.  These treats aren't your usual sugar ladened desserts.   You're supposed to savor them, enjoy them with tea, and appreciate their subtle sweetness.

Their mochis are soft and pillowy.  I bought the Sakuradaifuku (cherry blossom) and the Kinkandaifuku (kumquat).  They were both good but I preferred the juicy kumquat surprise in the middle of the last one.
