The Momoaya is a white peach jelly and that was just all juicy goodness.  I think I should have chilled it first and it would have been better as a light after dinner treat.   

I bought two other jellies, the kinds where you put them in the freezer to eat like sherbet. One was white peach and the other was melon. Both are delicious and delicate in taste. Perfect way to beat the summer heat. So good!

The sweetest dessert that I tried was the Ayashirabe.  I really enjoyed it.  It's soft and sweet and has condensed milk in it.  The outside is similar to the outside of a pound cake, velvety.

Speaking of pound cakes, I also spent almost $30 on the baumkuchen cake.  It's light and subtly sweet with hints of almond and rum.  It's a sponge like cake, very simple yet kinda elegant.  Would be great with tea, and maybe my sister's homemade whipped cream and some fresh berries.  I came here specifically for baumkuchen, ever since I saw the Youtube video on how it's made, I've been curious to how it tastes.  It's nice.  If I was richer and wanted to bring a cake to tea time with fancy people, this would be it.  I'm glad I tried it.

Other thangs:

Street parking is a bitch.
Join their frequent buyers card, fill it up and get something for $5 free.
Nice and helpful service.
author: Walerz B.

description:
I MUST stop by this Japanese sweets shop whenever I'm in the area. The confections are not only exquisitely packaged, but they're also heavenly! The mochi is the freshest and softest you can find! I also love the red bean and chocolate pancakes, jellies, peach and white bean paste pastry, milk-flavored white bean cake and green tea sponge cake sandwich. These treats are on the pricey side, but perfect for an afternoon pick-me-up or elegant gift. 

Make sure to ask for a stamp card to accumulate repeat purchases for discounts.
author: Suany W.

description: Handmade dessert imported from Japan, great service and prefect sweetness in every single dessert. Costly but worth it.
author: Louie Z.

description:
Pros:
- cherry blossom mochi (super soft mochi and sweet filling)
- nice, clean shop
- helpful and knowledgable staff
- good for gifts! (pretty packaging and quality ingredients)

Cons:
- on the pricier side ( $3 for 1 ball of mochi)

Bottom line: I really enjoyed the mochi! I haven't had that many... but this might have been the best I've ever tried. If you prefer mochi to be soft and only slightly chewy, you will probably like this place.
author: Jiann M.

description:
Wow talk about expensive sweets!  Every item is an art form in and of itself.  I was intrigued by the window display.  All of their desserts and mochi items looked so delicious!  

I know for us Americans, we usually think of mochi as  glutinous rice cakes with ice cream filling.  Don't get me wrong because I absolutely LOVE that stuff.  However, I don't think the Japanese actually eat it that way.  When I was in the store, several patrons came in asking that same question: "Do you have ice cream mochi?"  Traditionally, the mochi is usually filled with red bean paste or green tea paste.  

Upon entry, we were greeted by two lovely Japanese ladies who welcomed us in Japanese.  We browsed around the store for a bit because all of this was so foreign to me.  All the pieces were so visually appetizing that I wanted to try everything.  After much contemplation, I decided to I try the Momoaya and the Sakura Daifuku.  The Momoaya was simply exquisite!  It is Japanese white peach jelly, and it just tasted so refreshing and sweet.  I wish they made it in a bigger portion, but even that little size cost about $4.  The Sakura Daifuku is essentially a sakura flower's flavor within a mochi.. it was pretty good too, but definitely not as yummy as the Momoaya.

I totally felt like I was in a small boutique shop in Japan.  It was artfully delicious.  However, I'm only giving it 4 stars because of the price.  You could easily spend $20 for only a few pieces of these sweets.
author: Cecilia S.

description:
Came here looking for a baumkuchen. Not the most common dessert in SF so I yelped for a place that had it. Theirs was so light and sweet. A little too sweet by itself, but great with green tea. Around $28 for the cake. They have them frozen, so let it defrost for a few hours.

Service was extremely polite. Place looks beautiful. And they gave me a stamp rewards card, which means I'll be going back.
author: Teresa P.

description:
Overall: Pricey yet good desserts.  They accept cards! They'll even give you a stamp card for every $5 purchase. Don't worry, you'll be spending way more than just $5 in there.  Everything is between $3-$5 per piece. 

Food: I don't remember the names, but I picked up everything with red bean.  There was one filled with red bean, one with green tea wrapped and red bean inside, soybean wrapped with red bean inside, and a peach mochi.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: So these desserts are pretty pricey but whenever I'm in the area I always stop to pick some up! They are so delicious and addicting. I have tried the cookies, red bean cakes and mochi. They are all awesome! I definitely recommend trying this place out once!
author: Nia R.

description:
Minamoto Kitchoan is one of the most well known higher end Wagashi brand. They have stores all over the world in all major continents. Most Wagashi are quite different from the western style pastries. They come in many varieties. Some with seasonal fruits, some with bean paste, some are like daifuku and mochi with all kinds fillings. Honestly, some of those might be more of an acquired taste. If you never had Wagashi before, it is very important to carefully pick something you (or your lucky gift recipient) would like. They have very good description of what each Wagashi is made out of. Don't be afraid to read and browse slowly. You really can't judge what they are based on the look. Those ladies working in the store are all very courteous and not pushy at all so do take your time. 

I think in general bean paste based ones are not as appealing to people used to the sweeter western style desserts. The flavors are more delicate and the texture is drier. Daifuku with fruity fillings are always a safe choice. Most people love those including little kids. They also have some western style Wagashi but I have yet to try those.

These goodies aren't cheap and the shelf life is often rather short (a few days for most). Enjoy them while they are fresh!
author: Mona W.

description:
Stopped in the other day and got some wonderful, and very cute, goodies to take home. I love the way they individually package their products and will place in a really nice box (for just a small fee) or placed in a really cute small bag that has minimal designs on it.  The cakes are also not too sweet and very delicate.

The only reason I took off a store is some of their items are really too costly for me, and being on a budget doesn't help when everything looks so good or is so cute. However, everything is imported so that's pretty important that they take such great care of their goods. Excellent service too. I'll definitely come back whenever I'm in town again.
author: Darline G.

description:
Minamoto Kitchoan is THE place to get authentic mochi. Their white peach mochi and sakura mochi are mindblowing to eat. I definitely recommend the white peach -- it is absolutely delicious. It runs from around $3.00 - $5.00 per mochi, but it is worth every penny. 

The staff was of great aid when I needed help with what mochi I wanted to take home. They really know their mochi! 

I am really excited because I have also bought a box of ten usagi buns filled with a bean paste that is citrus flavored.. I imagine it to be phenomenal. I will edit this review soon and say how it tastes! They are just too cute!

-- I have tried the usagi, and it was downright amazing! The citrus was definitely low-key, so it did not ruin the whole experience of eating the cute bun! It was a little dry, but the taste made up for it!
author: Rachelle V.

description:
My friend's been saying she wanted to take me to this mochi shop for a while.  I guess I couldn't wait anymore and made my first visit on a recent trip to the city.

I could barely contain my excitement when I approached the store and stepped inside.  What a beautiful shop!  I love how it's so tastefully decorated.  I would like the whole store, please.  Just wrap 'er up.  Back to reality...I grabbed myself a basket and would have deliriously/happily skipped through the store, picking one of each goody for purchase, if I hadn't consider how ridiculous I'd look to the nice customer service ladies.  I'd probably freak them out, thinking I'm a mental patient.  BUT, I just LOVE LOVE Japanese snacks!!!  I don't know if anyone else really shares the same obsession...

Yes, I did grab one of everything (practically).  The compulsion was too great to resist.  Wagashi -- mochi, jellies, little pancake-like sandwiched together, and sponge cakes, all with red or white bean paste, chestnut filling, or whole fruit.  The products are quite pricey, but they've come a long way from Japan...so you know they're authentic!  The grand total was $55 with tax.  Yes, I did expect it to be around $40 something but then again, I'm not the greatest with math...despite your usual Asian stereotypes.  Yup, I've filled half my punch card already!  With one visit!

Somehow when all my goodies were packed in 3 paper bags in a bigger shopping bag, it seemed like a lot.  But when I brought them home and unpacked everything (see photo). the number didn't seem too outrageous.  I've even have them all sorted out by expiration date...which needs to be consumed first...hahaha.  The mochi does not keep long but for a day or two.  Freshness is not guaranteed beyond the date on the little sticker.  So, there...your excuse to gobble these little, precious, delectable morsels without hesitation or guilt.

My first tasting was the mochi with sesame seed and red bean paste filling...MMmmm....
author: Melinda Y.

description: I used to frequent the Minamoto Kitchoan in New York City and was really happy that there is one in San Francisco too! I love their kasutera, different kinds of mochi, fruit jellies, and other seasonal treats. As with other wagashi, the sweets made here exude the unique flavors of the ingredients and are gorgeous to look at! They're almost too pretty to eat! I love the spring seasonal pastries as they have cherry blossom flavors infused.
author: Sherry L.

description:
I love the Japanese Sweets here!

I've gone here a couple times on different San Fran day trips since I've been living back in Sacramento, CA. I discovered it the first time I went by happenstance. I was walking down Market Street. I went in because it was so lovely from the outside. To my surprise it was a Japanese Sweets Boutique. I went inside and purchased a variety of sweets, all that I really enjoyed. My favorite was their Chocolate Mochi. I just love their Chocolate Mochi!

So yes, I'm definitely looking forward to trying even more of their Japanese sweets!

Keep up with them on facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/Minamoto-Kitchoan-SF-129368650419044/
author: Janice Marie F.

description: I love anything matcha, mochi, sesame, red bean, and lotus. I also love beautiful packaging. If you're the same, stop reading this and just go straight to Minamoto Kitchoan. This place is great for gifts because everything is already beautiful, and they do a great gift wrapping job. I've never been to Japan, but I imagine the interior is a very accurate recreation of what it might be like in a Japanese pastry shop. The employees are all Japanese which gives me the impression of product authenticity. I can't really recommend any particular item because every time I go I get something different and forget the name immediately, but I've never been disappointed. Quite the opposite, in fact. It's a true delight to step into this little haven after a tough day at work, or roughing it around soma/mission/market which can be kind of nasty sometimes as you may or may not know.
author: Shayan S.

description:
Beatifully crafted mochi! 

I bought two different kinds of daifuku mochi here. One had a red bean filling and a sweet chestnut in the middle. The other had a white bean paste with a kumquat in the center. Both were light and not too sweet. The filling felt like it was almost whipped in consistently rather than clumpy and uneven. The outside layer of mochi was not thick, but also not so thin that the filling could break through. 

I saw a sign that read all of the desserts here are imported from Japan for quality reasons. However when I purchased the mochi the cashier warned me that the mochi has a short shelf life and should be eaten ideally in the same day. Not sure if I believe they have daily shipments of mochi, but maybe only some of the cakes are imported and others are made on site. 
I didn't try any of the other sweets but the items in the display case looked to be high quality and nicely packaged. Looks like a great place to come and buy a present in the future.
author: Kailin L.

description: Beware of this store's no refund/return/exchange policy. I purchased what I thought was a $14 canister of green tea, and did not realize until I got the receipt by email that it had cost me $40. Perhaps I mixed up this canister for something right next to it for the lower price. Whatever the case, the store was completely inflexible about me returning it, even though I haven't opened it and it's sealed in plastic. I could understand if it was an opened food product, but to be so steadfast on all products is not a good customer service policy.
author: Anne T.

description:
This place is a fancy Japanese desert place which you take it for to go.
It is not a cafe which i thought lol

The interior is very clean and the staff is very helpful and nice. 

Every single dessert looked so good. I wish I could buy it all!!

I tried the green tea boumkuchen. Never tried green tea version. 
They only had a frozen one. They told me to eat it in 1-1 1/2 hrs. It did not taste like it was in the freezer.
It tasted soooo goooood!!!

Def coming back and going to try different desert!
author: R R.

description:
4 star for the delicious mochi and cakes. 
5 star for the tea ceremony. Nice packing, could be a nice gift.
author: Alice H.

description:
I still haven't been inside this store yet, and have just driven by a few times. However, I was lucky enough to have my friend order a few things for my birthday gift, and I got to try their most popular items. She paid extra for them to package the items in a beautiful box, but their packaging still looked fine without the fancy box. I tried:

-Dark Chocolate Mochi (Chocolate Covered Mochi w/a Creamy Chocolate Center, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/minamoto-kitchoan-san-francisco?select=AU5rt-0BgkvaumWssTcr_A#AU5rt-0BgkvaumWssTcr_A): Yum! The mochi was super soft and chewy, and had a good dark chocolate taste without being too sweet. Highly recommended!
-Green Tea White Chocolate Mochi (Green Tea Covered Mochi w/White Chocolate Filling, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/minamoto-kitchoan-san-francisco?select=AU5rt-0BgkvaumWssTcr_A#DXE_W1vMf-qa-x-n0LiWHA): Also yum! The white chocolate was a little sweeter than the dark chocolate, but it was still delicious. However, I preferred the dark chocolate over the white.
-White Peach Mochi? Jelly? (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/minamoto-kitchoan-san-francisco?select=AU5rt-0BgkvaumWssTcr_A#1lbAYcPYqL09i0hH6KfgIQ): Unfortunately, I can't remember exactly what dessert this was (super behind on Yelp reviews right now!) but I remember it was good! It was a white peach flavored dessert. Recommended!
-Hakutoujelly (White Peach Japanese Style Jelly, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/minamoto-kitchoan-san-francisco?select=AU5rt-0BgkvaumWssTcr_A#nifew2c7fL8jyu8rWt-g_w): I didn't like this one =( The gelatin was really smooth, and there was a good white peach flavor, but it also tasted a little fake, and I thought the gelatin was too thick. Skip!
-Jyukushinosato (Persimmon Flavor Jelly): On the website it says $12, but I hope my friend didn't pay that much for one jelly! I didn't like the taste of this at all or the thick texture of their gelatin (again). Skip!

If I knew the prices of the desserts, I might change my mind about my review a little, but since they were a gift, I really enjoyed them and highly recommend trying them out if you haven't been! I really enjoyed the cute packaging, and that their desserts weren't too sweet.  The parking around this area is pretty tough, and I recommend avoiding the weekday rush hour traffic!
author: Amy D.

description:
The pinnacle of mochi in SF.  I've eaten mochi everywhere and this store is the creme de la creme.  It's a small store, and they never pack it to feel cluttered. It's nicely laid out, the people are extremely attentive and they make you feel welcomed.

I always stop by here to get some omiyage whenever I visit SF.
author: Toby I.

description:
I love Minamoto Kitchoan! I love it so much, I have a special punch card, but it will take me a while to fill it up since everything is so small here. 

These wagashi treats are delicious, but they definitely are an acquired taste. Many people that have never had Asian sweets such as jellies, custards, and bean pastes will *not* like these. These sweets do not have that much sugar in them, but they really let the ingredients shine. 

Since they aren't overly sweet, they don't bog you down, but refresh you. You can have one of the denser sweets like the bean pastes with tea or coffee for a satisfying afternoon snack.

I love going in to see what the new seasons have brought in, or to get tried-and-true staples such as the ume shu jelly for myseld or the white bean custard crepe for my dad.

When I went this past time to the store, I think I literally bought one of everything. The ringo (apple) jelly had a nice cinnamon flavor in the outside, and the sakuranbo (cherry) was mildly sweet and moist, not to mention beautiful to look at.

I was surprised this store wasn't in Japantown, but rather near Union Square on Market Street. It seemed a tad out of place, but once I was inside, I was happy and started filling up my basket with all these edible gems. 

By the way, they also sell variety packs that would make great gifts for family or friends, if you think they are worthy. The boxes and bags they wrap everything in are so simple yet beautiful, and they let me use my NJ/NY punch card here, even though I wasn't allowed to (shhh!)
author: Nicole O.

description:
Who would ever give this place a four?
When I'm on Monument, and I'm feeling like a nice guy, I buy a few sakura mochi and bring them home to people. 
I tell them to eat the leaf. They say no. I force them. They say, "Oh, I was wrong."
The staff is incredibly kind, as most Nihonjin are, so I wish I could come back more often if it wouldn't get me fat.
author: Sean H.

description:
I am always looking for unique places and food and I had to stop when I saw a sign that said Japanese sweets. You don't see many (any) of those. The store looked great and inviting. The food display looked like a jewelry store as opposed to a bakery.  Apparently this is a chain but this is the only store in SF.

The ladies who work work were super nice and help me navigate all the choices.
She guided me to a couple of different kinds of mochi and I tried the sesame and cherry blossom.  The cherry blossom looked interesting and was wrapped in a leaf, great presentation.  The taste however too different for me and I did not enjoy either one, I guess it is an acquired taste.  I will be stick to Beard Papa for my Japanese desserts.
author: Sunil R.

description: the fresh chocolates are awesome, it's really hard to find those in american dessert stores somehow(unlike in asia), however i read about this place on yelp from the first time and saw the dark chcocate mochi so i went there just for that but they said that the main store back in japan is not sending them the dark chocolate mochis cuz its too popular back in the mainland...you should take down all the dark chocolate mochi pictures on yelp unless you're gonna sell them here again, lol
author: Jaesang C.

description:
I can't believe I have walked past this store so many times and never went it! It sells authentic Japanese sweets and has very nice Japanese women who help. They also have things that are only seasonal! 
Some of the highlights:
The black sesame mochi was very good. Chewy and and just delicious! 
The green tea cookie was good but a bit too dry. 
There was this red bean cake which was very rich and delicious. 
Probably my favorite was the peach jelly that you can freeze so that it becomes like a sherbert. Very nice for the summer!
author: Kristy K.

description: A bit pricey but it's well worth it if you appreciate delicate Japanese desserts. My favorite is the Castella cake. There are sugar crystals forming on the bottom which gives the cake this awesome crunchy texture. The cake is not too sweet so you can eat many slices without getting sweetened out.
author: Joseph L.

description: I was blown away how good these mochi are. I tasted my daughters mochi and about an hour later we were back to buy a box of them. A great treat.
author: Chris P.

description: This manju shop lures the sensibilities serenely with its gorgeously packaged morsels of rice and bean cakes. The pastries are of the highest quality you can get in the U.S., with high prices to match. But they are a treat in which to indulge if you are a manju aficionado. Love love love this little shop. Wish it were in Seattle, closer to where I live.
author: arlene j.

description: The shop can feel a little intimidating with everything behind glass; however, these mochi are bar-none the best I've ever had. Feels pricey but who cares if it is just one? Beautiful artisanal desserts, great for gifts.
author: Grace C.

description:
I am OBSESSED with Japan.. especially their culture and FOOD.

I've had this place bookmarked for awhile but because it closes early and parking is tough around the area so I haven't had a chance to visit until now.  Unfortunately I didn't see any sakura mochis or bunny cakes!

My haul:
Fukuwatashi Senbei (Vanilla cream between two wafers)
Maccha Busse (Green tea sponge cake)
Shocora Mikasa (Chocolate "pancakes" surrounding chocolate cream)
Tsuya (two small pancakes with red been inbetween)
Shimizukage (Plum jelly)
Fukufukusa (folded sponge cake with red been inside, taco style)
Genrokukoban (almond cake with red bean inside)
Kibimochi (rice cake with bean filling)
Ayashirabe (kidney bean cake)
Maccha Manjyu (green tea cake)

Total $29.00 and so worth it!

I'm eating one a day, slowly savoring it, with a cup of hot genmai cha.  Everything is packaged so nicely that I feel like I have to eat it with a knife and fork, which I have been doing.  I'm so happy right now :) I'm totally coming back!  Hopefully soon!
author: Vivian H.

description:
Great interior design, this place looks amazing and their products taste amazing. 
Best mochis in San Francisco!
author: Ra A.

description:
A-OK indeed.  There's not many little shops in SF that sell cute seasonal treats and desserts from Japan.  This place sells all sorts of cute creations that you would find in Japan.  These are fresh so you really have to check the date to make sure they aren't expired.

So why only 3 stars?  Because I have access to Mitsuwa in the South Bay and whatever I found here I also found at J Sweets in Mitsuwa.  Granted it is unreasonable to compare 2 stores 50 miles apart because they cater to different locations.  But J Sweets has a bigger selection of items (including cute Hello Kitty gaufres, bakery items, macarons and MochiCream) and they have a stamp card.

So if I had to choose, hands down I would go to J Sweets instead of Minamoto Kitchoan.  But if I'm in the area I might be tempted to stop in for a daifuku.
author: Vicky C.

description:
Oishii!

I received a box of sweets from a specific store I had walked past the other day with the fellow.  He must have watched my sudden interest and listened carefully when I explained the Japanese process of gifting or better known as omiyage because the next week, I received a box of delightful Wagashi, or otherwise known as Japanese sweets.

Although I do not indulge much of these starchy thick cuts of sweetness, they are well appreciated by my family, especially the elders.  They enjoy it with a cup of hot tea.

Our box held the following, a fine assortment of Yokan (sounds like Yo-o-kan) made from green tea and azuki bean paste.  Again, these are extremely sweet and typically nibbled on while sipping tea, so don't expect to pop them one after another.  In addition to the sweetness is the visual appreciation of these small confections.

The shop itself is done high brow touristy style but I found it typical of shops lining the Ginza district: accomodating to austere audiences with a tendency to OCD cleaniness, with the staff bowing and saying "Irraishaimase."  One of my favorite shops in Nihon is Toraya, which has been around since the 1600's and for further education, I'd recommend reading this page all about Wagashi (http://www.toraya-group.co.jp/english/wagashi/types.html)

What I am saying, is if you date a lady who is Japanese (think close to 1st gen), remember to bring a form of omiyage when you go visit the family.  This shop will help you garner those extra + points.

My parents were impressed  ;o)
author: Miika M.

description:
Far be it for me to dis da sistuhs at Minamoto Kitchoan. They're a lovely group and bring a tear to my eye since they remind me of my dearly departed oka-san. And the shop impeccably presents a broad variety of wagashi that reminds me of the omiyage my mom used to make me give to my relatives after temple on Sundays. But I am wondering if  the Ginza-gauging prices necessary to sell the wagashi makes this any more than a one-stop curiosity shop.

I felt a need to support my sistuhs, so I bought four of the cheaper little treats (see photos). They reminded me of how hit-and-miss these sweets are for the uninitiated. I am not a manju freak by any shot as I usually can get through only half of one at Benkyodo unless it's the peanut butter manju. Those I like. Anyway, it was hard to decide which ones to get based on the packaging and the descriptions in kanji. I went for the Oribenishiki ($2.50), a bean cake with the imprint of the five-lobed compound leaf on its brown top (see photo). That apparently signifies that there is a combination of chestnut and dark red bean pastes inside. Meh.

The second was a white-bean jelly called Tsuyaguri ($1.60), a gelatinous bean cake filled with minced chestnuts. Another meh. The third was a mini-jelly cup of plum wine jelly with an actual plum in the middle, Kohakukanume ($4). It was rather sloppy to eat and yet again, meh. The last one I had was the Macchamanjyu ($2.80), a pale-green sugar-dusted rice cake filled with red bean paste with a chewy chestnut in the middle. OK, that was the best of the bunch, but it took me twelve bucks to get there.

Listen, I don't fault the staff for the lofty pricing. I have to believe it's expensive to import these things from the motherland, but the owners should really consider that we are in the middle of a recession in this country. Maybe a more Costco-oriented approach could bring a new audience of wagashi warriors. Meanwhile, the manju elitist can rejoice with Minamoto Kitchoan. All three of you.
author: Ed U.

description:
Me and my boyfriend always pass by this place but never walked in for two reasons: 
1) they close too early so we always miss it.
2) looks intimidatingly expensive

However, we finally went in!!! It wasn't as expensive as I thought it was. There's so many choices!!! I, for one, am not too fond of choices because I am very indecisive and it takes me forever to pick something, so my friends and I were in here for a while until I made up my mind on which ones I wanted to try. I ended up buying four different things. I don't remember what the names were but I can definitely tell you that all four of them had mochi, because I am in love with mochi 

4 desserts for about $18--- not bad. It was worth it; the desserts were so soft and perfectly sweet (not too sweet); the bean pastes balanced everything out and I was just absolutely in love with he mochi man!! There were some special instructions for some of the ones I bought, like one of them I had to eat by the next day and the other one was only good by he end of the day.

Overall, it was a good experience and I would definitely come back for more
author: Jorgess M.

description:
Every time I visit the city, I have to make a visit to Minamoto Kitchoan. Let me tell you folks, I love mochi and this place has a pretty good assortment of them.  I usually purchase the black sesame and the sakura (both the pink and saltier versions) mochis. 

I love the black sesame mochi because it has a sweet and nutty flavor that isn't too overpowering since I tend to hate sweet things.  The sakura (cherry blossom) ones are a treat since they remind of me spring (haha, I don't know how else to describe it), but it brings warm feelings to me.

This time around I tried the peach mochi since it's in season. This one was white bean paste mixed with peach.  It was very light and similar to the other mochis, not too sweet.  

I also recommend Aya-shirabe (red bean cake) that's wrapped in a white package with origami cranes printed on it.  This one is delightful with a hot cup of tea or some coffee.

They also do a wonderful job of gift boxing if you're interested. My friend got his goodies wrapped up and ready for his friend over in NYC.  I'm sure they'll enjoy it.

I also like that they have a stamp card thing going on.  If you purchase $5 you get one stamp on your card and once you fill it up you get $5 off (hey, at least I'm saving somehow).
author: Michelle V.

description:
If this place were a little dog, I would have petted it.  Yeah, it's pretty cute.

So I walked in when coming across it, figuring they'd have a few things I'd want.  They kept offering me a tiny basket to put everything in, but I didn't want to buy too much so kept declining.  Love the presentation of the items here, and all the products have a pretty detailed description (some of the pics illustrate this well), which helps since I can't read Japanese and it's not easy to know what's inside something only by looking at it.

The prices were about as I expected, not cheap but not a total ripoff these days for a place like this.  For $10.20, I got shirogasane (green tea flavored), shocora mikasa (chocolate), and benimitsu ringo (apple w/ cinnamon).  Yeah, I'm sure you know what all these are.  After eating them, I'm not entirely sure either.  The shirogasane was great, basically a green tea thingie inside a pancake.  The shocora mikasa was similar, but chocolate.  The benimitsu ringo was a gooey thing.

I'd say the taste and size for the price is 3 stars, but it's such a cool little place and the employees were so kind that I'll put it at 3.5.
author: Brandon C.

description: The best of Japanese treats! Everything is not just nicely wrapped but taste so delicately delicious. The staff were all very helpful with describing each item.  I initially wished they provided samples but honestly, take my word. Everything is yum-o!!
author: Tess Y.

description: Very nice, upscale Japanese sweets. Customer service on par with the prices. Wonderful selection of unique sweets you generally wont find in the Japanese grocery store.
author: Devin P.

description:
As soon as I saw those little bunny shaped treats (Usagi), I knew I had to have them. Yeah, they don't offer samples, so you can't tell how they taste. Yeah, you can't just buy one bunny, you must buy a whole pack/herd/bunch? of 10 bunnies (price $20).  But, I didn't care.  They turned out to taste as expected --tender and a little too sweet --but it's really all about how they look.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/H6jEWhnxWlzTobANR-VNJg?select=4iFhAQMmuCFNheogPAb0Ng

Sure, it's pricey and feels like I'm shopping at the Tiffany's of treats, what with the top notch staff, the display cases,and the hushed atmosphere, etc.  But, I haven't been disappointed with any of the treats I've tried there, such as the red bean wrapped in a yellow pancake/crepe (Kazekaoru), the purple jelly, and the bunnies!
author: Peg S.

description: Overpriced and not very good. All items are imported and defrosted.
author: E T.

description:
This place is great for the authentic Japanese sweets. You'll come back with your wallet lighter and tastebuds happier.

A huge fan of the matcha green tea mochi and white peach mochi. Their packaging for their loquat jelly and white peach jelly are hard to open. The thick foil-like seal wrapper to keep the jelly fresh is difficult to open and can get messy.

Make sure to sign up for their membership card (free) if you plan to keep coming back (like me). The membership gives you $10 off your next purchase when you've spent $100.
author: Henry C.

description:
After getting off Montgomery St Bart and walking on Market St. I see Minamoto Kitchoan Japanese Sweets.  Oh so cool!  I've read about them on Yelp.

All the Japanese Sweets are made in Japan so nothing is made in house.  It's expensive due to shipping & packaging I guess.

There's description on each item in English.

I got a few things:

Fukuwatashi Senbei $2.50- a small thick waffle-like cookie w/ some white sweet cream sandwiched between another waffle-like cookie.  I liked it though it's made w/ margarine!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/H6jEWhnxWlzTobANR-VNJg?select=9sjUPm_-Icz-vD0zkA2IQA

Saisaika $4 (loquat jelly) - seasonal item - like a goopy jello w/ a loquat in it.  Not very tasty & too slippery to eat - skip it!

Kazekaoru (bean cake) - seasonal item $3 - cake like w/ mochi & red beans inside a bit sweet.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/H6jEWhnxWlzTobANR-VNJg?select=KWCfmWNAg7eudWiE5SFj0A

I should have gotten the "rabbit cakes" seasonal item - though only 10 in a box for $20 was spendy but so cute!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/H6jEWhnxWlzTobANR-VNJg?select=ycMf0GUFPPsz1a03WKMxfA

They can wrap your gifts, I don't know if it's extra - didn't this time.

Credit cards taken.

Hrs:
9:30a-7p Daily


They have other stores in NY, London, Singapore.  

Website:
http://www.kitchoan.com/

Ph:
415-989-1645
author: Ann L.

description:
Along Market street in downtown San Francisco is a shop who's sign simply reads "Japanese Sweets."  Wander inside and you will be greeted in Japanese by the most pleasant, professional Japanese women and a long J shaped counter displaying some of the most beautiful, delicate, traditional candies you'll see outside of Tokyo.

If you haven't had an opportunity to try Mochi, you really need to stop in and get educated.  Great selection, a little spendy by the piece for candies that aren't made on site (but par for the course in San Francisco).

My favorite by far "Ohagi Kurogoma" which is a sweet red bean paste kochi rolled in black sesame seeds.  Take a moment and try a few, it'll be a taste and texture experience.
author: Tony M.

description:
Wow!  Hello beautiful store with irresistible goodies.  Goodbye cash!

First of all, the rabbit shaped confections?  Could anything possible be more me?  Perhaps ice cream rabbit shaped confections.... But the lemony cakes certainly do the trick.  Soooooooo cute!!!  Uggggghhhh.  Must buy!!!!

And the dried persimmon?  It just looked so tasty and so pretty.  Couldn't resist that, either.  Walked away having bought $30 worth of stuff I so obviously do not need.  But I had to have!!

Don't go in here unless you can resist ridiculously cute, way too expensive but unbelievably adorable goodness.  Don't even look in the window.  Keep walking!  Don't say I didn't warn you!
author: Cassidy P.

description:
I'm not Japanese and I don't consider myself to be an expert on mochi, but here goes nothing.

I received a small box of treats from Minamoto Kitchoan as a gift for my birthday. I've tried mochi from quite a few places, both here and in Asia, and I could tell that the quality of mochi here is superior than most. I especially loved my red bean mochi with chestnut inside. That's definitely hard to find. 

Have you guys read the book "Predictably Irrational" by Dan Ariely?  There is a segment in it that resonated with me when it comes to pricey food item. In the book, Dan compares generic white t-shirts to designer versions. He asks, "The designer t-shirt costs five times as much as the generic, but is it five times better?" This might be me going off on a tangent, but it helps me keep my food opinions in perspective. This mochi is two to three times more expensive than Benkyodo in Japantown, so is it twice or three times as good? It depends, in my opinion. I think the treats at Minamoto Kitchoan would make for a lovely hostess gift or birthday gift for someone who appreciates the unconventional. The packaging was gorgeous and the little cakes and mochis had unique flavor combinations. If that's the sort of thing you or your recipient will appreciate, then yes, do try the offerings here. If you're buying for a mochi newbie or someone who wouldn't appreciate the packaging or delicate flavors, then maybe consider something else.

And in case this encourages anyone, they do offer stamp cards for repeat customers.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Expensive desserts that make for great gifts. They will put all your treats into a box and wrap it for you (extra $3). My favorite would have to be the persimmon with stuffed beans. 

Unique. Try it. Take a bus or walk because parking is very difficult.
author: Logan N.

description:
EXOTIC AND GOOWY.. IN YOUR MOUTH!!!

 Oishii
(delicious)

1st - GET THE SEASON TREATS

literally, i didnt know Japanese sweets can go so far to tickle my sweet tooth. im giddy. this place is by far handsdown delicious. mochi like treats, moon cake but not really moon cake like treats, sweet bean treats, jelly treats (with fruit), what an exotic fortee for the tastebuds. 

honestly, i had no idea what to expect. you walk in, everyting is organzed and pretty, the treats look like plastic but their really edible. the place is high-end for such treats, expensive, very clean, and employees are bowing and speaking japanese (or maybe because they think I am japanese). I've easily spent $22 dollars for 7 items.

though the website only may lack items seen in the store and doesnt have items which are listed on the items, please check the pictures I've posted.

PALATE 411.
- Fukuwatashi Senbei (1 - $2.50)
- Oribenishiki (2 - $2.50/each)
- Saisaika (1 - $4.00)
- Yarmimizu (1 - $3.50)
- (forgot name) (1 - $3.50)
- Kazekaoru (2 - $2.50/each)

My two favorites SO FAR..
- Kazekaoru - wrapped in a thin layer which looks like scrambled egg but really tastes like sweet pancake batter, inside are two type of sweet bean paste. This is a seasonal treat, its the season, better get some before its too late. the portion is half the size of your palm (woman's palm). Please see picture.
- Saisaika - OMGood. by far, expensive but so good. clear orange jelly with Biwa fruit in the middle. I asked that too? what does Biwa taste like and its a mixture of orange and white peach. the portion is as big as 2 teaspoons... $4 but WORTH IT. this item is also seasonal.

MINUS ONE STAR.
Not fully having a pamphlet with descriptions of each item. i know im pretty critical to things but it was so inconvenient. they had a small booklet but it didnt say much about items that were displayed. not much justice. i had to ask for a piece of paper and pen and wrote down the items i was buying as i continued my stroll thru the store. 

I'll follow up with an update of each one and a detailed description of what it looks like, taste, and is it worth it or not.

Will i be back? Yup went back in less then 24 hrs to get more of my two favorites. 

Until the next review.....
author: Jane A.

description:
I love it!!  My brother's ex used to buy us treats from her trips to Japan, and I was never able to find the same quality Japanese treats anywhere near besides the mom n' pop mochi places (which I love also!).  But the way Minamoto's treats are delicately packaged make each one so *special* and fun to unwrap like a little gift made just for you!  

We bought 4 individual treats which equalled about $12 (right, you can't go crazy and buy everything in here).  So far, we ate a couple that had red bean and chestnut inside - we love it!!  They're rich yet sweet, but not too sweet - you have to go in and experience it for yourself.  

The store is soooo clean and neat (very Japan-Japanese!), and the 2 ladies there were nice, sweet and polite.  Can't wait to eat the other 2 treats we bought and we will definitely go back for more!!
author: Maile N.

description: What an excellent, authentic Japanese dessert shop. I felt like I was back in Tokyo for a minute!
author: Chad T.

description:
Looking for a snappy, unique food gift for a birthday or special occasion? Why appear a dim-witted, thoughtless sack of potatoes toting around a box of boring chocolates purchased at Walgreens when you can make a lasting impression on your subject with a handful of sweet snacks from Minamoto?

If you (or the person you're buying for) is into Japanese sweets, you'll dig their array of far east offerings. Everything from bean cakes, mochis, and jellied delights litter their jewel case of dessert items, and if you have inquiries about odd-looking confections that you've never laid eyes on before, the staff will gladly explain the morsel in question without making you feel like a completely uncultured boob. They'll even take the time to wrap your purchases in authentic Japanese stationary for that extra wow factor at no additional charge. Style points for days, son! 

Sure, it's a little expensive... but really, do you want to look like a bargain basement type when trying to convey a message of endearment or appreciation? Me thinks not.
author: Ruggy J.

description: Customer service here is lacking. No samples?! Given price, incredible that you'd pay without knowing what you're getting. Basically know what you want, buy and get out. Simple
author: JAMES L.

description:
Beautiful and Delicious. Artful and Polite.

Serendipitously Savored: 
~ ORIBENISHIKI (http://www.kitchoan.com/?page_id=188)
+
~ FUKUWATASHI SENBEI (http://www.kitchoan.com/?page_id=149)
author: Sally M.

description: The service is great with no pressure. Very knowledgable. Great Japanese gifts and sweets. Everything is very classy and taste great. Got some really good gifts for the family.
author: Michael B.

description:
Best Mochi I have ever had, I give it a 5 star because I don't know what to compare it to. 

Mochi was soft and chewy, the attendant was very knowledgeable and didn't just push product on us. We told her we from out of town and wanted to buy ALOT but she said it wouldn't last because mochi is delicate and will expire in a few days.

I will order online if I want more.
author: Jack F.

description:
Category: Candy store?? This ain't no candy store, Yelp.   Suteki na washoku no mise desu yo.  If anything, it's a fancy "bakery"...

I've now been to 4 different locations of Minamoto Kitchoan (Ginza, NY, the stand in Mitsuwa, here!) and while each are vastly different in atmosphere and decor, I have enjoyed them all equally and would return to any of them for the same high quality Japanese treats.

My favorite year-round good they sell is their green tea kasutera cake.  It's light, not very sweet, and has enough flavor to complement any tea of your choice (Japanese, of course).  I prefer a nice hojicha after dinner with this simple yet delicate dessert.

All of their ever-changing seasonal goods are always hits.  I LOVE their jellies and anything with red bean or chestnut.  I LOVE their hakutou zeri and my favorite seasonal treat has to be the hakutou mochi.  Such a light, fluffy, fragrant mochi.  Get the big box.

These treats make great gifts.  Just make sure that the recipient knows these expire within weeks since they are "fresh" and not made with preservatives.

This place is pricey, but definitely come and get/try the kasutera.  I think it's less than $30 for a foot-length of cakey deliciousness.

Ah, I miss Japan...
author: Ruth C.

description: This place is really expensive. $16 for a small peach jelly. While the decoration is soooooo cute   that no girl can resist, it is indeed just a jelly :( won't try again.
author: Vicky L.

description:
I had no idea what half of these confections were, but they had to be the most beautiful little works of art I have ever seen.  If nothing else, go to Minamota just to admire them.

My husband was more familiar thanks to his Air Force days in Japan.  He led me to what he thought I would like and steered me away from what I wouldn't.  

Even though they are expensive, you won't need to buy many because they're almost too pretty to eat!
author: Heather C.

description: Beautiful lay out of the place with friendly staff.  Can't wait to try their high quality Dry Persimmon "Hoshigaki" filled with sweet white bean paste!  I wish they sell individual bunny cakes. Hard to find parking in that area.
author: Ash M.

description:
Expensive, but excellent.

We've been fans of these luxurious Japanese pastries ever since we stumbled upon their shop in NYC several years ago (I don't think there was one in SF at the time)

When we discovered there was one in SF, we knew we'd have to make regular visits, but not too often, because it is pricey!  We generally get about 6 tasty little tidbits, and it comes to about $20.

My favorite is the Sakura Daifuku (a cherry-blossom mochi), which is apparently only seasonal in the springtime, but they have several other good ones... the bean-filled pancakes, the white peach bean cake, the vanilla-flavored white bean cake (tastes like a dense, rich fortune cookie), the kumquat daifuku, to name a few.

You can get good and cheap mochi elsewhere (we got a whole pack at a drugstore a block or two away, for less than the cost of one piece at Kitchoan), but the decadence, presentation, and service at Minamoto Kitchoan can't be beat, so it's worth an occasional splurge, or as a surprise gift for someone special.
author: Matthew G.

description:
I'm so glad we stumbled upon this place when walking around and exploring the city. Yes, we were a little shocked with the prices, but now that I think about, it's understable for really good quality Japanese treats.

We didn't get a gift set or anything. My friend just got the kuri daifuku, which is one of their most popular items. 1 piece is $3. It's a really soft mochi, with red bean, and a sweet chestnut in the center. Very yummy and addicting. I just got the kusa mochi. 1 piece is for $2.50. The mochi was very soft, fresh, and is green b/c they make it out of this leaf/plant called yomogi. Inside is sweet red bean. NOM!

It's a place I will definitely come back to and probably bring my parents. This is also a really good place to make a nice gift set of mochi and Japanese treats for someone special. You won't be disappointed with this place!
author: Maki K.

description:
This sweet shop is wonderful!  A fantastic addition to market street, and a really special shop to just wander into, buy a few sweets, and wander out.  The interior is beautiful, and the sweets we bought were delicious.  

The individual sweets are pricey, but well worth it for a different sort of treat.  Also, compared with the outrageous prices people are charging for cupcakes these days, the cost is actually pretty standard.
author: Tasha D.

description:
I discovered this store on a lazy Sunday afternoon while exploring San Francisco. Having walked about six miles around the city, and feeling like I deserved a treat, the window display had me drooling microseconds after laying eyes on it!

They have a wide selection of Japanese sweets. The staff are friendly and helpful. They pointed out that an initial selection was still frozen and couldn't be eaten for several hours (that would have been tragedy incarnate...). I ended up getting an orange mochi and it was really delicious. Apparently they import their sweets from Japan. Certainly they are not cheap, but in my non-expert opinion the quality was really good.

They have seasonal offerings that vary from time to time and that I have not seen in other Japanese food stores around the area. Also, you can order some of their stock online.

The store is dangerously accessible from BART (dangerous for my waistline and wallet, that is) or Muni; I'll be coming back for sure!
author: Seán O.

description:
Just dropped in unexpectedly after having lunch in North Beach.

It's Sakura season, so it was only natural for me to possibly consider Sakura mochi for a tasting.

Sadly I was deterred and got two Hokkaido milk cookies and matcha (green tea) dusted white chocolate mochi.

(no pictures this time, you have to take my word on this one).

The hokkaido milk cookies had a nice crunch but I didn't taste too much of that rich hokkaido milk flavor I expected.

As for the green tea white chocolate mochi. The green tea was a bit too bitter, but the white chocolate ganache core hit the sweet spot perfectly. Everything costs a little less than $20.00 w/tax of course.

They even have a customer stamp card for ongoing patronage and customer rewards. Their shipments usually arrive in the course of 1-2 weeks typically on a Wednesday, in case you're more inclined for fresh product.

Otherwise, I look forward to trying more of their flavors before giving a final rating. 3 stars is all you get for a preliminary tasting. Cheers.
author: Ryan M.

description: Its kind expensive, but its just like the desert i have had in Japan. Super fresh and delicious and authentic.
author: Lijia W.

description: Stopped by here before to browse but never really purchased anything since the prices seem to be quite high and I normally get my mochi fix at Benkyodo.  But we decided to stop by again to give them a shot this time.  We were able to find the kumquat mochi like the ones at J Sweet in San Jose which we became quite fond of for $3.  Since it seems like a seasonal item, we also got 2 loquat jellies which is best eaten cold...not sure if it's worth the $4 a piece though.  Since they are from Japan, the prices are understandably high but it's a bit too pricey for my taste.  I rather pay an extra couple of bucks and have a box of handmade mochis from Benkyodo.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
Cream of the crop for Japanese treats.  My wife is a HUUUUUGE fan.  The dorayaki is pillowy soft, their jelly are awesome and the daifuku are some of the best I've had.  It's basically the same as the high end stuff you'd get in Japan.  (Well, it's not basically the same....it IS the same.)

It's super expensive.  They'll even charge you to put it in a box.  But it's nice white glove service if you want it that way, and it's worth it if you want Japanese sweets.
author: Arthur Y.

description:
Tucked away in hustle and bustle of financial district, next to Radio Shack- lies this hidden gem. The store front is always decorated either one with the season or Japanese national holidays-- or Girls Day (雛祭り) or hinamatsuri right now. 

Upon entering, you feel like at any moment with a bit of clumsiness and misstep, you are bound to break million dollar china bowls. Relax, this is only pastry :) 

Pastry are traditional Japanese wagashi (和菓子), Hand made and flown in from Japan, hence the hefty prices but its worth it.. comparable to fake cronuts they sell across the street for $3.25. 

These sweets aren't meant to be devoured, but rather enjoyed with a nice tea pairing. 
Each piece is unique and delectable. My choice for the evening was sakura mochi and tsuya/doryaki. Both consisting of red bean filling sandwiched between cakes. 

If you haven't tried a wagashi or common introduction to this form of dessert, its Mochi, i highly recommend you go and spending $5 bucks or less next time. 

And if you want to impress your friends at dinner parties, rather than overly sweet and common cupcakes, why not try Minamoto Kitchoan? You will feel like you just traveled to japan (notice the money plate they use when providing you with your change) and you will impress any guest with fascination and sweetness.
author: Youna K.

description:
I have been buying snacks from here several times per year. Are the prices high? Yes they are, but the snacks are one of a kind. The snacks are visually appealing and taste great. Because of the high prices, I only come here about 5 times per year. They have seasonal snacks which keeps me coming back. The service is also great. Very friendly people.

Definitely give this place a chance. I gave 4 stars instead of 5 because of prices. Everything else is good.
author: Dennis N.

description: I am sure if you like Mochi, you will like this place.  Good treats, but very pricey.  i knew this walking based on how nice the shop was.
author: Jessica E.

description: Some of the best mochi I've ever had. So many artistic little pastries of soft goodness. I have Celiac and really enjoy having gluten free desserts that are so sweet and yummy.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Imported traditional Japanese sweets, as good as it gets! This stuff is quality, it is widely known in Japan too. On average you will be paying $2.50-6 for one piece of sweet, sweet heaven. I am a big fan of the daifuku and mochi they carry. Most things are flavored with red bean or a natural fruit flavor. It is easy to spend $20 on just a few sweets, so treat-yo-self. The only downside? Since everything is fairly perishable, they recommend you to eat the sweets by a certain date, most of which are usually a day from purchasing. So don't come here expecting it will be okay to give as a gift unless you know it will be consumed immediately.
author: Diana S.

description:
Yay! I'm a fan indeed!

I came here with my brother today and ended up leaving with several desserts. It is a bit pricey compared to other home-made mochi that other places serve, but they are pretty great. The sweets are a nice, great balance BUT it is still hard for me to hand over ~$23 for 5 desserts. Worth it, but it is definitely a special treat.
author: Sophie D.

description:
I was really impressed at the quality and the freshness of all the sweets. All their products are flown from Japan. I haven't tasted anything that was this authentic in the States. (Seriously, the most authentic sweet shop in SF.)

Honestly, if you are going to complain about the price. Think about it this way you are saving a lot more money by buying the product in the United States than flying all the way to Japan to consume the same product.

I have bought many omiyage for family and friends that live throughout the country. FYI-The location is conveniently located near BART and Muni, which makes it perfect for last minute gift pick-up.
author: Sara N.

description:
In search of authentic wagashi, I visited Minamoto Kitchoan.  I was expecting exquisite works of art as I'd eaten in Kyoto.  Sadly Minamoto Kitchoan is a bit more mundane than the finest wagashi you can find in Japan.  

The mochi is very good, but it didn't seem as fresh and natural as I had hoped.  I guess it is because they are air-flown from Japan, so they have to survive a lot longer than normal wagashi would.  I was disappointed to find that many of the items had artificial coloring added.  Avoiding all the artificially colored or wheat or milk containing mochi and jellies, there were four choices left.  Black sesame covered mochi, kinako covered mochi, a sakura mochi on a leaf, and a tiny yokan.  All were excellent.  In case you are looking for vegan and gluten free sweets, these four are all vegan and gluten free.  You can easily figure this out because each mochi is well labeled in English.  Update: later I discovered inconspicuously in the back of the shop an azuki bean rice cracker sandwich that is gluten free, vegan, and all natural which I highly recommend

Having grown up eating super fresh mochi and also having some high quality wagashi and mochi in Japan, there are definitely levels above Minamoto Kitchoan possible.  I was hoping Minamoto Kitchoan would deliver that super fresh wagashi experience, but I suppose for a chain trying to operate across the world, they are pretty good.  It's definitely a very Japanese experience, right down to the excessive packaging, paying by passing back and forth a little tray, and the Japanese ladies behind the counter who didn't understand the word "utensil", allowing me to exercise my Japanese skills.  

They have some very nicely packaged tea available which would make a nice hostess gift along with a few mochi or a yokan.  (If you are unfamiliar with Japanese culture, Japanese are all about gifts, small and large, which is probably part of why excessive packaging is so popular)

Overall worth a visit, it's all very good and a cut above most, but for the best wagashi I think you're still going to have to visit Japan or keep looking.

The best description I can think of is that this is like a shop you would see in Japan for foreign tourists, it's a very mainstream citified version of what I was hoping to find.
author: N T.

description:
My must go place whenever i am in SF.

The store is small however layout is very nice and  very Japanese.

It is expensive place for Japanese cake and snacks, however IMO it is not overpriced. 

How often do you walk into a retailer in US seeing the staff dressing in company uniform?  A polo shirt/T-shirt with company name sitched doesn't count!

How often can you buy Japanese cakes/pastries directly imported from Japan and most of the products are within 30 days shelf life?

How often do you eat any Japanese or Asian cake here and feel/taste so soft so fresh and made by high quality ingredients?

How often do you find any Asian store locating in such a convenient, high end shopping locations such as Ginza Tokyo,  5th Ave of New York and Financial District of SF?

Highly recommended if you are in town or just try the kusa mochi or tusya which are less expensive.  You can definitely tell the difference.
author: Sandy L.

description:
Their black sesame mochi and red bean pancakes are absolutely delicious. I wish I could buy them in Seattle.

It's expensive, yes. But well worth it.
author: Kevin C.

description: This shop gives a feel of Japan in the middle of SF. I really like the selection of wagashi. Although the items are a bit pricier than most dessert places each item is a work of art.  So delicate and delicious. There was a cake I wanted to buy but it was sold out. Items all come from Japan. Give it a try if you haven't been.
author: RJ O.

description: Friendly staff! But the Japanese sweet is kinda pricy! But their food is delicious!  the sweets are all freshly made, some will expire next day!
author: Mengze Z.

description:
Real authentic Japanese sweets?  Of course, items are all made in Japan and shipped to the U.S.  

I had to think really hard about how to review this place.  Should I review at the standard of compared to other Japanese dessert places in Tokyo which I frequent often these days?  Or should it be compared with Benkyodo Co.(http://www.yelp.com/biz/benkyodo-co-san-francisco), a local San Francisco establishment?

VS. Benkyodo:  Quite different.  
Benkyodo is a local shop making Japanese mochi using California rice and red bean pastes using American sugar.  Kichoan uses Japanese ingredients (well, there is always a possibility that they use imported beans from China, but I do not know).  The biggest difference is that Kitchoan products are FROZEN once.  Benkyodo products are fresh and never frozen (i hope).  Kichoan makes their products in a massive factory on an assembly line.  Benkyodo's assembly line consists of grandpa, dad, mom, and angry teenager (just imagining).  Taste wise, Benkyodo is more traditional style, quite rough and old fashioned, unaffected by the changing taste bud of Japan.  Kitchoan taste is more refined and reflects the current trend in Japan, suppressing the sugary sweetness.  When comparing the establishment date,  Benkyodo born in 1906 is much older than Kichoan born in 1947.   Knowing the personally of local loving San Francisco community, people should support Benkyodo over Kitchoan.  

VS. Japanese standard:  Kitchoan is one of the big guys with over 100 stores in Japan (most of them inside department stores).  Do not rave about Kitchoan to Wagashi Otaku (Japanese sweets fanatics) because they do not take these kind of huge production establishments seriously.  Otaku argues that these big guys use techniques that enable products to last over a week at room temperature, which sacrifices taste.  Big guys has to worry about transit time from factory to shops where as smaller establishments sometimes sell items with ONE DAY expiration date!  For example, my favorite Dorayaki shop in Japan is "Usagiya" (http://www.tctv.ne.jp/usagiya/) established in 1913, tell you that their dorayaki only tastes good the day it is purchased with expiration date of next day.  

PRICE:  
$3.00 Tsuya (dorayaki)
$2.80 Mame Daifuku
Dorayaki in Tokyo is about 180 Yen, which is about $2.  Thinking about their trouble of shipping the items to the U.S. and going through the delicate defrosting process, the price is not so bad.

CONCLUSION:  Defrosted taste did not bother me too much.  They must use a very good technique.  Having an option to buy authentic Japanese sweets in SF is awesome, so addition of Kitchoan in the city should be appreciated, although I do not think it replaces Benkyodo.  I personally think that Benkyodo continues to be a unique SF treasure.
author: トモ T.

description:
If you are into Wagashi, then you gotta park your azz into this place.
Quite expensive, but the treats here are delicate and refined.
I tried the Hakutoshigure Bean Cake and smiled.
...shibukukan
author: Derek N.

description: OMG! Loved their sweets. It is a lovely experience walking into the store. relaxing and effortless. It's so difficult to choose, though! I had two regular bean paste filled mochis - sakura (cherry blossom) and a chestnut. The chestnut mochi actually included a whole chestnut inside! It was delicious. I also had the black sesame mochi which was my favorite. They have courteous staff and a wide selection of sweets. I highly recommend this store for some real authentic Japanese sweets.
author: Flavia A.

description:
I came here when they first opened last year, and was interested to buy Japanese traditional sweets. So I bought a few that included mochi, a mango infused filling in a waferlike crust, katsusera(Japanese and French style sponge cake), and other rice cakes filled with red bean and other traditional Asian fillings.  The products were pricey but I believe this is worth trying and excellent for gift giving.

I like the ambience and the staff is very friendly and courteous which reminds me of any Japanese stores that I went to in Japan. I liked how they helped me on their advice and recommendations. They really answered my questions.  The minimalist design of their store and their packaging is great too.

very narrow and small Japanese traditional sweets shop especially used for wagashi - sweets used for tea ceremony.
author: Jade M.

description:
As expensive as SF rent--$7 for a small bag of sembe, which are just rice crackers wrapped in seaweed--but so worth it for a splurge. A wide range of wagashi that I haven't seen anywhere else outside of Japan. This place is mandatory if your Japanese aunties judge you by the quality of your gifts.

I guess it's cheap if you compare this to airfare to Tokyo.
author: Lian C.

description:
This place is overpriced! The mochi isn't even that good... at least the one's that I bought today. (Kuridaifuku, Macchamanjyu, and Ohagi Kurogoma). I've definitely had better mochi before! I don't understand why these mochis are $3 a piece..  I guess it was "authentic" mochi, but it was probably just not fresh enough. I understand that it's shipped from Japan and they add no preservatives, but it just didn't satisfy my tastebuds:( However, the service was exceptional. The young lady took the time to answer all of our questions and recommended the most popular items! 


It's great to receive these as a gift because they're oh so prettily packaged!

We also bought these fresh shrimp chips and the ones I usually buy from the Japanese supermarkets taste so much better! They weren't salty enough.
author: Chantel Y.

description: Mmmmmm....YUM, YUM, YUM!  For authentic Japanese wagashi or manju, this is the place.  It tastes nothing like the refrigerated ones that are sold at the Japanese supermarkets.  WAAAYYYY better quality.  These are showcased in glass display cases where you can pick and choose the ones you want.  Some are in fancy wrappers and boxes that can be great for gifts, but beware.....they're not cheap!  Can these really be from Japan?!  My favorites are the manjus (mochi with red bean paste in it), especially the kusamochi.  What a treat!
author: Erica S.

description:
so i'm walking down the street and towards my old boss's office. i was debating if i should bring him pastries or egg tarts for my visit.. and as i walk by i saw a very beautiful display at the window.. BINGO!  what a great thing to bring to my japanese boss.. i'll bring him Japanese desserts!! 
this place is so cute!  and very classy.. everything is like in a display case and the service is so nice.  they have desserts from japan that they ship here. they have those really good green tea pastries with red bean paste inside..  they are kind of expensive but it's worth it! and they give you a stamp card!
author: Belinda C.

description:
$$$ for sure. 

These are all prepackaged goodies from Japan. Not unlike the specialty goods you see at the department store or in Tokyo Station. The only thing missing is the giant roll of baumkuchen baking behind the counter. 

* It can get really expensive in here but I do like it here a lot. 
* Get baumkuchen with icing for your next tea party. So freaking good! 
* Some items can be purchased individually like their little jelly things. 
* There's a stamp card for frequent customers.
author: Margaret S.

description: The best place to get fresh and authentic Japanese mochi treats...and with authentic Japanese customer service, too! Feels like walking into a peaceful shop in the middle of Japan. I like stopping here the day before flying home to get gifts for my family. Also a unique gift for that special someone :)
author: Ariane B.

description:
Very cute little Japanese sweet store located in the heart of Financial District. Very polite and warm services. Everything was so organized and clean. 

All the sweets were imported from Japan, therefore they were not cheap at all. The price was ranged from $3 and up (each treat). They were all in pretty and nice packaged. Besides, the packaged, I think the sweets were not that unique. You can find the similar tastes in Japanese Supermarkets and you only need to pay half of the price. 

I only got three treats: 

Fukuwatashi Senbei (Vanilla cream between two wafers) $2.50 - the taste of this one was very good. The wafers were so crispy and the vanvilla cream was not too sweet. 

Tsuya (two small pancakes with red been in between) $3.00 - this one you could easily find it from other Japanese markets. I still got it maybe of the lovely package...hahahaha 

Kuri Daifuku - (Red Bean Mochi inside with a whole Chestnut) $3.00 - this one tasted pretty good. The mochi was so soft and fresh. 

Although the treats here are expensive, I still glad that we have this kind of store in SF. It gives us more gift ideas for special occasions :-) 

PS. They have STAMP CARD program. You will earn one stamp for every $5.00 you spend. Once you have accumulated 20 stamps, you may be redeemed for $5 worth of products.
author: Liza T.

description:
THIS PLACE IS AWESOME, BUT WATCH OUT, IT'S PRICEY.

Pros 1) The people are super nice and know what they're talking about 2) where else are you going to find fancy assortments of mochi? 3) they even wrapped my little gift with a ribbon! 

Cons 1) why the hell am i paying so much for a little mochi slice? 2) it's so quiet in there I feel like it's too fancy and I can't have fun 

I tried the peach one and it was soooo goood. but it's like a little mochi ball about the size of the circle you can make with your hand if you were making binoculars with your hands LOL.  and that's like $3-5 and a nice set can run 20-70$

This would be a 5 star rating for all people who know and love mochi for sure. It's at a 4 star because of how expensive it is and also because you can't take anyone here. It's definitely not a fun place for someone who doesn't know what mochi is because they'll just be kind of weirded out i think
author: Ashley M.

description:
Are you ready for this jelly?
I didn't think I was ready for their jelly. All kinds of dainty, delicately wrapped jellies. Peach, green tea, red bean, cherry, citrus, apple cinnamon... 'n more!   

I could've lugged back some froufrou chocolates, but instead I blinked and threw down some serious $$$ for these bite-sized sweets. Many run a few dollars and on up. Pick your favs and they'll put them in a nicely wrapped box for a little extra. I've had tastes of Minamoto's before, so it wasn't too overwhelming. Even then, there were tons of other intriguing treats. Seasonal and those only available in separate boxes. Since there's no samples, you almost have to go by looks, descriptions and hope you've made the right choice. Of course as gifts, it's difficult. I got a couple of gift boxes and then an assortment just for myself. There wasn't a 'lil treat I regretted picking. Beautifully paired with a nice cup 'o tea.
author: Jenny H.

description: This is a great store selling Japanese sweets.  These are generally large, well-made traditional-type sweets, not bulk candies in wrappers.  Many are wrapped in mochi rice pastry and have nuts or fruits, red bean paste, etc., and others are jellies.  They are not cheap, but then each one is large and filling, they are good quality, interesting, and very different from what one normally can get here.
author: Wulfstan C.

description:
OMG yum!!!~~

A little expensive but it's so yummy~~

I only had the yuzu jelly thing for like 2.80... it was small and cute. These would be nice gifts if you wanna splurge for somebody that's worth it. 

I'm a little bit sad that I didn't see the cute bunny dessert in the main picture... I would have loved to try it. The white peach mochi looked good too, but it came in a box... that shit wouldn't have fit in my luggage. But I was sooo happy with my yuzu jelly. 

I'm sad and relieved that this isn't anywhere close to me. (I'm from LA)... sad because it's SO YUMMY but relieved that my wallet will be kept fat and my waist will remain small.

If I'm ever around San Francisco again, I'll definitely come back and try other shit.

tl;dr
YUMMY JAPANESE SHIT (MOCHIS, JELLIES, ETC ETC) BUT EXPENSIVE... worth it tho ~
author: Stefan B.

description: At Minamoto Kitchoan, you can buy imported Japanese sweets.  They are a little pricey, because the items have been flown in from Japan.  However, the quality is much higher than the similar items you buy at Japanese supermarkets.  My favorite is castella cake.  Yum.
author: Thomas C.

description: Pricy, but what do you expect for items that come overseas. The chocolate mochi is amazing. Everything is so fresh. It's a delacy boutique confection shop.
author: Gwen K.

description: Very cute, elegant Japanese pastery store. I haven't seen a store like this on the east coast; it has such attention to the delicacies, pretty packaging, and a large selection. Prices seemed pretty steep, but maybe I am not sure what the going rate is. There were also lots of items I've never seen elsewhere, like, various types of mochi and seaweed crackers. The store is very pretty and is worth even just looking in.
author: Jess L.

description:
"Yokan [jellied bean paste] is the king of pastry" 
- Natsume Soseki (1867-1916, author, British literature scholar)


After hitting NY market successfully, Kitchoan opened its SF branch in late summer of 2009. They specialize in traditional and semi-western Japanese snack/pastry (Wagashi) that are made at their own factories in Okayama, Japan (the place famous for growing high end fruits sold at department stores). Anything you buy at this store meets the contemporary upscale Japanese standards 100%. No shit. 

My fellow Japanese residents bitch about them and say all items are pricey. I think they're crazy. It is incredible that you have anything to buy at this business under 5 dollars because Minamoto Kichoan is the Rolls Royce of Wagashi outside Japan.  

There's something in the world in which people can never beat Japanese within a century of two. Snack/Pastry is one of them. You can travel to Belgium and stay there for a week and try all kind of bakery and desert places in the country before coming to Minamoto Kichoan. You'll see the unbreakable wall that separates Ichiros and Yokos from the rest of the world. 

Minamoto Kichoan clearly bests all other desert/pastry shops in the Bay Area. If Le Boulange is 3.6 stars, Kichoan is 4.9. The difference is decisive. 

BTW, Minamoto Kichoan is not considered by the Japanese people as top 10 wagashi company, maybe not top 20 either.
author: yota L.

description: There are so many amazing treats available in San Francisco, that it seems nearly impossible to showcase just one, however, my current favorite is the mochi from Minamoto Kitchoan -- not to mention their beautiful jelly chocolates and wafer cookies. These items are true luxuries, with the price tags to match, but I call it an "affordable luxury," because each delicious morsel is a taste thrill. Delicate, light and flavorful with the perfect blend of mochi-chew and soft centered melt. Each piece is elegantly wrapped like a little gift - and actually IS the perfect gift, for yourself, or for someone else. Mark this as a must try (at least once), then go ahead and try to find a better mochi anywhere within a reasonable distance. Bet you won't!
author: Alison M.

description: Amazing! I didn't know what to expect but all of their treats are incredible and the staff is incredibly helpful. They made sure to nicely package my gifts and suggested fun things to try, which all turned out to be new favorite desserts!
author: Lisa N.

description:
I'm definitely charmed by this fancy shop with imported, including seasonal, Japanese sweets.  It's similar to Nippon Ya in Japantown, with fancy treats ready for gift giving and plastic food models, but the selection differs.  Minamoto Kitchoan has a smaller selection, one that emphasizes mochi, jellies, crackers and cookies.  While some items are available in box sets only, including the adorable rabbit cakes, many of the treats can be purchased individually for about $2 - 4 a piece.  Minamoto has a more upscale feel with some items in glass cases, reminiscent of a jewelry store.  Your payment is accepted on a tray and the change and receipt are returned on a tray.  The shopping bag seems to come from Japan (it has Japanese on it).  They play Japanese music in the store. 

* Fukuwatashi Senbei ($2.50): So good.  It's a cookie sandwich that looks like an extra thick ridged yellow potato chips with a thin layer of vanilla cream in the middle.  The cookies are very crunchy and taste a bit like fortune cookies only better.  The cream was also very good.  Highly recommended.

* Kuri Daifuku ($3): This was a red bean mochi with a whole chestnut in the center.  The mochi was a light green.  The paste was a bit chunky.  The chestnut was soft and very sweet.  Nice flavors but probably not worth $3.  

* Kusamochi ($2.50): This was a flat, moon shaped sticky green mochi pancake with red bean inside.  The green came from the mugwort which didn't have a strong flavor.  The mochi part was stickier and softer than usual.  Good but not that different from other red bean mochi.  

* Kazekaoru ($4): A seasonal treat, very pretty.  The exterior was a spongy light pancake and inside it had red bean paste with a chewy strip of mochi.  I enjoyed the many contrasting textures.  

* Yarimizu ($2.50): A piece of jelly with bits of perilla leaves.  Too sweet.

These treats will make you feel special (and they'll do the same for lucky recipients).
author: Lolia S.

description:
Sweets overload!
I bookmarked this a long time ago, and finally had a chance to come here to pick some goodies up for mother's day and a friend's birthday (and of course for myself).  There's so many sweets to choose from, that it's hard to decide what to get.  Getting everything would have broke my wallet.  However, the staff here were very helpful in helping me choose.  So, I got a variety of mochi/manju and crackers.  And my favorite was the chestnut manju, delicious.  I think next time I come here, I will try their loquat jelly.
I wouldn't come to this place just to have my fix of mochi.  It's just way too expensive, even though the quality is very good.  This place is more for gift giving.  Individually packaged very pretty, they provide a box for $3, and free gift wrapping.
author: Karen L.

description:
this is only my second visit here.  i  think if i was into this type of sweet more, id rate it higher.  its just not my thing.

their items are flown in from japan.  that might explain the price.  parking can be found on montgomery.
author: claudia y.

description: Adorable Japanese confectionary store- they make great treats or gifts. Everything including the packaging is adorable. The staff is super nice and knowledgeable. Always go in every now and then to pick up a Baumkuchen cake (like a sugar donut that isn't too sweet turned into a cake. Nothing has preservatives so you have to be sure to check the expiration dates. If you pick a bunch of different little treats and a gift box, they take time and package it all together very nicely and then wrap it.
author: Kajal G.

description: I have been here on several occasions. Yes, their stuff is a bit pricey and their products vary (ranging from nothing special to delicious, depending on your tastes), BUT I believe they are a nice little place people should check out. Plus, their products make very nice gifts for people who like Japanese sweets. Lastly, they have a stamp card that allows you a discount (forgot if it's $5 or $10) once your card is filled. The staff is very sweet and lets you know if you are only a dollar or two away from another stamp (making your money's worth it towards the discount) - like if you the stamp is every $5 and you are at $4, they will let you know.
author: Christina L.

description: If I could give this place 10 stars on Yelp, I would! Everything piece of pastry (or rather, wagashi) here is so delicate, so carefully crafted, and the flavors and textures just surprise you. Plus,the packaging is just beautiful!!! Best place to source little treats for gifts and corporate thank-you boxes. I just wish they had a better ordering system online, but no matter, they have a store in Los Angeles as well (in Torrance)!
author: Kat C.

description: Absolutely delicious!  The service is wonderful.  It is a beautiful experience to shop here and try fabulous manju!
