author: mi m.

description:
It's a beautiful store and a very nice experience, but it's definitely expensive for what you're getting.  Minamoto specializes in nicely packaged Japanese sweets imported directly from Japan.  I bought 4 pieces of small, packaged Japanese cakes (they're all bite size!) and the bill came to 12.50.  The service was first rate - they bow to you and use a tray to hand you the bill and receive your cash.

The desserts I had were really not that unique if you're of East Asian descent or if you're familiar with traditional Chinese / Asian desserts.  Typical of those desserts, the cake exterior is made of either rice, fruit, wafers or wheat.  The filling consist of red beans, a variety of fruits, chestnuts, sesame or yam.  

I bought a Kuri Daifuku (red bean mochi), a Maccha Manju (Mochi with g. tea filling), a Oribenishiki (baked cake with bean and chestnut filling, similar to a Chinese Mooncake) , Ofukuimo (yam and black sesame cake).  All the cakes were good, but they're not unique as I can easily go to a nice Chinese bakery (i.e. Keewah) and buy something similar for about 2/3 the price and about 3 times the size.  

What they're selling here is the Japanese experience - the distinctly Japanese decor & presentation, beautiful packaging and great service.  I enjoy the experience very much, but once is probably sufficient for the high price tag, for the not so unique desserts that's not baked on the premises, with no interior seating for you to enjoy the decor.
author: Paul K.

description:
Rare store one cannot find elsewhere easily
Is it overpriced? maybe a little bit
But I still suggest  it to everyone who loves Japanese sweetened rice
author: Ross Z.

description:
I have been frequenting this place for years and absolutely adore it. The selection of delicious and beautiful Japanese treats is extensive and I love being able to purchase single items to try. These are not meant to be wolfed down (although I do), but savored and enjoyed. 

The staff is incredibly polite and attentive. I can't say enough good things about Minamoto Kitchoan.
author: Mrs P.

description: Great friendly service and delicious pieces. Got some for mom's birthday and they are amazing. Great little shop and the prices are actually pretty reasonable for something so authentic and yummy. I will come back for sure.
author: Mel L.

description: Why, oh why was I born Italian-American? I know in my heart of hearts I was suppose to be Japanese. As I walked into the beautiful yet subtle and elegant Minamoto Kitchoan on Market Street, I never felt so at home surrounded by the most precious and delicious Japanese 'petit-four' I had ever seen. I filled my little basket with all sorts of wagashi for my husband and I to enjoy later on in our hotel room. Shirogasane, tsuya, oribenishiki, and the ayashirabe are just some of the ones I recall that we tried. Nothing was terribly expensive - the most expensive treat was not much more than $3 or $4. Later that evening it was very difficult to pick just one that stood out amongst the others - we loved them all. None too sweet and all very unique and satisfying. We will definitely be making a trip back here the next time we are in San Fran.
author: Laura R.

description:
Growing up in Asia, Minamoto cakes and mochi were such a treat! I was surprised to see it's location open below my office on Market St. 

I stopped in to pick up some red bean cakes for my mom...and of course had to get some mochi for myself. 

The treats don't come cheap..but they are delicious and worth every penny!
author: Mimi T.

description:
They keep this adorable store impeccable, stocked and the staff is lovely. 

They have realistic looking faux treats on display for you to see exactly what they look like unwrapped/cut open. 

My favorite, hands down is the Sakura mochi.
author: Julie R.

description:
My office is only two blocks away, so I've passed by this place many times over the past year. I always look in through their front window, but only recently decided to actually go inside. 

At first glance, you'll notice how adorable everything is. From the mochis themselves to the packaging, everything was well thought out and put together. You will then look at the prices and think "Wow, this place is expensive AF." A little mochi a bit bigger than a quarter will run around $4 and a little cracker with chocolate filling is about the same price. For ONE! Want a mochi that's the same size of your fist? $30+. But hey, I was already here so I thought I might as well. I looked around and picked up two mochis, a green tea mochi with white chocolate filling, and a white peach flavored sweet bean cake. I was actually unaware that the white peach one was a bean cake until I opened it, and I personally wasn't a fan of the texture, but I really enjoyed the flavor of it. However, the green tea chocolate one was delicious. Texture was soft and chewy and the white chocolate filling was SO good. 

I was actually hoping to not like what I purchased because of the price. I can definitely say that the mochis were good, but the big question is whether or not it's actually worth $4 just for one tiny piece. The jury's still out on that part, but I would still recommend this place to try if you haven't already.
author: Kari G.

description:
I'm utterly fascinated with Japanese food culture. What was once sushi and teppanyaki being the extent of my knowledge has spread to ramen, ozakaya, yakitori, kaiseki, yakiniku, and a fair number of other preparations Im not recalling off the top of my head right now. Who knew that something like okonomiyaki, buta kaknuni, or the differences between Kyoto and Hiroshima style cooking would lead me down so many culinary paths? 

Well add one more notch to the journey, the world of Japanese desserts. Ive had my fare number of treats from the various Japanese markets and restaurants but Minamoto has gone to the extent of serving the specific Japanese tea ceremony style confections. I want to believe that this is the same chain that is in NYC, London, Singapore (http://www.kitchoan.com) but it's not indicated on their somewhat fragmented website. Been told you can find some Minamoto items at the Mitsuwa marketplace but I'll have to verify for myself.

Everything is exquisitely packaged and the attention to detail (so Japanese!) is phenomenal. My fruit jelly was put together almost in an origami style fold and had a puzzle like quality. The texture, the taste, look were all subtle as most Japanese food is. Not for the faint of heart as these items are pricey, but one must understand the craftsmanship and attention to detail that is put into these to really appreciate them to accept the price tag. Otherwise you might want to hit Powell's sweet shop if you're looking for something less subtle.
author: Kim N.

description: It's a pricey place but it is definitely worth the price. I had a strawberry mochi and it was incredible. The ladies behind the counter were also absolute sweethearts even to me in my baggy sweater and backpack. Haha
author: Joshua V.

description:
This place is a mochi garden of delights!

The first time I walked into this place, it was like walking into Yoshi Wanka's Wagashi factory.  They have so many varieties of Japanese sweets/confections.  I heard their entire inventory is flown in directly from Japan, so that basically makes it HELLA Japanese.  It felt like all of the girls of Morning Musume might pop in at any moment.

My favorite is the Sakura Daifuku, which is a seasonal cherry blossom confection.  These pink pieces of heaven sell pretty quickly when they arrive.  One time, as I arrived, I saw a couple of tourist lingering behind the display case which contained the last five pieces of Sakura Daifuku.  They were spending time with the clerk inquiring about some of the selections in front of them.  Thinking quickly, I spoke to the other clerk - in Japanese - to request the five pieces.  She gladly retrieved them for me even before the tourist realized what had happened.  Five star service! (PS Don't ever get between me and my mochi.)

In the event that you do feel like sharing, they package the pieces in really nice boxes which make terrific presents.
author: Shea G.

description:
My favorite are 

1. Mochi (they have several kind with an (bean past) inside. You have to eat Mochi within maximum 2 days to enjoy the soft / chewy consistency. Kitchoan's mochi are all shipped from Japan frozen and defrosted at the store. I really appreciate seasonal fresh mochi from sweet shops in Japan. It is nothing like freshly made mochi. That said, I like Kitchoan's defrosted mochi better than benkyo-do's fresh mochi. Why? I prefer more refined sweets at Kichoan better than country side grand ma sweet shop Benkyo-do. I believe Wagashi (Japanese Sweets http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wagashi) suppose to be beautiful, delicately colored / flavored, seasonal, and follow traditional craftsmanship. Also I really like Kitchoan's beautiful gift boxes (you can ask them to put whatever you select in their washi box!) 

2. I enjoyed their very fragrant crystallized Yuzu skin.
author: Chie J.

description: Japanese pastries! A treasure of bite size delicacies. I want to try them ALL. Rice cakes, yokan, mochi, wagashi, sponge cake. It's a pretty fancy sweet shop. Everything is displayed nicely so you can see what's inside each piece and what it's made of. Very helpful for first timers.
author: Charlene K.

description:
This place inside looks like jewelry store, really..
I picked Japanese sweets as a gift to one of my clients, it is quite pricey for the sweet goods.
While picking sweets for the gift I got for myself almond biscuit, i regret that I ate it later, after giving the gift ... well it tasted ok, but wasn't fresh, was kind of stale...
It's cool idea, great wrapping, but I wouldn't be back...
author: Anelya S.

description: SUPER expensive. Limited selection. Eh. Have not yet tried it but I bought a couple mochi's. The workers here are really nice though.
author: Stacey W.

description: Crazy pricy but delicious. I had a handful of the treats but the sakuramochi is my favorite - the texture of the mochi is perfect and the salted sakura is just lovely.
author: Monica L.

description:
For those of you who have lived in a cave/hovel/Uni-Bomber bunker, Mochi is a popular Japanese Confection consisting of sweetened rice that has been pounded into a sticky gooey consistency, conventionally filled with a sweetened bean paste called Azuki. It's definitely not your conventional sweet dessert, but texturally it's divine.

Nowadays, Mochi is pretty much everywhere, one iteration that is very popular is the Mochi Ice Cream (ice cream filled Mochi in various flavors) which is popular in Japanese restaurants.

However, for the real thing, you have to go and buy from an authentic Japanese confection shop; so when we're in SF, Minamoto Kitchoan is a destination must that should not be missed...

You immediately get a sense of Japanese culture once you enter the store; like entering a pristine showroom, only with sweets on display instead of cars.....candy cars....anyways....

The interior is modern minimalism, clean but warm with distinctly Japanese touches.  The displays are incredibly elegant, each piece is shown like a piece of artwork, elevating them to a higher level. (if you could taste with your eyes, it would be heaven!)

Minamoto Kitchoan has all types of sweet and not all of them are the same: you have Mochi in it's plural iterations, Jellies and Custards, sugar candies, Castella (Portuguese Honey Cakes), and then there's something called Yokan- a Red Bean Jello/Agar brick block that is utterly horrendous, (my opinion)....I wouldn't get that....

We have two favorites at this shop; they embody the best of both worlds.  It's a hybrid between the West and the East: Chocolate Mochi!!!

There are two different types: the Dark Chocolate Mochi has Powdered chocolate covered MOchi with a creamy chocolate center.  The quality of chocolate combined with the soft elastic texture of the MOchi provides the perfect meld between both worlds... There's six to a box, so it's a precious confection- we savor every bite

The other Mochi we get is the Green Tea White Chocolate-super heavenly delicious: Powdered Green Tea covered Mochi with White Chocolate Filling.  I love how the White Chocolate works so well with Green Tea, it's culinary evolution!

 Minamoto Kitchoan has stores all over the Country: LA, NY as well as all over the world (Taipei, Singapore, Hong Kong and of Course, Tokyo).

If you're ever in the mood for some authentic and innovative Japanese sweets, Minamoto Kitchoan is a must, especially if you're a cultural enthusiast!
author: Alan M.

description:
Oh Yelp, why hath thou misled me after so many years of great advice?  

So the first thing I have to say about this place is that it is not a candy store.  

The second thing I have to say is that it isn't a bakery, either.  

The store features authentic Japanese cakes, jellies, and mochi - of course, all excessively albeit adorably wrapped in Japanese designer pastel paper.  In case this has not been made clear, none of the items in stock are made in-store, which I consider one prerequisite to a place being deemed a bakery (and ohhhh do I love bakeries from all over the world).  Rather, everything is imported from Japan.  

That's right, preservative packed snacks shipped to San Francisco.  The kasutera cake may be airy and yummy; the jellies might have a high variety, and the mochi may contain more variations of red bean paste than you ever imagined possible, but still.  This is no better than what your friends bring back after a trip in Japan, or what you could order online?  

The shopaholic in me wanted so badly to purchase something from this highly rated shop, but alas, I could find nothing at Minamoto's that would tempt my easily sold palette.  Still, the salesladies were incredibly sweet.  And the place is cute.  I suppose if you're realllyyyyy into mochi and jellies, this would be the place to go.  But this sweet tooth prefers her desserts freshly baked.
author: Aimee P.

description:
I always feel a little guilty buying from here since they have such a big carbon footprint, but after I take the first bite, that guilt just sorta disappears...

Some key things to try: 

- Fukuwatashisenbei - Two crinkle vanilla cookies with cream in the middle
- Tsuya - red beans between two pancake-like cookies
- Any kind of mochi they offer. It's the best!
- Ayashirabe - Thin pancake layer with sweet white bean paste in the middle

Those are my top 4, but I've never had a bad experience here. These make wonderful gifts as well, especially if you want to make a good first impression when visiting your SO's parents for the first time. ;) They are a bit pricy, but worth every penny. If you buy a lot or buy often, make sure to get the stamp card!
author: Jen D.

description: Amazingly yummy treats which are are close to Japan as I can get. The people who work there are very friendly are always can suggest the right type of gift(s). 5 stars!
author: Bella B.

description:
My choice of hosts' gift when attending a dinner party.

There was a minamoto kitchoan near where I used to live in Tokyo so going inside and being greeted 'irashaimase' from the elderly japanese women make me feel at home.  

They are so helpful and carefully explain every delicacies you have questions on. 

Favorites: peach mochi with white bean (hakutoumochi), ume jelly (kohakukanume- try it frozen!) , see-through jelly with cherry (sakuranmbo), dried persimmon with sweet white bean paste (suikansyuku)

***Be careful who you give these to gift boxes ($30-50) to.  For people who are unaware of japanese delicacies, it may as well have been $10 box of cupcakes when they 1.don't eat it  2.chomp it down without tasting it 

food is an art people.  slow down and enjoy life.
author: Hannah W.

description:
Maybe my taste buds are just blasted, but everything here tastes underwhelming. The presentation, shopping experience and even texture of these confections are all amazing -- it's just the flavor is so delicate as to almost not register. I'm not asking for sweet, but I would like bolder flavors.

I tried a sesame mochi which tasted like, well, raw sesame. Raw sesame is nearly flavorless (if you're imagining that thick black sesame paste of Chinese pastires, don't.) I tried a pear jelly. This had the best flavor of all, with distinct pear aroma, but it felt more like I was sniffing a wrapper that had a good pear dessert in it, rather than actually eating pear. The red bean fish also suffered from lack of red bean flavor.

This place looks pretty, but any number of dessert places in Japantown taste much better and cost much less. If you truly eat with your eyes, you'll enjoy it. But those of us who eat with our tongues and noses should look elsewhere.
author: Alexander J.

description:
When I lived in Manhattan, there was one of these shops in Rockefeller Center that I really missed.  So glad a location opened in my new home of San Francisco.  I know there are similar shops in Japantown selling at a lower price point, but the presentation really is top notch here.  I'm by  no means a Japanese snack connoisseur, but the goods taste higher quality here than those in Japantown too!  As pricey as fancy chocolates ($8 for one piece of Suikanshuku), these are nice small snacks for days when you want to treat yourself.

Suikanshuku: Pasty red/white/kidney bean center with bits of dried persimmon.  Gelatinous outer layer crusted in sugar.  The sugar crust is unfamiliar to me from my experience with Japanese treats so I enjoyed it compared to the normal cakey outer layer.
author: Adam B.

description:
If only they were a bit cheaper. 

I found this place a year ago while I was frolicking on Market Street on a Saturday. Went again after visiting Crocker Galleria. I LOVE their Sakuranbo, which is Japanese cherry covered with lightly sweetened Jelly (http://www.kitchoan.com/?page_id=127).  

I think it was $4 a piece (at least according to the website), so it is NOT cheap. But the shop is so....calm and beautiful. And their products are pretty tempting. But I stopped myself and left with just one Sakuranbo.

The employees here seem to be actual Japanese people, and they're really nice. Like I mentioned earlier, the store is so calm - it's like a zen place amidst the busyness & loudness of Market street. 

Visit if you're in the area. I don't think you'll regret it.
author: Soo Jung R.

description: first time here. wasn't so great. i got a chocolate type of mochi covered with cookie crumbs which i did enjoy. i also got a mini pancake sandwich with red bean paste inside which i did not enjoy. it barely had a taste to anything and worse is that the sweets are a bit expensive when the sweets aren't even tasty. my sister got 3 treats and i took a bite of hers, not good at all. craving japanese sweets? try another place.
author: Cake L.

description:
I got a box of treats for my birthday (thanks, Denise!) and I ate all of it before I could take photos! 

I loved the oak leaf mochi! The aroma of the leaf elevated the mochi experience exponentially! I felt like I was eating mochi in a forest IN JAPAN! 

All the jellies are good too! I was leery of bean-filled jelly but they are all tasty! 

Crackers are nice and crunchy but nothing out of the ordinary. The bean cakes (fish filled and flat) are both delicious but also nothing out of the ordinary. 

The box sets make lovely gifts! I enjoyed opening the box and exploring all the little items.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
came here and tried a few items. yeah, it's not cheap. 4 items for $31. 


 I  tried the Laquat Jelly (seasonal item).  not super impress.  but the green tea pastry Maccha Busse (sponge cake)  I bought is amazing.
the $20 a piece whole white peach jelly is pricey but I love it.
the Muscat sherbet is just an ok. I did put it in the freezer.


I did a little research on this shop.  All the sweets sold by this shop is made by their own company.  they didn't just import from random store.  here's their company website in Japan
http://www.kitchoan.co.jp
they are actually not over price. for example the whole peach jelly is sold here for $20 and is sold in Japan for about $13. which I think is fair for the $7 air ship desert directly from Japan. Eating these desert in Japan is a elegant thing you don't just start eating in as soon as you are out of the store.  bring it home, put it on a pretty plate and enjoy it with a nice cup of tea.
I only wish they can give free boxes since the desert is not cheap and can be crushed easily.
you can head to the Daiso shop about a block down  to get a cute box for $1.49 to put these lovely desert in. 
I will definitely be back for more!
author: Rina C.

description:
The place was beautifully lit like a lighting designer had just walked out before you got there. The candy so beautifully arranged not unlike Japanese flowers, IKEBANA... The candy was amazing, and unexpectedly so with so much bean paste. But its an awesome place to grab a gift for anyone who likes amazingly cute stuff, and/or Japan. Ganbatte!!!

It gets a 5 because there is nothing else like it, or anything as cool.
author: Ricky V.

description:
On my way to the Apple Store with a coworker, trying to recover from the heat wave, we didn't get a block from our office when saw the beautiful amber light glowing from the large picture windows of Minamoto Kitchoan.

The elegant silver signage simply proclaims: JAPANESE SWEETS and inside you'll find a fantasyland of delicious, delicate Japanese desserts and treats. The store itself is reserved, immaculate. minimalist and well-lighted like you would imagine a Japanese sweet shop should be.

I had the Maccha Manyu ($2.20) and a sample of my co-worker's Fukuwatashi Senbei ($2.50). The Maccha was a chilled mochi-type treat and the Fukuwatashi was like a cream-filled waffle. 

I'm no asia-phile and I needed my co-worker to help me figure out what to get, but damn was I impressed!

What a exquisite shop to have near Montgomery BART. If you need to pick up a chic, sweet gift on the go this is your place or if you're tired of taking Peet's and Specialty's breaks during the workday (as am I), this will be a great alternative because there were several treats in $2.50 to $4 range.
author: Alexis W.

description:
Let's just say that from a purely aesthetic perspective, if Apple were a dessert company, it would be Minamoto Kitchoan. And vice versa as well. If someone told me that Steve Jobs drew inspiration from this place, I'd totally believe it.

The treats here are so visually delightful that I don't even care about the taste.
author: L W.

description: The people who work there are super helpful & nice, and their mochi is always fresh. No complaints
author: Monica A.

description:
The taste of the sweets is divine. Can find a variety of Japanese desserts, and wonderful to have a place that offers such cuisine. However, I give it 4 stars as opposed to 5 because of the fact that they don't have any samples of the dessert and not being Japanese, I would not know what each taste like. I had to purchase one of each of the sweets I was interested in in order to sample it. 

But if you like Japanese dessert, I recommend this place!
author: Aisha A.

description:
I begrudingly give this place a freaking awesome 5 stars.  

First thing - it's dang expensive.  It's like the Prada of sweet shops.  It's got locations all over the world, where every other expensive boutique lives.  5th avenue NYC, Hong Kong, Tokyo, London, etc etc.  

Everything, even without being hand-wrapped as a gift by the impeccably dressed and mannered staff, already looks too good to eat.  But when you do actually eat the little sweet nuggets of taste-bud gold, you think and plan about when you can go back immediately.

Got the white chocolate mochi.
And you should too.
It's covered in an intense green tea powder, almost like the dry chanoyu kind that they use in Japanese tea ceremonies.  If you pop the whole thing in your mouth, and then begin to chew that way, it's almost overwhelming.  But once the flavors and textures all meld together, you find that every single thing compliments the other.  The dryness of the powder with the moistness of the mochi.  The bitterness of the green tea with the sweet, warm cream of the white chocolate filling.  

There's a strawberry jelly thing that comes inside its own little plastic container.  It looks almost translucent on the outside, giving way to a delicious red inside.  It's $4.  And you eat it in about a second and a half.  And once you do, you want more.  

Got some other stuff too but...

I've got to go now eat some more and maybe jill off in the process...
author: HQ G.

description: The items here are so adorable but so expensive. The little snacks and dessert items are in cute packaging and shapes and really highlights the natural ingredients. None of the snacks are super sweet and they all make great snacks to pair with tea. There's  also seasonal items so you're bound to visit every now and then to see what's new. The current seasonal item (November) is a persimmon filled with white bean paste which is so delicious but will cost you $8 and is smaller than your palm.
author: Grace L.

description:
Ridiculously expensive, but apparently delightful treats.  4.5 stars (-.5 star for expensiveness).

I had the seasonal Kaze Kaoru (Red bean paste with citrus flavored rice cake) and it was wonderful (see picture)... and $3 for a single piece.  That was more or less the low end for this shop, unless you're interested in the standard red bean paste treats.

If I'm feeling rich I may try more and update (they may get 5 stars if they continue to impress me), but I don't know if I'm feeling rich.  The black sesame red bean paste balls certainly looked good, though...
author: Audrey C.

description:
I absolutely love this place. 

It feels like such an authentic little Japanese sweet shop, right smack dab in the middle of downtown San Francisco. I only happened to spy it by chance when I was walking across the street and made a bee line straight for it.

The interior is bright, airy, and incredibly streamlined and clean. Frankly, it's very beautiful. The women who work here are attentive and not pushy in any way whatsoever. The moment one of the saleswomen saw that I had picked up something to purchase she immediately came over and offered me a shopping basket and left, never hovering, but always there to help as soon as she was needed. Both women were kind and professional. The products are made with such care and quality, and the taste is outstanding. I bought a bag of their spicy rice crackers and was completely satisfied with how light and crispy they were. I also bought a chocolate ganache shocora mikasa (pan cake) that was PHENOMENAL, and my boyfriend bought multiple types of mochi, including the red bean, green tea, and strawberry, According to him, they were the best he's had. My only complaint is regarding the prices; definitely on the steep side. There were so many things I wanted to try, but didn't have enough to spend on them. Regardless, I'll definitely be coming back here. It's worth the trip, and I was very impressed.
author: Angela M.

description:
I have been looking for a Japanese sweets store for seven years. This is amazing. I've been to the ones in Japan town, and I did not find them to be adequate. This place is as close to Japan as you get (probably because they only import from Japan...).

The only difference was that in Japan, everything was made fresh..so that in itself puts it on a new level, but this is very very good.

Yea, expensive, but it's Fidi. I spent $10 and felt it was well worth it.
author: Cory D.

description: A vast array of delicious and beautiful Japanese sweets. I'm addicted to the tiny little lemony bunnies.
author: Katie E.

description:
This little shop is so pristine, so adorable, and so delicious. 
Most single items, such as daifuku, go for $3, but there are some items even fancier that are more expensive. They have stunning gift boxes for most of the items. 
The service is friendly and they even offer advice on the sweets, such as enjoying the daifuku the day you buy it. 
They also sell matcha and bamnkucken. They have a few iced bottled teas as well.
author: Heather F.

description:
We just happened to walk by and noticed the window display, very much in the Japanese sushi restaurants...but hold on, it wasn't sushi.  We had to investigate.  

This simply shop displayed the various Japanese sweets known as "Wagashi".  Food in Japanese culture is both pleasing to the eyes but also tastes really good.  We grabbed a basket and started reading the little signs describing the flavor and type of sweet.  Some we're like Chinese moon cakes with red bean fillings, while others were mochi with different seasonal fillings, while others were jellies fill with fruit.  There was also an interesting item we picked up, it was a block of jelly which you push through a tube into individual strings and you dip into a sweet sauce.  My girls loved everything we brought it.  I should add, we really loved the sweets with whole chestnuts in the middle.

It was a slightly pricey treat, but all so good.  The sales women inside the store were all very sweet and of course polite.  The one that helped us was even teaching my daughters some of the words they didn't recognize in Kenji.
author: Twist' D.

description: Good selection of traditional Japanese sweets. Get here early or your first choice may be sold out. I would give 4 stars but the staff isn't particularly helpful or friendly. Not a great shopping experience.
author: H. H.

description:
Finding really good manju is hard outside of J-Town.  I was really excited to pass this place on my way to my hair appointment and even more excited that it was open when I got out.  I bought what looks like 2 small pancakes with red bean paste inside and a pounded rice with red bean paste inside.  They are pretty sweet so it's great paired with a good strong green tea.

Pricey.  I spent $6 on both of them where a lot of places I would have bought a package for about the same price.  However, I liked these better and it's not like I'm going to eat bucket loads of them.
author: Ashley I.

description: This place is amazing. I fly to San Fran just because their China Town is the best in the world, legit. The treats here make you feel like you're really in Japan. The sweets are so delicious.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Minamoto, I loved you from afar all these years.  I would walk by you when I worked on Market street, and you would coyly wink and smile at me as I hurried by.  Many many times I would walk by glancing at you and being too afraid of saying hello.  Knowing that once I did, I would fall in love.

And, amongst a group of out of town friends who were waiting for our reservation at Yank Sing ... I stopped in.  I fell in love.  I can't resist little sweet things so perfectly wrapped up as only the Asians can do cute packaging.  I love the high level of service that only the Japanese seem to provide.  

I love everything about you, and I'm looking at my stamp card, and I know I need to come back and see you again :-)
author: Joe S.

description:
okay ive been here a couple of times already but just havent reviewed it yet. Yes it is a bit pricy but it is also authentic japanese sweet from japan. All the items are priced with a 'best by' date and each look really yummy. So far my favorite is Kuri Daifuku (Rice Cake, $3.00 each). I love chestnut and it satisfied my appetite since theres a whole chestnut inside the red bean paste and mochi. This time around, I bought Kasuteira (Green Tea Sponge Cake, $13.00) Maccha Manjyu ( Bean Cake, $2.20 each), Cheese Busse (Sponge Cake, $3.50), Tenkataihei (Fish Shaped Bean Cake, $3.00 each), and Daikitchoimo (Sweet Potato Cake, $ 4.00 each). The total came out to $25.70. They dont charge tax. They take cash or credit/debit card (Visa, Mastercard, Discovery). The people are always friendly and eager to help. The store is bright and welcoming. I will come here again when I want some japanese sweets and have some cash, haha.

* Now I can add Tenkataihei and Kasuteira to my favorites. The Tenkataihei is yummy, the outside was a thin cake layer that looks like a fish and inside is sweet red bean paste with whole red beans. The Kasuteira is basically a sweet green tea cake that tastes wonderful with tea. The tea part tastes like matcha green tea and it is very yummy.
author: Jen M.

description: Very cute little Japanese sweet shop. They have a great variety of mochi, crackers, little cakes, and other treats. I love the display cases which make you feel like you're browsing at an upscale jewelry store. They always have great seasonal items so it's fun to go back. Definitely pricey but worth the splurge and makes for great gifts.
author: Alice J.

description: Huge selection of fancy mochi and other sweets. Prices are a bit high but it's all about the quality of the product and they treat everyone like family. Great place to satisfy your sweet tooth or trip out on the time and detail they put into their sweets.
author: T L.

description:
Irrashaimase! 

Introduced to me by fellow manju aficionado ChristyD, I was excited to visit this little Japanese import store for myself. 

Walking in you are greeted by a long glass display case full of tempting treats or wagashi (traditional Japanese confectionary to be served with tea - aka tea cakes) - each with an explanation card detailing the contents and some even with cross sections so you know what is inside. 

I deliberated and selected 3 treats:
-Aya shirabe ($3): translation to "bean cake" does not do it justice. It's made of smoothly ground kidney beans, sweetened and then wrapped in a firm cake.
-Kuri Daifuku ($3): Kuri = chestnut which is my favorite. This one is a mochi outside filled with sweet red bean paste wrapped around a chestnut center. The mochi was beautifully light and delicate but with a nice chew. Mmmm. 
-Ohagi Kurogoma ($2.50): Ground black seasame fills the center of this mochi ball. I love the flavor of the black sesame. It's good for you too I hear. But beware that it may leave some unpleasant seeds in your teeth. 

Note, many items are frozen given the imported nature of shipment. So some need an hour of thawing. The store clerks will instruct you. 

Prices vary from about $2.50  - $3.50, at least for the ones I chose. Great as a gift and for tea time. Oh, and you can get a stamp card to keep you coming back for more.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Hey, what happened to irra-shai-mase?  Was on our way to the gallery opening event downtown last night when I was surprised to see a store with Japanese sweets.  When did this get here...I thought this used to be a See's Candy store at one time.

Anyway, the reason I'm jokingly writing about irra-shai-mase here is because when you walk into a traditional store or business in Japan, you usually get a warm greeting.  I realize they were helping somebody, but I didn't get such a greeting or the warm and fuzzies during the time that we were in there.  We were actually ignored.  Very odd.

Regardless, I loved their variety and the presentation of the sweets in their display cases was downright perfect.  Although a box of these confections can get pricey (nothing compared to what I've seen on business trips to Japan), the cost per piece was appealingly reasonable.  A lot of exciting, delicious choices were available for only $2.50.  

Will definitely have to go back although I do wonder if this is the ideal location for them to open such a store.  No parking at all and away from the downtown shoppers.  I think they would have done better opening up closer to Westfield Center since the higher rent would have been offset by the much greater foot traffic.  The Ferry Building would have been an awesome place.  Heck, even Embarcadero Center or the Marina would have been a better choice to open such a store in my opinion.
author: Roy N.

description: I was walking by with a friend who wanted to get a sweet snack, so we decided to check it out. The packaging and displays for everything was lovely, like most Japanese treat places, and the lady behind the counter was very pleasant. I was not in the mood for mochi, but I did get a bag of spicy rice crackers that were great.
author: Seong P.

description:
I'll never forget during my first trip to Japan when I first descended to the basement of the department store, where they had groceries and food counters galore selling everything from fresh fruit and veggies to elegant cakes and chocolates. Minamoto Kitchoan has one such place in Ginza district in Tokyo selling traditional Japanese sweets: glutinous rice cakes filled with sweet chestnut/bean paste, dried persimmons, jellies. 

And in their SF store, you can also get a small taste of Japan, freshly imported. Mind you it will cost you a pretty penny: I think $2/ea was the cheapest price I saw for a tiny chestnut cake you could probably pop entirely in your mouth. But to me, it is totally worth it!

For a cheaper alternative, you could try Nippon-ya in Japantown, but it will be nowhere near as exquisite or fresh (but typically with a much longer shelf life).
author: natalie n.

description: Simply amazing asian desserts. Very fancy and very expensive but delicious.
author: C. C.

description:
The best little Japanese dessert place I've been to. And to think, the only way we found this gem was in the midst of getting lost in SF!

Pricey? Yes. Worth it? Totally. And I'm usually never a fan of these types of desserts. There's no point naming off what I ate, cuz I bought a buncha diff types and loved each of them in their own special ways. Be sure to get the limited seasonal ones--  this time it was the dried persimmon w/white bean inside. DELICIOUS. I wish there was space inside to sit and eat... but luckily we found a seating area outside to eat and relish in the perfect SF weather.

I'm driving back here justtt to grab more goodies for the parents before Thanksgiving.
author: g k.

description:
I love this place! A small little Japanese dessert store in the heart of Financial? Count me in! 
The ladies were incredibly sweet and helped me find a cookie that my Dad would have eaten when he was a little boy in Japan. 
A bit pricey, but it's all imported from Japan, and I would definitely say it's worth it.
author: Monique K.

description:
I have been to this Japanese store for 2 times, and I am satisfied for both the service and the candy!
This little place located in a busy street, but once you get in, you know this place is different. The store is quiet and bright, also, all the candies look really attractive!
My personal favorite is the taiyaki (Fish-shape red bean cake) and grapefruit jelly.

Although the candies are pricy, but it's worth to try.
author: Chow P.

description:
These Japanese treats are seriously good.  I became addicted in NY when I worked near their midtown location.  My sister and I would meet up there for an afternoon snack and loved trying things that were completely new to us and seeing the seasonal offerings that they provide.  This is truly a special store.  Please go and try something new today - you'll be glad you did.
I only wish that they still carried the gen ma chai tea that I loved so much...
author: Arran S.

description:
If you want to go to Japan but can't afford the airfare, just go into Minamoto Kitchoan. With their minimalist Japanese décor, I felt like I've walked through Doraemon's "Anywhere Door" when I came in. The displays and packaging are absolutely gorgeous; you can tell attention is paid to the smallest of details. I really enjoyed looking at all the plastic models of their wagashi, which are cute, realistic, and yummy-looking. I think I ate more with my eyes than my mouth here!

All their wagashi is imported from Japan so they're definitely authentic. But, imported also means their prices are on the steep side.

On my last visit I got the chocolate mikasa, cheese busse, kibimochi, and aya shirabe (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/H6jEWhnxWlzTobANR-VNJg?select=GeffZNpsdVIrTh98qDkg9A). 
- chocolate mikasa (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/H6jEWhnxWlzTobANR-VNJg?select=DtZA4XSn8Jg87B6oYfigog): similar to a dorayaki, with rich chocolate cream sandwiched between two sweet pancakes
- cheese busse (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/H6jEWhnxWlzTobANR-VNJg?select=1CVunrZ3MLlg8VQvNRMY-w): sponge cake with a buttery cream filling
- kibimochi (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/H6jEWhnxWlzTobANR-VNJg?select=4FgYBMJDuuTWKosmuMdLhQ): two small mochi filled with smooth red bean paste and coated with kinako, or roasted soybean flour. The mochi wasn't as soft as I'd like but the red bean paste and kinako were good. 
- aya shirabe (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/H6jEWhnxWlzTobANR-VNJg?select=ZXlT4KgVbDTzYzBlSi2RQQ): puck-shaped sweet white bean paste wrapped in a crepe.

All were pretty good, but nothing all that special, especially considering their prices.

I've also tried their yuzu and shiso yōkan (a jellied dessert) before but wasn't a fan of the hard texture or the taste, even though I normally love yuzu and shiso...

Aside from how cute everything looked--the Japanese have definitely perfected the art of making your food look as good (if not better) than it tastes--the service really stood out. It's Japanese hospitality at its best - the ladies are extremely polite, use both hands when handing you something, and bow to you when you leave!
author: Steph L.

description:
Delicious sweets, but really pricey. It's not something to be snacking on everyday, but well worth it for a special occasion or just a splurge.

The bunny pastry they had here are awesome. They look great and are fresh even though they're packaged. 

I'm not sure, but it looks like everything is packaged sweets here. They have this frequent customer card, where you spend $100 and get a $5 off your next purchase.
author: Steven B.

description:
Wow!  Beautiful store filled with stunning Japanese goodies.  These tasteful sweets are so well packaged one almost (yes, almost) feels sorry to need to eat one!

Makes a great gift.  (At least I would be thrilled to get some.)

Tanoshimu!
author: David A.

description:
Leisurely.  Detailed.  Novel.

Just when you thought you were going to give your boss another coffee mug warmer from Walgreens, BOOM!  A magical shop from the likes of "Howls Moving Castle" and "Spirited Away" emanates on Market St.  The dainty, detailed sweets will lure you in, the intriguingly friendly and docile Japanese women will keep you wandering.

Minamoto Kitchoan is for the adventurous tongue (read: slightly sweet gelatinous triangles specked with Japanese basil)  or for lovers of fine Japanese treats (variety of mochi).  Treats range from $2-5 a piece - well worth the soothing experience, the detailed wrapping, and the delicious treat inside!  

Note:  This is NOT an American venue, so don't expect fast, overly friendly American service.  Service is hands off and speed may be unbearable for impatient, fast-paced city folk.

Pre-boxed goodies $19-55
Pretty box for your sweets $3
Individual goodies $2-5
author: Jane L.

description:
Today is my lovely mom's birthday. All this time, I was wracking my brain, wondering what I should write my 1200th review on, and then it dawned on me - what better way than to dedicate it to my mom on her day!

Minamoto Kitchoan is the type of shop that my mom adores. Filled with beautiful wagashi (Japanese confectionaries), that make her nostalgic for her time spent in Japan and Taiwan. She grew up snacking on these kawaii sweets. The women who work there are extremely gracious, and all the displays are like artwork - you can spend a good half hour just ogling the cases. 

So today, I stopped into the new shop in SF, and picked out a basket full of these adorably packaged sweets that I knew she loved, which included Tsuya (sweet red beans sandwiched between sweet mini pancakes), Oribenishiki (chestnut and sweet red bean paste wrapped in Japanese cake), Fukuwatashi-Senbei (vanilla cream filled cookie), and flavored jellies like bihu and muscat. The very sweet lady who helped me managed to arrange them perfectly into a box - after three different box sizes and various configurations to get it right. She then wrapped it in beautiful Japanese paper. Although they have pre-packaged gift sets, I thought it would be more special to custom make one with items I knew she liked. Plus, these snacks are quite spendy, so you want to make sure who ever is eating them will like every piece. 

I'm going to give her the box later this evening when I take her out to dinner, but I'm pretty sure she's going to love them. After all, she was the one who taught me to enjoy life's most smallest things.
author: Connie C.

description:
All little cakes here are from Japan.

MAMEDAIFUKU. $2.90
STOP!
Don't even say it.
No, It's not that. 
it's not what are you thinking it is!
My God it sounds really bad.
But, it's a nice little sweet rice cake for crying out loud.
Mame is beans.
Daifuku is big happiness, I don't know that's a proper translation but it means good luck.
But it sounds like Die FXXXyou.
About the Nutrition Facts of the MamDieFxxxyou.
1 piece 65g, servings for 1
142 calories, Fat Cal 2,
ingredients:
water, granulated sugar, glutinous rice, red beans, corn starch, peas, trehalose, salt, emulsifier(glycerin esters of fatty acids), amylase, contains milk, and soybean.

KURIDAIFUKU. $3.00
Please don't say that.
1 piece 63g, servings for 1
141 calories, Fat Cal 2,
ingredients: same as above + Chest Nut, sulfite.

TSUYA $3.00
Tsuya? Whatthefxxx?
It's DORA-YAKI, isn't it?
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dorayaki

I hate the jiveass fancy name like "Tsuya" for a "Street" sweet cake.
BullShit!
But, it is GOOD! REALLY GOOD!!!
I MEAN IT!
it makes Benkyodo's lame.
1 piece 80g, servings for 1
196 calories, Fat Cal 1.5,

KUSAMOCHI $2.50
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/H6jEWhnxWlzTobANR-VNJg?select=KDs_aSdWJz0IGfxalwXyIQ

I love Kusamochi. The green thing.
It usually a round rice cake with mugworts, but this one is half-moon.
1 piece 70g, servings for 1
201 calories, Fat Cal 2,
ingredients:
water, granulated sugar, glutinous rice flour, red beans, potato starch, maltose, mugwort, deoxidized starch syrup, salt, emulsifier(glycerin esters of fatty acids), amylase.


Benkyodo closes 5 pm. Sharp!
So, it's difficult for me to go there.
I still like Benkyodo.
But, there is a big difference.
Benkyodo is TAJ, Typical American Japanese.
Yes, I'll say out loud. TAJ.
Japanese call them Nikkei-Jin.
Some times Japanese use the word "Nikkei" as an insult.
In some reason, people still think that people from Japan is better than Nikkei?
That's Bull Shit. 
But, TAJ and J,
I think WW II separate American Japanese and Japanese still.
Speaking Japanese to American Japanese person is very hard for me. They don't talk Japanese much.

About Minamoto Kitchoan.
I can speak Japanese to the store clerks.
And they speak very nice polite Japanese that TAJ can't.
They know how to help a JiveAss Japanese customer like I am.
This is something I don't get at the Benkyodo.
Service of Benkyodo is same as anywhere else like McDonald's.

Uniform?
WHATTHEFXXX?
That's right, they wear uniform!
Shit!
I remember, in Japan, They DO wear uniform.
Banks, Department stores, any business offices, you name it, All ladies still wear uniform in Japan.

I'd like to say again, All products here are FRESH MADE AND FROZEN FROM JAPAN.
SO GOOD!

P.S., All display in the glass case are NOT REAL THING. I thought it was. It was on the glass case looked like a sample, but some dumb ass dude took it. But it looks really real.

By the way,
Jason C. said, "So, how do you say FUKU then?"
In Japanese, right? OK, well, it sounds like "Pho-Cu". I think.
author: Nobu K.

description:
beautiful delicious mochi.
a gorgeous shop.
fantastic gifts.
done.
author: Duey C. H.

description:
Loved this place and i'm hooked.  I love mochi and everything japanese.  I actually bought on my first visit:  Ohagi Kurogoma, Maccha Manjyu, Otafukumen = 8.50.  Which is kinda steep, but it was fresh and super yummy.  

I've been back since and will keep on going back.  The workers are so polite and kind.  I love going here, it just reminds me of my visit to Tokyo a few years back.
author: Brenda H.

description:
The exterior really draws you in. Downtown on Market Street isn't exactly the place I'd expect to find a Japanese sweets shop, so I couldn't resist stopping in for a peek.

The goods are so beautifully cased, wrapped and displayed! I was skeptical about the freshness of pre-packaged manju and wagashi imported all the way from Japan (I can't get on board with the ones at the market), but it held up amazingly well. We purchased a few small treats and they were still fresh today when I ate them (roughly three days later). The rice cake part was tender and soft as if I had just bought it fresh from Fugetsu-do! Thoroughly amazing.

Downside is that manju alone isn't enough of a draw for a trip downtown. They're also pretty pricey but with the flavor and quality you definitely get your money's worth.
author: Torie Y.

description:
For the moderate sweet tooth, this place will be an absolute delight. Designed and executed with the bold yet restrained detail and precise simplicity of Japanese sensibilities, its calming interior and veritable bounty of confections (wagashi) is a treat inside the wrapper and the mouth. Suckers for packaging, beware! You will want everything. Never fear, there will always be a polite, uniformed woman on hand to offer smiles and gentle suggestions.

Those new to this realm of indulgence, let's map it out. Choose a few jellies, mooncakes filled with bean paste, wafers and rice crackers making sure to taste varieties with adzuki, yuzu, bihu and seasonal fruit (currently peach which looks like boobs), and you'll cover the basics.

A fantastic place for a unique gift or a great escape from the bustle of Market St.
author: Ligaya T.

description: Super cute store, staffed by sweet ladies.  Varied treats, yummy!  Only the price keeps it from being amazing.  2.50 per piece of mochi is expensive.
author: Rebecca H.

description: Wow.  Just wow.  Definitely on the pricey side, but you know it's the quality stuff.  The mochi's so soft and chewy.  The cakes so moist and flavorful.  I went to Japanese dessert heaven.  Just be prepared to lose a lot of money cause you'll definitely want to buy the whole store.  Also make sure you get a frequent buyer card!
author: Carolen M.

description:
I LOVE This place!
I first discovered it when i was in NYC; that store is in 30 Rock

- Beautiful pieces of mochi; like pieces of art!
- FRESH and soft mochi; like fluffy pillows of yummy goodness!
- My faves are the ones with red bean paste, green tea or delicately coated in black sesame or peanut

The prices here are a little expensive, but worth it for what you get. 

I'm not really sure what the other reviewer is ranting about regarding the Killing of Whales in Japan. ?!?! 
Are you accusing the owners of Minamoto Kitchen of killing whales in Japan? What's the connection here? Not all Japanese are pro-whale-killing, just like not all Americans are crazy.

Would be nice for reviews to be focused on the business and not racial profiling.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
To be honest, all I know about Japanese sweets is mochi.  I love it.  It feels like biting into a chubby baby's cheeks.  

This place was a bit of overload for me.  Its my own dang fault, but I just couldn't decide!  I went with the macchamanjyu (rice cake, red bean paste, chestnut).  it was pretty good.  I decided to stop there and save myself for another visit.  

Its a cute concept here and I applaud the effort....though it made me want to dress up like a harajuku doll and carry a hello kitty backpack!  

See you next time!
author: Susan L.

description: I love the sweets here. My favorites are the sesame & sour cherry mochi. YUM!
author: Kristina G.

description:
Real pretty and real pricey.  I've been to Minamoto Kitchoan in Tokyo, Los Angeles (in the Mitsuwa), and London.

Where they really shine: seasonal desserts.  Not many places will have the jellied things in the summer, or the manju made to look like seasonal fruit.

Minamoto Kitchoan is the Mercedes-Benz of wagashi - looks real great and costs a lot.  But did you know you can get a more authentic product close by for cheaper?

I prefer:
- Benkyodo in J-town on Buchanan.  The place looks like a little diner, because that's what it is.  Real wagashi for real people.  This family has been in the manju business since before the war.
- Shuei-do in San Jose.  Also family-owned and pre-war.  Their monaka is a lot better than Minamoto Kitchoan.
- Fugetsu-do in Los Angeles.  Also great monaka, and a huge variety.  They also have a bunch of Hawaiian innovations.

And come on Yelpers... you can learn a lot from their web site.  But I've actually been to these places.  Do a bit of original research and write what you know, not what you read somewhere else.
author: Brian D.

description:
My boyfriend and I went in this store last night because I love mochi. We bought a cherry blossom flavored mochi and when we asked for a knife to cut it in two, the clerk asked us to sit on the bench, took the candy in the back, cut it in two for us, and brought it out on an adorable tray with two cups of tea. The tea and candy were wonderful, and the store atmosphere is very soothing and calm.
We liked the service so much that we bought a tray full of sweets. We will be visiting again in the future.
author: Lacy K.

description: My friend and I actually ran into this place by accident walking from FiDi to Union Square to do some shopping.  The words JAPANESE SWEETS on the outside caught my eye, and I interrupted her mid sentence and said MOCHI!  We've been talking about a certain type of mochi for weeks so we went in just to see if they carried it.  Unfortunately, they didn't but we grabbed a bunch of different things to try anyways.  Their displays and packaging is so cute!  They carry a variety of different mochi with (fruits, beans, paste), cakes , daifukus, cookies, filled pancakes, and other desserts.  The people working there are very nice and they even offer to get you cold ones from the back if you want to enjoy them right away.  Their mochi is so fresh and delicious,  some of my favorites were the green tea matcha, the cherry with jelly on the outside, and the tangerine daifuku which had a tangy fruity inside covered with paste and the softest mochi!  I will definitely be back for more!
author: Kymberli C.

description:
A really beautiful, almost like the froyo style candy store (white wavy walls!!) that serves all my Japanese glutinous and red bean sweets!

They are not congested and are laid out in a crisp and elegant way.

The presentation of the store is simple and the lovely, lovely treats will be what I want for my Halloween!

Obviously the treats are not inexpensive, each piece is about a few dollars but I have to say if you crave truly imported indulgence, you have found it!

And with all the business and chain stores, this is a refreshing addition.
author: T L.

description:
You had me at irishaimase.

Ever since my year abroad there are subtleties of Japanese culture I miss from my everyday life. The extreme politeness and attentiveness of Japanese shop owners is not the least of these. On Market and Montgomery of all places I've found my note of nostalgia.

 Entering Minamoto Kitchoan is like stepping into a slice of Japan, as it is authentic in it's design, layout and with how it is run. The layout is simple with display case presenting the different sweets, each with a short English description. The staff greet you warmly as you enter, and are ready to answer any questions without hovering too much. 

Best of all, the selection of sweets are all rather traditional and common in Japan, but I don't know anywhere else in the Bay Area that carries them. Even in Japantown and the Inner Richmond. 

Though the prices may seem high, it's not much more expensive than what a shop in a Seibu department store or a place off of Sanjo-dori in Kyoto would charge.  I'm very pleased with my Usagi (dough bunny rabbits filled with a slightly sweet bean paste,) and a box of ten only cost $20. They would cost $16 at one of the aforementioned stores. Not including cost of plane ticket.

Oh God who am I kidding. I'm just glad I was able to use my Japanese here without the staff looking at me like "Great, another one of these dorks." They were surprised,  laughed and seemed to enjoy it. I'll be sinking a good chunk of money into this place on a regular basis.
author: Keith M.

description:
I recently visited and purchased my first bag full of treats on Christmas Day. (I might just have to start a new Christams Day tradition!) I was excitedly pleased to learn that Minamoto Kitchoan was open on Christmas Day when rest of the City was quiet and closed under a blanket of rain this holiday. My sister and I were warmly welcomed by two attentive Japanese ladies. *Irasshaimase!* Our entire time inside the store, the employees made me feel like I was back in Japan because of the level of service and courtesy they provided.

My sister and I took our time admiring the beautifully displayed individually wrapped treats and eagerly picked up our favorite wagashi. The employees were helpful to explain and point out different sweets I was searching for. Prices start from $2+ (some may think it's a bit costly but the quality ingredients used and beautifully crafted treats makes it well worth it). 

There's a loyalty program stamp card to fill up to earn $5 credit, but it's the experience and quality treats that will make you look forward to coming back.

$3 for gift boxing.
author: Mindy C.

description: I love the green tea mochi with white chocolate inside. Remember to always ask how you should store these desserts before you eat them, and how long the shelf life is. It makes a difference.
author: Eva G.

description: Had a red bean paste filled mochi. Melts in mouth. Could be closer to my office.
author: Bruno N.

description:
Delicious small treats. 

Generally, the treats are tastier and higher quality than ones we find at large Japanese grocery stores.   Since we don't fly around that much lately, and we love Japanese cuisine, we think the sweets are worth it here. They are meant to be savored, not mindlessly gobbled.  Authentic products, good looking packaging, and great service!
author: Karrot L.

description:
No, this place is not called "Japanese Sweets". That's just a sign for non-japanese people to know what the heck this store is selling.

Minamoto Kitchoan is probably 10 times more japaneezy than most stores in japan town. Seriously. It's like stepping into a shop in japan, complete with "irasshaimase" and "arigatogozaimasu" and multiple bows. The employee's english is probably as good as my 4-year-college japanese and that's not a compliment (I suck). However, it's really not that hard to communicate.

The merchandise is as pretty as it is expensive. Only buy them if you can appreciate this kind of magnificent confectionery. Preferably with a nice, steaming cup of ocha. Mmm...

Some small, individually wrapped sweets can cost $3-$5. A box can go somewhere around $70-$100+. Crazy stuff.
author: Ari C.

description:
I have so HAPPY to have found this place, down the street from where I work, no less! I have to admit that while I have savored many a bowl of fine udon in my time, my palate for Japanese sweets had not extended out much further than Pocky and delicious mochi.  This place has so many exquisite treats, it's wonderful! Some of my favorites include: the fukufukusa, which is a waffle-covered red bean cake  confection from my dreams. Similarly, the tsuya red bean cakes are so yummy! And of course, make sure you try the sakura daifuku...absolutely divine!

Don't you love walking into a place in which you know you can order ANYTHING and enjoy every minute of it? I sure as hell do! Can't wait to go back (don't forget your point card)!
author: M. F.

description: The most expensive desserts on the planet. But if you read their story and ingredients you will understand why.  The freshest from straight Japan makes the best for gifts because of the presentation of the desserts.
author: Jaseon F.

description:
Wagashi morsels 
Finally here in SF
Happy tummy
author: Su K.

description: Good quality but absolutely over-priced in Japan and here. If you like the nama-gashi here, you probably have not tasted the best that Japan has to offer. The Yamada Seika in Japantown was much, much better ( except in presentation, which is what you are paying for ). The best here is Seijyu-bai, and they do a very good job with fruit-based wagashi. Anything with chestnuts just seems incomplete.
author: George T.

description:
This place, like their manju, is delicately wrapped up in Japanese beauty. The Girl's Day dolls displayed in the store made my heart melt more than the intricately packaged delicacies displayed beneath the glass.  The dolls beckoned to me, hoping that my dad would help celebrate the momentous month of being female when he asked, "Should we go inside?" My dad got a sakura manju and I had a matcha green tea cake which was light and fluffy and crumbling with matcha powder.  Everything looks much too pretty to eat but since there's a definite expiration date on the package you better get your $10 worth and eat it up.  The workers are diligent with packaging and folding the bag just right with one corner folded...which my dad promptly messed up after reaching in the bag for his piece. Men. They just don't get it!!

In all, this is a beautiful store with high quality mochi and sweets, and if you're willing to plop down some hard-earned $ for a taste to match, go ahead and indulge.
author: Emiko T.

description:
Sophisticated and clean. Every time, when I go to the Europeans dinner party, I carry one box of assorted sweet. All guests are really, really impressed with gift wrapping first, and then the taste, too! 
The service in the store is good and they can make gift box for you under your budget.
author: Y T.

description:
You get what you pay for.  And Minamoto Kitchoan delivers the quality, taste, and aesthetic you expect from these exquisite Japanese confections.  And yes, you pay a bit more... but if somewhere else in SF has this selection and quality at more competitive prices then I'm all ears.  Till then, I'm sold on Minamoto.  Dunno what beef other reviewer had with the staff, as I had nothing but superb service, smiles, and attention from the staff.

Brought my sweetie some choice mochi sweeties tonight.  Amazing box of chocolate mochi (subtly sweet chocolate mochi surrounds a liquid chocolate center then rolled in a semisweet cocoa powder); some fluffy fresh mochi triangles stuffed with red bean; a seasonal sweet of persimmon paste rolled in a sour persimmon "dust"; and a box of assorted fruit jellies with "surprise" jelly centers.

All so beautiful to the eye it's almost a shame to pop into your mouth.

Almost.
author: Rick M.

description:
Freshly imported  Japanese treats with amazing service.

I was recently on a trip to Japan, and most of the fancier treats that I found in Tokyo's dessert floors at the malls could be found here as well. A great selection of treats in a very clean and chic location.

The staff are extraordinarily friendly and helpful to help pick out treats. They are also honest about which sweets might not suit one's tastes. I didn't stay to enjoy the tea service, but I can only imagine it is very well received by others.

My recent visit here was to pick up a plum jelly (includes a plum) cup. It was delicious. I picked one up from the counter and the woman helping me asked if I would be eating it then or later. I told her I'd be eating it within the hour, so she grabbed me a chilled one from the back (it's better served cold).

The only negative thing I can think of is that the FDA is required to screen each and every package that they import. Because of this, it's possible that they run out of a particular favorite snack and though they have it available in a shipping package in the back, they aren't allowed to serve it. This happened during my visit, but that's okay because there was plenty more to enjoy.

The prices may seem high to some, but I find them to be reasonable for the most part. You need to remember that these are being imported directly from Japan, and that in itself is not cheap.

I will definitely return here to get my fill of snacks.
author: Shamim I.

description:
First of it's kind in the city and it's absolutely top quality. This is exactly the type of store you would find in the Ginza district in Tokyo, Japan. From the decor to the displays to the wonderful polite service. Items are pricey, but they are shipped directly from Japan. Made fresh, frozen, shipped over, then defrosted - that's as fresh as you can get without going to Japan yourself!

They have a variety of cakes, mochi, cookies, and other interesting seasonal items. I opted to get a box of the Kibi Mochi for my clients as a nice dessert. Each mochi is individually wrapped and the box is nicely wrapped and makes for a nice gift.

Also tried the...
- Daifuku: sweet red bean, good rice cake dough
- Matcha Mochi: nice green tea flavor, the rice cake part is the best part!
- Kibi Mochi: small individually wrapped, red bean filling with soy powder on the outside, pretty good
author: Linda C.

description:
ONLY for the very select try shiro-an WAGASHI or whatever that is seasonal. par example: 6 pieces $27....do NOT get the eye candy for the unknowing. it is only for those that really can appreciate this. it is not a hershey penn/mars bar thang. it is MOMOYAMA good.

MUST be eaten that day...not the same...these MOCHIGASI are delicate and for the very exclusive before the MATCHA tei-en.

Open...open ...open AUGUST 28, 2009...had it in New York and London ...but only for those that are fans of this special delicacy....!

I spent about $11 for three items and my favorite was the exterior patebrise like thing with matcha bean paste and the biwa jelly..the matcha mochigashi was maaa maaa...
author: miriam b.

description:
Stepping into this Japanese sweet store feels like stepping into a virtual travel transport machine that in just seconds sent me to Tokyo's high end neighborhood of Ginza. 

All the sweets are made and imported from Japan and the store design is exactly like stores you see in Japan. The staff are Japanese, they speaks Japanese and their service is also like what you may experience when you are shopping in Japan. Staff are super polite, soft spoken and very patient when it comes to helping with selection and packaging.  

I bought 4 pieces of sweets of the season to sample. I tried 1 kind of sweet in every category: mochi, jelly and wafer.  

The mochi with a whole chestnut and sweet red bean paste wrapped with lightly green mochi was the winner for me. Then a yuzu (Japanese pamelo) jelly was very dense and a little too sweet for my taste, but still tasty and the scent of fresh yuzu is apparent in this little dessert. I also got a piece of Fukuwatashi Senbei (vanilla cream between two wafers), which was just ok. I had hope the wafers to be little more flaky, but it was more cripy and the cream was mediocare.  

Overall, a good find in SF downtown area and a good place to go when I need to shop for authentic and traditional Japanese sweets for my Japanese friends. Prices are a little on the higher side, average price per piece $2.50 although some specialty and seasonal items costs a little more. But given these are hand made sweets flown in from Japan, you have to throw in a little more for the sky soaring gas prices. Worth a try if you like Japanese sweets done the right way or simply to browse at the beautiful store front and the delicate and dandy little individual sweet. Is definitely not something you'll see in the typical American desserts shop.
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description:
Like it but don't love it.  don't get me wrong, I love manju and this place has it down, perfectly packaged and delicious treats flown from Japan.  

The service is a throwback to 1980's Japan.  Frankly - with this location and the prices - I'm not sure how long this place will be around.  

It's obvious is made for Japanese tourists instead of the Nissei's that live by the Bay.  It's authentic and pricey.  Personally,  I'd rather just haul up to J-Town and support the few small family manju shops that are left.
author: Dean F.

description: beautiful shop with delicious authentic japanese sweets! we bought several mochies and they were all delicious.
author: Char Y.

description:
I walked in there and all three employees greeted me (ilashaimase) 
So i went up to the closest one and said, "do you sell  hiyokomanju,"        a very popular manju made in japan, in japanese. Although the store didn't have it, they offered a similar manju in the shape of a rabbit. We talked for around 15 min about manju and these beautifully hand made boxes that one of the staff members makes as a hobby. I think she should sell them!! I bought roughly $130 of manju for my cousins as a christmas gift and some for myself. The price is pretty expensive but you have to put into account that it's imported. 
Service 5*
Goods 5* 
Decoration 5* 

Feels like you're in Japan, until you walk outside. :\
author: Masashi S.

description:
Giddy, scary, slippery tasty fun!  I had no idea what to expect, and gravitated towards the jellies that didn't have very much bean in them.  The plum and perilla were delightful!

The shop is like a jewelry store, with delicate edible gems on display.
author: Mutant O.

description:
Wow, this place is great! Just upon entering Minamoto I felt transported away from the hustle of Market Street. The counter personal was so calm and kind in helping my wife and I select a mochi to buy. We accepted her offer to help us decide on what to purchase and she gladly answered our questions and explained in detail the stores offerings. We chose a peach mochi of some sort. It was quite expensive for one piece, but the product felt and taste of great quality, so I will say no more about the price ;) 
This was our first time trying mochi, other than the frozen ice cream varieties from the grocery store and my wife and I both agreed that we enjoyed the density and chew of the dough. Minamoto is definitely a shop in the City worth visiting, if not to buy a mochi, at least to see the beautiful displays of mochi throughout the store.
author: Joseph L.

description:
This place is incredible.

Very clean. Very well presented. Nice little japanese ambiance with the geisha like music. All the sweets are fresh from Japan. The store staff were courteous and helpful. 

We bought a selection of sweets and enjoyed them all! Green tea cake, peach cakes etc. Not too sweet - made just right!
author: J P.

description:
Very happy to have a wagashi place in SF.

While their wagashi is not the best I have ever had, I am still very happy to know that I can get good quality wagashi in SF
author: Wakaknee J.

description:
I finally went!

My friend showed up at my house last year with a box of kibimochi and I couldn't believe how good it was...it was exactly what you would get in Japan.

I got off BART at Montgomery and bam, there it was. I walked in there and instantly, I felt like I was shopping at a store back home. All the Japanese sensibility you expect was there. Clean, modern and yet traditional decor, meticulously displayed products and polite sales clerks. Ahhh...LOVE.

I got Sakura Mochi (cherry blossom mochi) and Kusamochi (mochi wrapped in sakura leaf) and they were both very good. Just what you expect from a reputable traditional Japanese confectioner. 

Price? 
Yes, expensive, of course. 
Think of it this way...it costs you $3.00 for 2 bites.
author: Aya C.

description: The problem with Japanese sweets is that they more often than not look better than they taste.  Plus, I don't get how what this store has to offer differs from those you can get at any Japanese grocery store?
author: Kristen S.

description:
This is a seriously posh Japanese sweets place. The inside is gorgeous, clean and fronted by shy, adorable Japanese ladies of course.

This is the real deal of Japanese sweets, which also means it's terribly expensive. This is the place to splurge for little food gifts for a special someone or yourself.

While I'm not terribly familiar with each kind of sweets they have, I say go crazy and try any one-they all look delicious and god'ssakes' it's Japanese-they would have to try hard to make it taste bad.
author: Joh W.

description: All their products are wrapped very nicely and quite tasty but just a little overpriced.
author: Stacey O.

description: The quality of the sweets and the customer service are excellent. This is definetly a posh Japanese sweets shop. The prices are high, but you get what you pay for. I tried several items there, and I have not been disapointed. If you are not familar with what they sell, just try the individual items they have there (instead of the box set). They are all well made. They also give good descriptions of what they sell. Overrall, the items they sell are not very sweet, some are slightly savory.
author: Hiroshi K.

description: I have a confession.  I love, love Japanese sweets!  This place gets me in trouble every time because I always want to try everything.  This place is not a cheap thrill.  It's pretty pricey but so worth it!  You have to savor each morsel and appreciate the freshness and quality that goes into every bite. I usually stop in here when I want to  treat myself or when I am having a bad day and need a pick me up.
author: BXN B.

description: If you live in San Francisco, you don't even know how lucky you are to have this place right in the city! This is the place to get the most delectable Japanese sweets with variety corresponding to the seasons. They carry the most exquisite yokan.  It's a very nice place to get a gift for someone you want to impress. The packaging is exceptional, too.
author: Alice R.

description:
OMG!!!!!  Minamoto Kitchoan is finally here in SF.  I can't believe I didn't know they were open until now.  This is one of my favorite shops in the world.  I used to drag back dozens and dozens of their goodies everytime I went to NY and would harass anyone going to NY, begging them to bring some back for me.

It is really hard to come here and not want to buy everything.

One thing that bums me out, though, is that I noticed the matcha mochi-type treat I bought had artificial food coloring in it - Yellow No. 5 and Blue dye, too.  Yuck!  Not all the goodies have these, but just something to look out for.

I like the fact that all treats have ingredient lists, nutritional info., AND expiration dates on each one.
author: Deanna K.

description:
This is the best find in San Francisco.  This Wagasi (Japanese Sweets) store has it all.  Direct from Japan.

My favorite is the Shocoramochi ( chocolate Mochi) like eating a cloud.  Light, fluffy and chocolate  Pure chocolate wrapped in rice cake topped with cocoa powder.

The Sakuranbo (Cherry Jelly)  a whole cherry with pit and stem enveloped in jelly (like Jello).

Service is outstanding and if your not familiar with the Wagasi they will explain to you.  Most items are seasonal.

The Art Of Five Senses-Wagasi
Appearance
Taste
Texture
Scent
Sound.
Think about this when eating and you will experience all 5.
Aloha
author: Ricky B.

description: Cool treats.  Lots of red bean paste.  I ve been wanting to try this place and finally did.  It was 50/50 on the 8 little sweets I bought.  The fact that it all comes from japan doesn't sit well with the buy local side of me, but I understand that this place has its niche.  Don't know if I will go back, but its worth a 1time stop.  Don't go out of your way, but if you are walking by like I was and want a weird sugar boost, have at it.
author: Duke B.

description: Nice Japanese fusion cuisine located in downtown Napa. Great service and experimental cuisine. Everything we had was excellent. Recommend the spicy crab legs and risotto as well as sashimi, maki, and raman. And the Kikusui Junmai Ginjo sake was fantastic. All really good. The only disappointment was their dessert shop near the entrance. As we left we purchased 1 each of ther chocolate assortments (which is not cheap) and we were shocked that the person helping us picked them out of the display case using their fingers and then put them in a cheap plastic to go container. Totally lacking what you would expect in regards to presentation and packaging. But this is me nitpicking. I recommend this place if you like experimental fusion offerings with a Japanese influence.
author: Robert J.

description:
Wow.  I like!  I felt like I just walked into a shop in Kyoto.  They even use the little tray for you to put your cash on.

Packaging is excellent.  There are so many different treats here, I'm not sure one visit was enough.  I liked the tea treat that I had.  It was tasty and authentic.  It wasn't the absolute best that I've ever had, but, I wouldn't have expected that outside of Japan.  So, until I find something better in this country, they get to have that fifth star.

Note: there was a comparison between this place and Benkyou Dou.  To me, that's like comparing 31 Flavors and See's.  I go to one for ice cream, and another for chocolate.  (Well, I don't go to either, but I hope you get the point.)  They both sell desserts, but totally different kinds of desserts.
author: masa s.

description: can i say that i absolutely love this place? it feels like i have been transported back to japan. the workers are all really nice and polite. this is a self serve place, so grab a basket and fill it up. theres a large variety of cookies and mochi to choose from. all of them starting at $2 to about $5. i tried the green tea cake, it had a nice, soft exterior with a tasty green tea filling. i also had a butter cookie with vanilla cream filling. the cookie was buttery and crunchy and so tasty. the filling was light and not very sweet but you can taste the hint of vanilla. i would love to try more of these treats! i will be back son, they have cute bunny cookies i would love to try!
author: Stella J.

description:
Strolled in to find some gifts for my aunt and mom...Here is my take:

1. Lots to choose from.
2. If you are not already familiar with Japanese Sweets, you may feel intimidated.  All of the packaging lists ingredients in Japanese.
3. Sales clerks don't speak much English, so if you have questions and don't speak Japanese, you may not get the answers you need.
4. They don't offer samples, so you will just have to buy and try and hope you don't pick anything nasty.
5. Everything in the store is neat, orderly and beautiful, with requisite plastic models of each item.

I purchased a Kuridaifuku (whole chestnut covered in red bean, all of which is covered in mochi) - $3, and the Mainohana (three layered steamed sponge cake w/ sweet white bean paste and chestnuts) - $15.  I'm sending both of these home w/ my Dad to give to my Mom and Aunt.  We'll see what they say.
author: Burrito M.

description:
They're in SF now!

I got*:
