Dried persimmon with white bean paste filling -- my folks liked it
Yuzu bubbly pancake thing with red bean and what was probably yuzu flavored mochi inside -- light but filling because of the red bean. I wish someone sold yuzu mochi
Green tea filled cookie thing -- my friends seems to think it was OK.
*These all have proper names in the store and on their menu/flyer

Pretty and beautifully packaged Japanese desserts and snacks. Definitely meant for gifts, but there's a nice selection of smaller, cheaper or individual items you can get. Unfortunately, the little bunny pastries only come in a box. Yeah, the gifts are expensive, but it's fun to browse. The San Jose store has a lot more selection. For what you're paying, you expect the treats to taste a lot better than they are.
author: Amy N.

description: Great little Japanese dessert shop near Montgomery Bart.  There Mochi and other desserts are delicious.  The store is well stocked with plenty of options.  This place looks like it has been transplanted from Japan to San Francisco from the mochis an other treats right down to the little tray that they use to hand you back your receipt and change.
author: Moe J.

description: Best shop in SF for fans of Japanese wagashi. Came here before the holidays to buy a present for a friend that loves this type of sweets. Not cheap but worth it.
author: George M.

description:
I'm so excited that there's finally a place in the city where you can get fresh authentic Japanese sweets.  The storefront could easily be a shop in Ginza (read: they neither westernized nor tried to dumb it down).

They were not the best Japanese sweets I've ever had, and they are a little pricey - but the quality is extremely high and are undeniably tasty.  Now we just need a Toraya here too!

After reading many reviews about the wonderful, helpful staff I was a little surprised that when I went in, I completely baffled the lady working by asking a simple question.  I asked first in English about seasonal items they had, then when she didn't understand I switched to Japanese (kisetsu gentei). When she didn't understand that, I switched back to English.  After a few back and forths, she finally said, "Yes, we have many season limited items.  What season were you interested in?"   Hmmm.......  *Just for clarification, almost all Japanese shops (confectioners and otherwise) have season limited items, so the fact she didn't know what I was talking about right away was slightly odd.

Normally, this wouldn't really bother me, but after reading review after review about the knowledgeable staff it slightly irked me.
author: l s.

description: Absolutely beautiful interior - go just to look around, even if you don't get anything!  I love to give a sampling of these sweets as gifts.  They're so appreciated!  I love the peach jellies and loquat.  It's like traveling to Japan the minute you're through the door.
author: Cristy C.

description:
This place was not what I expected. Yelp has listed this as a candy store, but it is nothing near that. 

The atmosphere is very quiet and serene. They have very traditional Japanese sweets like mochi, jellies, buns, and some chocolate. I felt very out of place when I entered this shop, but the workers were very nice. My friend and I decided to try something since we walked here, but we were very anxious. We weren't sure if we were going to like this. Plus, the treats were quite pricey. We decided to get the green bean mochi and a peach jelly. 

I must say, I was very pleasantly surprised. I wish we bought more. The mochi was very smooth and creamy. The jelly was sweet and potent. Yummm. :) Wish I could buy more right now!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
ooo........ooooo......ooooooooo..........the store is bright, the sales people are nice, & EVERYTHING is beautifully package, as a graphic design major i wanted to buy everything, but i controlled myself & only bought myself 2 items to see how good it really was

hmmmmmmmmm.......the Chocolat Mikasa (chocolate pancake, $3.0) tasted like nutella sandwiched between two dried pancake, that had barely any chocolate flavor.....plus it was only about 3 inches in diameter

the peach jelly ($3.5)....tasted like the 0.99 per bag with many many more serving of peach jelly that I usually buy at the chinese market

i think it is place to buy gifts that look impressive, but taste so so
author: Erica B.

description: So effin' kawaii it makes me want to go teetee. To be honest, I don't have the wildest sweet tooth, so the sensible Japanese know just how to treat the likes of this dullard. Lots of absurdly (yet spartanly dressed) bits goodies... jellies, mochis, cakes, and all kinds of other tasty thingies. It really feels like every old, Japanese woman's purse I've ever rummaged through in my whole life. I'm sure it's my imagination but the place just triggers my olfactory to smell Shiseido. A little pricey, but I'm not opposed to paying for a little something from them if I'm in the mood to gift someone something somewhat sweet. Otherwise, Specialty cookies it is...
author: Roy M.

description: Very, VERY interesting place. I was walking to the BART station and just couldn't resist walking in. The treats were a little on the pricy side but what a wonderful treat! First class ladies waiting on you, the whole place has an up scale jewelry store feel!
author: Brian M.

description: What a great discovery! I was on my way to Sutter Station aka Shitter Station aka Sutter Gutter (don't ask) when I stumbled upon this immaculate and shiny Japanese candy shop. Only a week away from Christmas, my mind was scrambling for gift ideas. What does my brother love? FOOD! Where is one of his favorite vacation spots? JAPAN! No brainer. The store was already set up for the desperate holiday shopper with various assortments scattered across the counters. You could select one of their pre-made assortments or customize your own. The trick was finding items that stayed fresh long enough for my trip home. The staff was great and walked me through all my options. In 15 minutes, I was out of there with 2 boxes of assorted goodies, nicely wrapped and ready for travel!
author: Susan L.

description:
minamoto is a little pocket of japan in the middle of the fidi--complete with the delicious-looking fake food all over, and the actually delicious authentic japanese snacks.  It's got that sterility of a japanese omiyage gift shop, with all the snacks individually sealed and packaged, combined with the warmth of seeing some of my favorite japanese sweet cakes.  they have at least 3 different types of mochi, including a little dumpling-shaped one that I've never had, called kusa-mochi (green tea mochi wrapper folded in half over red bean paste that's not too sweet), a standard red bean stuffed mochi, and a chestnut paste mochi.  they have the classic tsuyu, red bean "sandwich" between two sweet pancakes.  they even have a creme-filled senbei-sandwich cookie, and a bunch of little usagi (rabbit) cakes that i have yet to try (they didn't have any samples at the time, and it was $20 for a box).

They even take your money/credit card on the little tray with the rubber bumps like in japan, and give you your change/receipt on the same tray.  And the two people in the shop were both japanese.

Completing the teleportation of japan, the cakes were about what you'd pay in japan as well...  the mochi/tsuyu/senbei were $2-$3 each (yeah... about the price of a double-double).  yep.  pricey.  but tasty.  and seriously it's like a little oasis of japanese customer service and cute little individually wrapped japanese snacks.
author: Fong L.

description:
I love this place because it feels like stepping into Japan. As much as I would like to buy the sweets for myself, everything is so nicely sculpted and packaged that they almost demand to be given exclusively as gifts.

The staff are super nice and can arrange any combination of sweets into a wonderfully wrapped gift box for a modest charge. Some of the jellies are available chilled if you'd like to eat them right away. Cold bottled teas can also be purchased at the register.

The shelf life of these sweets is very short, so you'll want to eat or gift them right away. Make sure to check the expiration dates.

The few chestnut, mochi, peach and yuzu goodies that I've splurged on were good. The seasonal persimmon treat was especially good. If only there were an adjoining tea room where you could enjoy the sweets with a hot cup of green tea. (I remember a shop in Kyoto that did something like that.) Now that would be luxurious!
author: Matt B.

description: Very extravagant traditional Japanese sweets known by the Japanese as "wagashi."  Minamoto Kitchoan is found in luxury department stores in Japan. If I need to impress a Japanese guest with a dessert gift, can't go wrong here. These wagashi are meant to be savored with a fine Japanese green tea or a cup of whisked matcha tea.
author: Bodhi D.

description: Used their black sesame mochi as a wedding favor and it was a hit! They also have a frequent buyer card...
author: Geri K.

description: I love all the sweets in this store!  My favorite sweet treat place!  Be aware of the very high price.
author: Elena L.

description: I forgot that I went here. I love the Japanese peaches. But gosh damn, why are they so expensive. They have interesting boxes too. Nice to see a japanese candy/cookie store from Japan in San Fran.
author: Joseph C.

description: Cute Japanese candy store right on Market Street.  Everything was eye "candy", look wonderful and I wanted to stand there and buy everything! Must visit again when I go back to SF
author: Nghi L.

description: As much as I lament the un-Japaneseing of Japan Town, I'm grateful that MK is BART-friendly. Got a box of delicious chestnut cakes here and got free gift wrapping. Also had little mochis with black bean filling. Awesome.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Tasty japanese snacks, reminds me of my grandmother. Little expensive though.
author: Brett F.

description: Very good presentation.  Everything is nicely design, presented, and packaged.  Nonetheless, the actual taste of the pastry is not as impressive as their presentation.  It certainly is on the high end when it comes to pricing.  If it's more affordable, I will probably give a 4 star, but considering how much you get out the money you spend, I have to say, probably a 3 star rating is more appropriate.
author: Kai L.

description: If I could hug a store , I would definitely hug this one. This store struck me as a Cartier meets willy wonka with it's amazing sweets encased in beautiful surroundings and delicate wrapping. We bought two desserts and within seconds of leaving dug into those suckers. One bite of the bean cake made me stop in my tracks and utter "wow". So happy I finally got to try this place.
author: Sophia C.

description: This place has the most awesome and unique Japanese desserts.  I love anything with green tea and red bean.
author: Dbear T.

description: the snacks are delicious and look gorgeous.  that is my no. 1 choice of gifts treating my friends and family at all times.  The rusk and mochi are terrific good.  love to drop by there at least once a week to treat something sweets to myself :)
author: Y L.

description:
Beautiful store with an utter zen experience. Walking thru the store brought back child-like wonderment that I had seeming lost after years of consuming overpriced domestic goodies! Ahh sweet confections loosen thy grip on my wallet and self control! 
This place is spendy, but worth every penny. It's always fun to splurge on a taste of real Japanese sweets made in Japan as long as you don't think too deeply about the cost benefits of shipping it all the way around the world. 
I'd say try the seasonal items as they are the most unique and seemingly exotic. I like bang for my buck! Like a trip to Japan without the jetlag! 
The Fukuwatashi Senbei $2.50 was yummy. Remincent of a sugary waffle cone sandwich cookie. 
Kazekaoru - I think that was $3.00. Fan! It was a light and airy crepe with red bean. I heart red bean anything! 
Kurimanju and the Hakuun-no hotori - I think that they were both $3.00 too. My faves! The first was buttery and had intense honey and chestnut flavor with a creamy white bean filling and the latter had just the creamy sweet white bean wrapped in a crepe. 
I'm not a fan of anything jelly, so that knocks out a huge portion of the treats for me. Boo. Its a texture thing! 
I think this store provides a fun and unique nichey product that is worth a try, but I can't say that I'd go back there again unless someone else was buying!
author: Stacy T.

description: Do you need to get away?  Bored of all the usual places?  Step right up, because once you've entered this charming storefront on Market you are gar-run-teed a 15 min Japanese vacation.  I went here to buy a Christmas present for a gluten free friend who loves Japanese candy.  The sales lady was sweet and helpful (double checking all the ingredients, just to be safe) and made a beautiful assortment.  Very high end imported candy that has an expiration date, but everything is such a treasure, encased in its own unique wrapping.  Gift wrapping is recommended if it's the case that you're giving.  Now I'm jealous of my friend, who will get to peel away the layers of beautiful printed papers, and find some exotic treat.  Go here only if you're freshly showered and dressed, otherwise you'll feel (or should if you have any powers of observation) like a big slob.
author: Kathryn M.

description: The sweets are gorgeous and presented beautifully and in general, would make a great gift.  But to be honest, not as tasty as other sweets I've bought from Japan.  It's pretty pricey otherwise I would give it 4 stars!
author: Cathy L.

description: This is the LV/Gucci/Chanel store for japanese pastries.  When I rolled my fat ass into this place I felt out of place.  I usually like the ghetto hole in the wall places like benkyodo but I heard many good things about this place.  I bought a couple of master pieces here but didn't get to try them.  I am too fat to eat cake.  I have to send my fat sister her the next time she visits.  She may close the store down.  fat ass.
author: Fatty A.

description:
walked by today and was drawn in by the design of the shop...
bought an assortment of 'sweets' 
haven't tried them all yet but so far so good and fresh
at first i didn't expect that they would taste good because they look so beautiful... not the case... delicious
author: charlotte s.

description: Some of the goodies are on the pricey side, but that is because they import their items from Japan. The cases are filled with all sorts of beautiful Japanese sweets and confections, and it was hard deciding which ones to purchase! I decided on a white peach jelly/candy and a vanilla zigzag cookie. Both were SO good!
author: Andie C.

description: Very cute display of Japaneses dessert. I really like the green tea mochi.
author: Michelle N.

description: Just in town for 24 hours, so I had to stop in on my way down to meet a friend at the Ferry Building. I got the Sakura Daifuku, and it was incredibly delicious! Yeah, $3 for a small bite is extravagant, but it was so tasty and seasonal, so how could you go wrong?
author: Jennifer S.

description: Very exciting to stumble upon this while I was walking on Market Street today. I loved their NYC store. If you are fan of true Japanese sweets, you will fall in love with this place. I had to get one of everything! If you want to just get one thing, try something seasonal. Right now its chestnut!
author: Tricia G.

description: Cute little shop on Market street with all of the lovely, little Japanese confectioneries that you usually only find in Japantown. A tad bit pricey, but the store is beautifully laid out and has a good variety of high end sweets. Some are sold individually, and they have boxes, too. One Maccha Manjyu (green tea bean cake) was $2.20 and the Kurimanjyu was $2.00. Delicious.
author: Maren P.

description: Very delicious daifuku, indeed much better even than the place we buy it in Japantown. Totally divine.
author: Esme V.

description:
I saw the Japanese Sweets sign from across the street and had to take a peak inside.  If you haven't been to Japan, this is a nice little glimpse to what's in store for you.  Itsy bitsy teeny tiny portions of sugary confections that almost look like plastic models--oh wait a minute! Maybe some of these are plastic models?  

I would recommend buying castella and daifuku  at a Japanese supermarket such as Nijiya before going bonkers on buying red bean sweets here at twice the price here.  And I like Benkyodo too, but what's nice about MK is its convenient location. 

I tried the pale green Kuri Daifuku and it was melty and so good with some hot green tea. It's a nice alternative afternoon snack escape from the humdrum of work. And $3 isn't bad when you think about how much a latte or a cup of frozen yogurt costs for an afternoon pick-me-up.
author: bisou m.

description: Think of this place as a jewelry boutique, but for desserts. Only the Japanese would enshrine plastic, fake candies behind a glass case. So much awesome!
author: Jeremy O.

description: Amazing store with equally amazing variety of seasonal traditional Japanese sweets. I don't think it is too expensive at all. In fact, I think the prices are just right for the quality you get in return. This is not your local See's candy store. Minamoto Kitchoan specializes in truly authentic, in season and extremely high quality desserts. For those who are complaining, what kind of a price do you expect to pay for something like that?
author: alisa o.

description:
Absolutely THRILLED they finally opened a location in the bay area.  Not only is more competition in the arena of Japanese sweets always good, but this place is also well known in Asia with locations abroad in New York and London.

Recent favorites include the kasutera (sponge cake in either matcha or honey flavor) and kazekaoru (think somewhat preforated pancake folded over a red bean filling plus gelee)--DELICIOUS.  Long time favorite is the gomadango (black sesame mochi balls filled with red bean).
author: P B.

description: This brings me right back to Japan! I just love everything about this store. The service is impecable and the the sweets are wonderful. I wish they would give out samples of everything, but it was fine. Yes, they are pricey but you get quality goods here. The items here are beautiful and fresh. Definitely worth a peek if you are in the area!
author: Keromi K.

description: the yuzu bean jelly is heaven. they have chilled ones in the back if you want to eat it right on the spot :)
author: Brian K.
